title: Uber passengers face paying 20 London weeks
story: However TfL bosses today defended the fare rises, saying they were keeping prices 'as affordable as possible'.Shashi Verma, Director of Strategy at TfL said: 'This fares package aims to keep fares as affordable as possible while still ensuring TfL can continue to run clean, green and safe services and support London's continued economic recovery.'Through daily and weekly capping, as well as the Hopper fare and our wide range of concessions, passengers can continue to get the best value fare by using pay as you go with contactless and Oyster.'It comes after TfL secured a last-minute extension of its bailout to keep Tube and bus services running across the capital.¬†The Department for Transport (DfT) provided ¬£4billion in emergency funds to TfL to cover the provider's loss of fare revenue since March 2020.In December to the Government agreed to extend the deal until February - an injection of a further ¬£113million.A DfT spokesperson said in December: 'The Government has repeatedly shown its commitment to supporting London's transport network since the start of the pandemic, providing more than ¬£4 billion in emergency funding to Transport for London.'In addition to the emergency funding, this year's Spending Review settlement for London provided over a billion pounds of capital investment per year, in line with previous funding.'¬†Sadiq Khan, the mayor of London, had previously said that without Government money Londoners could see a reduction of 10 per cent of Tube services, 20 per cent of bus services and more closures of the Rotherhithe Tunnel.¬†¬†¬†Mr Khan has previously indicated that without a solution to TfL's funding crisis, whole Tube lines could close - with the 115-year-old Bakerloo Line mooted to be axed.¬†The mayor has said that he will not be able to balance TfL's books until at least the 202425 financial year and has announced a cull of 500-600 staff members at mainly central London stations to bring down spending.¬†A DfT spokesperson said: 'We have repeatedly shown our commitment to supporting London's transport network throughout the pandemic, providing over ¬£4.5bn in emergency funding to Transport for London and pledging a further billion pounds of capital investment every year up until at least 202425 - all at a time of significant pressure on the national finances.'We're aware that TfL are still feeling the aftereffects of the pandemic but it is the Mayor's responsibility to accelerate overdue reforms that will ensure TfL becomes financially sustainable.'We have offered a short extension of 14 days to continue discussions that will ensure any further settlement represents value for money for taxpayers across the UK.'The DfT says its support of TfL has always been on condition that it reaches financial sustainability 'as soon as possible and with a target date of April 2023'.¬†

title: paris saint germain v real madrid champions league last 16 live
story: Real Madrid have been goal shy of late, so they‚Äôll be pleased to name Karim Benzema in their starting line-up again. Gareth Bale drops to the bench.Advantage Paris? Well, perhaps, but though they‚Äôre top of Ligue 1, the mood music isn‚Äôt perfect. They‚Äôve recently been knocked out of the French Cup, Lionel Messi is in underwhelming form, and the futures of Kylian Mbapp√© and Mauricio Pochettino are up in the air. Whether Real can take advantage is another issue: they‚Äôre top of the league back home, too, but have only scored one goal in their last three games, and are desperate for the return of Karim Benzema, who may or may not return from injury tonight. All set up nicely, then. The glamour tie of the round kicks off at 9pm at the Parc des Princes, 8pm GMT. It‚Äôs on!

title: sporting v manchester city champions league last 16 live
story: The answer is that they have both lost only two league games this season, and drawn only three. For City, that‚Äôs enough to be hot favourites for yet another Premier League title. For Sporting, it‚Äôs not enough, as they find themselves six points behind Porto, who are unbeaten. But it does show how resilient they have become under R√∫ben Amorim. When the world seems to shine like you‚Äôve had too much wine, that‚Äôs Amorim. After inheriting a shambles two years ago, this rookie manager, still only 37, has led Sporting to a league title, two league-cup triumphs and this, the second Champions League knockout tie in their history. He may prefer to draw a veil over the first: back in 2008-09 Sporting managed to lose 12-1 on aggregate to Bayern Munich, setting a record for the heaviest knockout defeat in the tournament that stands to this day. Another drubbing is all too possible here. According to Nate Silver‚Äôs prediction machine, City have a 70pc chance of a win tonight, making this the second most lop-sided tie of the round behind Chelsea-Lille. If that sounds like a recipe for complacency, four of City‚Äôs best players will bring an extra motivation: Ederson, R√∫ben Dias, Joao Cancelo and Bernardo Silva are all alumni of Benfica, Sporting‚Äôs deadly rivals.  Still, as Pep Guardiola pointed out in his press conference, Sporting were good enough at the group stage to edge out Borussia Dortmund. And, as he didn‚Äôt go on to say, they‚Äôve seen off City over two legs before ‚Äì in their only previous meeting, a Europa League quarter-final ten years ago. So you‚Äôd have to say the home side have a Sporting chance. That win, by the way, came on away goals, the funny old tie-breaker that has now been binned. No more of those Monaco nightmares for Pep no more of those intriguing calculations for the rest of us.  Kick-off is at 8pm GMT, and I‚Äôll be back soon after 7pm with the teams.

title: aoc interview democracy joe biden covid us politics latest updates
story: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre on the verge of some significant breakthroughs in healthcare,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut should it be based upon what you can afford to pay? If Congress acts we can take care of things with the stroke of a pen tomorrow.‚ÄùHer counterpart Ed Markey, the other Democratic senator from Massachusetts, voted against the confirmation.  ‚ÄúNot only has infrastructure week finally arrived, you can look forward to infrastructure decade,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúJust 92 days after I signed the law, it‚Äôs already making a tangible difference. We announced billions in funding allocations to put people to work in good-paying jobs, cleaning up rivers in Ohio, chemical plants in Florida and dozens of other sites, bolstering the energy grid with stronger transmission lines and towers and modernizing bridges.‚Äù  Biden continued: ‚ÄúThis is only the beginning: hundreds of billions in new investments are on their way. Now it‚Äôs time for the counties to get ready.‚Äù Senator Joe Manchin, a Virginia Democrat, urged senators to oppose Califf‚Äôs appointment earlier this week, saying he bears ‚Äúa great deal of responsibility‚Äù for many of the US opioid overdose deaths in the years since Califf‚Äôs first stint as FDA commissioner under the Obama administration.  The Associated Press reports that at that time, Califf ‚Äúadded new warning labels to opioids and commissioned outside recommendations on how to tighten regulation of the drugs. But he was replaced by President Donald Trump before implementing any major changes.‚Äù Califf has promised to launch a review of opioids as one of his first actions in his new role.The 50-46 vote means Dr Robert Califf, a cardiologist, will helm the agency, which regulates billion-dollar industries including prescription and over-the-counter drugs, as well as most foods on sale in the US.  Califf previously held the job for 11 months in the final years of Obama administration after securing overwhelming support in the senate - a contrast to Tuesday‚Äôs tight result. The FDA has played a key role in the US response to the Covid-19 pandemic, including reviewing and approving vaccines against a backdrop of deep political polarization over public health measures.Sarah Raskin is the wife of Jamie Raskin, a Democratic congressman from Maryland. Schumer has issued a unanimous consent request to file cloture on the correct bill, but as the name implies, it requires unanimous consent ‚Äì and Rick Scott, the Republican senator from Florida, is standing in the way because he doesn‚Äôt like the legislation.  It‚Äôs not the end of the world ‚Äì this just means that the bill will be delayed a few weeks ‚Äì but it‚Äôs frustrating development for postal reform advocates, nonetheless. This will be the first time a gunmaker is held responsible for a mass shooting in the US, and comes one day after the four-year anniversary of the mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas high school in Parkland, Florida, when Joe Biden called for such accountability to take place.  ‚ÄúCongress must do much more ‚Äì beginning with requiring background checks on all gun sales, banning assault weapons and high-capacity magazines, and eliminating immunity for gun manufacturers,‚Äù Biden said.  Details of the settlement are still unclear, but in July, Remington offered $33m, which was substantially less than what the victims‚Äô families were seeking. In a February court filing, their attorneys estimated the wrongful death claims likely totalled in excess of $225m, rising above $1bn with punitive damages.Punchbowl News is reporting that the senate is currently stuck on two unrelated government funding snafus. One of the two snafus stems from Marsha Blackburn, the Republican senator from Tennessee, who is holding out on a three-week stopgap funding bill because she believes that the Biden administration is trying to set aside money to hand out crack pipes. Though the White House has denied this, Blackburn is allegedly waiting on the Biden administration to formally respond to her concerns before she allows the bill to go through. The last tussle comes from several Republican senators, led by Mike Lee of Utah, who are demanding a vote on the amendment to ban the federal government from funding a vaccine mandate for federal workers, contractors and the military.  However, Punchbowl News noted that these last-minute disputes have become standard for the senate ahead of funding talks, and will likely be resolved - there likely won‚Äôt be a shutdown. ‚Äôs Dominic Rushe has more details here:  As it has been in recent weeks, much of the focus in Washington has been on Ukraine, and the imminent threat of a Russian invasion. Make sure to check out our live blog here for live updates as the situation unfolds.  Meanwhile, in the US, progressive congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez has been making waves as she campaigns for progressive candidates in Texas and talks about turning the once staunchly red state blue.  Today, her New Yorker interview raised more eyebrows when she said there was a ‚Äúvery real risk‚Äù that democracy would not exist in the US 10 years from now.  Read more about her comments here:

title: surge in demand for erasmus places among irish students is welcome news
story: Tens of thousands of students from Ireland have participated in the Erasmus study abroad programme since it was established 35 years ago. Photograph: iStockIt is the largest study abroad programme of its type in the world. In fact, it has been so successful that the term ‚ÄúErasmus‚Äù is now the internationally understood shorthand for those who study abroad no matter what the funding background.Since it was established 35 years ago, millions of students across Europe have left the comfort zone of their home institution to spend study or traineeship visits in another European country, among them tens of thousands of students from Ireland.For the first time in the history of the Erasmus programme, the Irish Government is to dip into the national purse to provide financial support for students seeking to study and work abroad. A surge in demand has left the Erasmus+ national agency at the Higher Education Authority (HEA) seriously short of funds.A co-fund of ‚Ç¨7 million is being made available by Minister for Further and Higher Education Simon Harris in two tranches ‚Äì ‚Ç¨3.5 million in 2022 and ‚Ç¨3.5 million in 2023 ‚Äì to help bridge the shortfall. The Government also anticipates that freeing up more places in Ireland will enable the sector to admit more fellow Europeans who would normally have gone to the United Kingdom.This welcome intervention has been made necessary by a massive 66 per cent increase in demand for places on the programme under the 2021-22 call. The HEA‚Äôs Erasmus+ national agency, which manages the higher education element of the programme received applications for more than 8,700 study and work abroad periods from the participating higher education institutions compared to 5,500 for the 2020-21 year.But a huge problem resulted when the European Commission was not in a position to provide the promised additional funding at the start of the latest iteration of the programme, which covers the period 2021-27.The national agency has had its budget for the 2021-22 academic year slashed by ‚Ç¨3 million (a 25 per cent cut) down to ‚Ç¨9 million compared to ‚Ç¨12 million for 2020-21. This dip will be recovered from 2023 when EU funds will rise appreciably.Without the Government funds, the agency would only be able to support about 3,200 student mobilities and 250 staff visits. Thanks to the additional ‚Ç¨3.5 million, another 1,500 iniduals can be assisted in 2022 and a similar number in 2023.The commitment does not extend beyond 2023. By then, the Government expects the extra funds from the European Commission will kick in. Applications always exceed actual realised mobilities with the highest outward-bound number to date being recorded in 2019 at 3,995. A realisation of 4,700 mobilities by summer 2022 will be a national record.The challenge is mainly felt by the eight Irish University Association universities plus Munster Technological University who account for some 87 per cent of total outbound numbers.Those with the largest growth are University of Limerick (+364), NUI Galway (+326), Trinity College Dublin (+264), University College Dublin (+261), Dublin City University (+170) and TU Dublin (+100).Driving the numbersComing off the back of a very travel unfriendly Covid landscape, the rise in demand is somewhat surprising. A significant feature driving the numbers is the fact that 1,500 mobilities are for students who must spend mandatory spells of one or two semesters of their degree programmes abroad.Other reasons posited are the greater flexibilities offered under the new programme, which, subject to certain conditions, permit study abroad periods of as short as five to 30 days compared to the traditional minimum two months studywork stays.Another very positive development has been the decision by the European Commission to provide mandatory supplementary social inclusion support of ‚Ç¨250 per month.The net result of this is that a Susi (Student Universal Support Ireland) student will be able to receive roughly ‚Ç¨550 for a study visit (up from ‚Ç¨480) and ‚Ç¨670 for a traineeshipwork placement (compared to ‚Ç¨500 per month, maximum). The Erasmus+ national agency voluntarily introduced top-up social inclusion support in 2014 and was heading for a 20 per cent participation rate from Susi recipients before the pandemic struck.The Covid-19 pandemic has badly disrupted the student ‚Äúexperience‚Äù over the last two years. Remote learning and close campuses took their toll. With savings from the pandemic unemployment payment in the bank, students may have a bit more disposable income in their pockets to recover some of that lost learning by embarking on a studywork period in another EUEEA country.

title: local and regional road funding for 2022 up 4 to nearly 600m
story: Flooding on Droichead Charraig a Log√°in which erodes the surface. Overall funding to repair roads countrywide will increase to ‚Ç¨597 million following the Government announcement of a 4 per cent increase in regional and local road funding for 2022 Minister for Transport Eamon Ryan said overall funding would be higher as the exchequer grants are intended to ‚Äúsupplement local authorities‚Äô own expenditure on regional and local road projects‚Äù. He said the grants do not represent the total investment in regional and local roads for this year.But additional cash to remedy problems on routes across the State has failed to resolve problems in many localities. And one such area is Ros Muc in the Connemara Gaeltacht.‚ÄúThe roads in the area have no cycle lanes, no walkways, not even a white line. There is a road in Ros Muc past the football field and passing P√°draig Pearse‚Äôs cottage which is only a cluster of potholes. We have the worst regional and local roads in Ireland,‚Äù said Co Galway resident M√°nus √ì Conaire of Iorras Aithneach. ‚ÄúA 4 per cent increase is not going to change that, unfortunately.‚Äù Mr √ì Conaire is a veteran campaigner for better roads in the Connemara region. He represents B√≥ithre Chonamara (Connemara Roads group) in discussions with Galway County Council engineers and believes inflation is likely to absorb the increase. ‚ÄúSenior management in the council have always told us they would like to do the work, but they don‚Äôt have the money,‚Äù he said.Agus sin √© an f√°th go bhfuil muid gl√≥rach faoina droichid. B√≠g√≠ c√∫ramach amuigh ansin inniu a chlann üåÅ‚òîüåÇ‚òÅÔ∏è https:t.covzeRTSSxNV‚Äî B√≥ithre ChonamaraConnemara Roads (@BoithreR) He noted four bridges in the area which, like many roads in Connemara, were not wide enough to qualify for designation of regional road status. ‚ÄúSome of those bridges have cracks in them,‚Äù he said. Mr √ì Conaire said he heard there is money in Co Galway‚Äôs allocation to restore several of the bridges, but queried the meaning of restore. B√≥ithre Chonamara‚Äôs social media is populated with videos and images of damaged roads and bridges as well as interviews with locals. Footage includes routes that have been spray painted to alert users to subsidence hazards and potholes. Road safetyThe funding will allow about 3,100km of roads to be maintained and 2,550km to be strengthened.Minister for State at the Department of Transport Hildegarde Naughton, a Galway West TD, said the grant represented ‚Äúa 28 percent increase in funding for local roads since 2019.‚Äù The Minister said the resource will help Galway city and county councils ensure improved connectivity, but will also enable them invest in road safety across the county. Ms Naughton referred specifically to the county‚Äôs allocation on Galway Bay FM: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôll be looking at investing in bridge rehabilitation across Galway, including at Leitir M√≥r, the Salmon Weir Bridge and the bridge on Millstreet.‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôll be looking to tackle roads affected by flooding, which is a safety concern. We‚Äôll be looking at places like the Dyke Road and Merchants Road.‚Äù The full allocation of funding by local authority is available hereStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: planning regulator knocks back dublin build to rent curbs
story: City planner John O‚ÄôHara last month said the policy changes were an attempt to return a ‚Äòersity‚Äô of housing types to Dublin City. Photograph: iStockThe planning regulator is to block attempts by Dublin City Council to introduce a number of tight controls on the development of build-to-rent (BTR) apartment blocks in the city.Deputy regulator Anne Marie O‚ÄôConnor has told the council not to go ahead with measures to stop developers from building blocks with no homes for sale, and to omit from the city development plan restrictions on numbers of studio and one-bed apartments included in a scheme.The draft development plan would require BTR schemes of more than 100 homes to have at least 40 per cent of properties available for sale. BTR schemes of fewer than 100 homes would generally not be permitted, as they would not have a ‚Äúcritical mass‚Äù to support good communal facilities.The plan also restricts studio and one-bed apartments to a maximum of 30 per cent of a development, a provision which would apply in particular to areas such as north inner city and Liberties, which already have a high proportion of smaller apartments.City planner John O‚ÄôHara last month said the policy changes were an attempt to return a ‚Äúersity‚Äù of housing types to the city. ‚ÄúBuild-to-rent has only emerged in the last three years, but it has largely displaced build-to sell altogether,‚Äù he said.Ms O‚ÄôConnor said while it appeared the policies were ‚Äúa response to the City Council‚Äôs observed trend of nearly all recent planning applications for apartment development being BTR schemes,‚Äù they were in breach of national policies and ministerial guidelines.Specifying 40 per cent of apartments had to be available for sale would mean those units would have to comply with higher standards than build to rent schemes. Similarly, she said there was ‚Äúno national or regional policy basis, or any other evidence provided, to support the view that a scheme of less than 100 units cannot provide meaningful communal facilities and services‚Äù.In relation to the curbs on the numbers of smaller apartments she said this would also conflict with Ministerial guidelines on BTR schemes which stated there should be ‚Äúno restrictions on dwelling mix‚Äù.She told the council it was required to omit or amend the policies which were inconsistent with the ministerial guidelines. However she said the regulator ‚Äúunderstands and acknowledges the context for the proposal of these policies by the planning authority in terms of failing to secure a reasonable mix of housing in an area or the potential of an undue concentration of BTR developments that may be presenting in particular parts of its area‚Äù.The council‚Äôs proposed policy that applications for BTR would be accompanied by an assessment of other permitted BTR developments within 3km to demonstrate there would not be an over-concentration of one housing tenure was ‚Äúa reasonable requirement‚Äù she said and provided a ‚Äústrong policy basis that would empower the City Council‚Äù to address the over-concentration issue.Overall she said the regulator ‚Äúendorses the majority of the housing policies‚Äù in the city plan.Stay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: moscow ready to engage in talks with the us and nato over missile deployments putin
story: Some troops in Russia's military districts adjacent to Ukraine are returning to their bases after completing drills, Russia's defence ministry has said. Video: ReutersRussian Defence MinistryRussian tank leaving for Russia after joint exercises of the armed forces of Russia and Belarus. Photograph: Russian Defence Ministry  AFPRussian president Vladimir Putin is seen ahead of a meeting with German Chancellor over Ukraine security at the Kremlin, in Moscow, on February 15, 2022. - The Kremlin earlier confirmed a pullback of some Russian forces from Ukraine's borders but said the move was planned and stressed Russia would continue to move troops across the country as it saw fit. (Photo by Mikhail Klimentyev  Sputnik  AFP) (Photo by MIKHAIL KLIMENTYEVSputnikAFP via Getty Images)Russian President Vladimir Putin has said Moscow is ready for talks with the US and Nato on limits for missile deployments and military transparency.Speaking after talks with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, Mr Putin said the US and Nato had rejected his demand to keep Ukraine and other ex-Soviet nations out of Nato, halt weapons deployments near Russian borders and roll back alliance forces from eastern Europe. They agreed to discuss a range of security measures that Russia had previously proposed.Mr Putin said Moscow is ready to engage in talks on limits on the deployment of intermediate range missiles in Europe, transparency of drills and other confidence-building measures, but emphasised the need for the West to heed Russia‚Äôs main demands.The statement came after the Russian Defence Ministry announced a partial pullback of troops following military drills, adding to hopes that the Kremlin may not be planning to invade Ukraine imminently.The Russian military gave no details on where the troops were pulling back from, or how many.Russia has denied any plans to invade Ukraine. Earlier Russia‚Äôs defence ministry was quoted as saying that some troops in Russia‚Äôs military districts adjacent to Ukraine are returning to their bases after completing drills. Russia‚Äôs Interfax news agency cited the ministry as saying that while large-scale drills across the country continued, some units of the southern and western military districts have completed their exercises and started returning to base.EncircledRussia has amassed over 100,000 troops near Ukraine‚Äôs borders, prompting fears of an invasion, especially as Moscow‚Äôs February 10th-20th joint drills with Belarus mean that Ukraine is almost encircled by the Russian military.Although Moscow has denied ever planning to attack Ukraine, it has demanded legally binding guarantees from the United States and Nato that Kyiv will not be allowed to join the military bloc. Washington and Brussels have so far refused to make such pledges.Nato‚Äôs chief on Tuesday welcomed signals that Russia may be looking for a diplomatic solution amid a military build-up on Ukraine‚Äôs border but urged Moscow to demonstrate its will to act.‚ÄúThere are signs from Moscow that diplomacy should continue. This gives grounds for cautious optimism. But so far we have not seen any sign of de-escalation on the ground from the Russian side‚Äù, Nato secretary-general Jens Stoltenberg told reporters ahead of a two-day meeting of the alliance‚Äôs defence ministers in Brussels.‚ÄúRussia has amassed a fighting force in and around Ukraine unprecedented since the cold war. Everything is now in place for a new attack. But Russia still has time to step back from the brink, stop preparing for war and start working for a peaceful solution‚Äù, Mr Stoltenberg said, calling the current situation the ‚Äúmost serious security crisis we have faced in Europe for decades‚Äù.France has not yet verified whether Russia is pulling back some troops from Ukraine‚Äôs border but if the information is correct, this would be a ‚Äúpositive sign‚Äù, France‚Äôs government spokesman Gabriel Attal told journalists on Tuesday.German chancellor Olaf Scholz arrived in Moscow on Tuesday to meet Russian president Vladimir Putin in a high stakes mission to avert war.It comes as Ukraine president Volodymyr Zelenskiy on Monday called on the country‚Äôs people to fly flags and sing the national anthem in unison on February 16th, a date that some Western media say Russian could invade.Ukrainian government officials stressed that Zelenskiy was not predicting an attack on Wednesday, but responding skeptically to the foreign media reports.‚ÄúThey tell us February 16th will be the day of the attack. We will make it a day of unity,‚Äù Mr Zelenskiy said in a video address to the nation.‚ÄúThey are trying to frighten us by yet again naming a date for the start of military action,‚Äù Mr Zelenskiy said. ‚ÄúOn that day, we will hang our national flags, wear yellow and blue banners, and show the whole world our unity.‚ÄùMr Zelenskiy has long said that, while he believes Russia is threatening to attack his country, the likelihood of an imminent invasion has been overstated by Western allies, responding to Moscow‚Äôs efforts to intimidate Ukraine and sow panic.Mykhailo Podolyak, an adviser to Mr Zelenskiy‚Äôs chief of staff, told Reuters the president was responding in part ‚Äúwith irony‚Äù to media reports of the potential date of the invasion.Russian parliamentRussia‚Äôs lower house of parliament voted on Tuesday to ask President Vladimir Putin to recognise two Russian-backed breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine as independent, the house speaker said.The move by the State Duma, if approved, could further inflame a wider standoff over a Russian military build-up near Ukraine that has fuelled Western fears that Moscow could attack. Russia denies any invasion plans and has accused the West of hysteria.Recognition of the self-declared Donetsk and Luhansk People‚Äôs Republics could kill off the Minsk peace process in east Ukraine, where a conflict between government forces and Moscow-backed separatists has killed 15,000 people.‚ÄúKyiv is not observing the Minsk agreements. Our citizens and compatriots who live in Donbass need our help and support,‚Äù Vyacheslav Volodin, the State Duma speaker, wrote on social media.Mr Volodin, a member of the pro-Putin ruling United Russia party, said the appeal would be sent to the Kremlin immediately. It was not clear how long the Kremlin would take to review it.Moscow casts the conflict in east Ukraine as a civil war, but Ukraine and the West say Russia helps the separatists with its own ground forces, something Moscow denies.Russia has issued more than 700,000 passports to residents of eastern Ukraine since separatists seized territory there in 2014 shortly after Russia annexed Crimea, souring relations with Kyiv and the West.Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov declined to comment on the substance of the appeal, saying that no decision had been taken on it. But he added that the pro-Russian separatist region known as Donbass was a matter of great concern for Russians.He said that Russia had repeatedly demonstrated its commitment to the Minsk peace process and that it still wanted it to be implemented.Four-way east Ukraine peace talks between Ukraine, Russia, France and Germany were held last week but ended without a breakthrough.After the talks, Ukraine said it would not yield to pressure from Moscow to negotiate directly with the separatists, while Russia accused Kyiv of putting forward absurd proposals. ‚Äì Additional reporting ReutersStay on top of the latest news with our daily newsletters each morning, lunchtime and evening

title: sweden right covid along
story: To understand Sweden, you need to understand a word that‚Äôs hard to explain, let alone translate: lagom. It means, in effect, ‚Äúperfect-simple‚Äù: not too much, not too little. People who are lagom don‚Äôt stand out or make a fuss: they blend right in ‚Äì and this is seen as a virtue.¬†Essays are written about why lagom sums up a certain Swedish mindset ‚Äì that it‚Äôs bad to stand out, to consider yourself better or be an outlier. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs so strange that, during the lockdowns, Sweden became the world‚Äôs defiant outlier.Swedes saw it the other way around. They were keeping calm and carrying on: lockdown was an extreme, draconian, untested experiment. Lock up everyone, keep children out of school, suspend civil liberties, send police after people walking their dogs ‚Äì and call this ‚Äúcaution‚Äù? Anders Tegnell, Sweden‚Äôs state epidemiologist, never spoke about a Swedish ‚Äúexperiment‚Äù. He said all along he could not recommend a public health intervention that had never been proven.Tegnell also made another point: that he didn‚Äôt claim to be right. It would take years, he‚Äôd argue, to see who had jumped the right way. His calculation was that, on a whole-society basis, the collateral damage of lockdowns would outweigh what good they do. But you‚Äôd only know if this was so after a few years. You‚Äôd have to look at cancer diagnosis, hospital waiting lists, educational damage and, yes, count the Covid dead. Almost two years on, we can look at the early indications.The problem with lockdowns is that no one looks at whole-society pictures. Professor Neil Ferguson‚Äôs team from Imperial College London admitted this, once, as a breezy aside. ‚ÄúWe do not consider the wider social and economic costs of suppression,‚Äù they wrote in a supposed assessment of lockdown, ‚Äúwhich will be high.‚Äù But just how high? And were they a price worth paying?As Sweden abolishes all domestic Covid restrictions, it emerges with one of Europe‚Äôs lower Covid death tolls: the rate is 1,614 per million people, just over half the amount of Britain (2,335). Given that our death tolls were comparable at first (both among the worst anywhere), it‚Äôs hard to argue that there‚Äôs some demographic force which meant Covid was never going to spread in Sweden.¬†Nor is it possible to argue that Sweden was some hedonistic party-nation: its people were incredibly cautious. But unlike Brits, they had a government that trusted them.There were some Swedish diktats: a ‚Äúrule of eight‚Äù was set up for a while. Bars, restaurants and cafes were all socially distanced and, at one point, had to close by 8.30pm. For a few weeks, Swedes even had vaccine passports. But that was about it: the rest was guidance, and it was followed.What no statistic can convey is just how careful Swedes were something that struck me whenever I‚Äôd visit. It was perfectly legal to meet up in bars and for a fika in a coffee shop, but most didn‚Äôt. A friend of mine had a rule that she‚Äôd only ever meet friends outside ‚Äì even in the Stockholm winter (she did this so much that she got frostbite). In summer last year, studies showed Swedes working from home more than in any other European country.This kept Covid low, while the lack of rules allowed for people to use their judgement while minimising economic and social damage. Sweden‚Äôs GDP fell by 2.9 per cent in 2020, while Britain‚Äôs collapsed by 9.4 per cent. Both have bounded back, but Sweden‚Äôs economy is this year expected to be five per cent larger than before the pandemic, versus two per cent for Germany. The UK will be about one per cent, one of the lowest figures in Europe.¬†The cost of the various Covid measures is best summed up by the debt mountain: an extra ¬£8,400 per head in Britain, and ¬£3,000 in Sweden.Swedish schools kept going throughout, with no face masks. Sixth-formers and undergraduates switched to home learning, but the rest of Swedish children went to school as normal. That‚Äôs not to say there weren‚Äôt absences as the virus spread: it was common to see a third, at times even half of the class absent due to sniffles or suspected Covid. But there were no full-scale closures and, aside from some suspicions about minor grade inflation (the average maths grade sneaked up to 10.1, from 9.3), there is no talk in Sweden about educational devastation.In Britain, there is calamity and cover-up. By doling out more A grades than ever before ‚Äì and telling universities to make more space ‚Äì young people could be shovelled through the system with lost ground never recognised or quite made up.Grade inflation was staggering: the number of A-level students marked at A or A* jumped to 45 per cent, up from 26 per cent pre-pandemic, but no one doubts that these students learned far less. By some measures, educational inequality has been set back 10 years. But some problems are too big to admit.Academics suggest the effect of lost education is permanent: less education inevitably means lower salaries and slower career progression. The Institute for Fiscal Studies talks about ¬£40,000 of lost lifetime earnings per pupil in Britain, ¬£350‚Äâbillion in all. Swedish studies estimate that Covid‚Äôs impact (on absenteeism and home-learning) could mean an ¬£800‚Äâmillion overall hit ‚Äì far smaller than the impact on Britain‚Äôs lost school days.The impact on hospital waiting lists is also very different. Fear of a virus keeps people away ‚Äì at the peak of the first wave, attendance at Swedish A&ampE was 31 per cent lower than normal in Britain, it collapsed by 57 per cent. Routine operations were down by 20 per cent in Sweden and 34 per cent in England, so waiting lists grew in both countries. As they did pretty much world over.But no country, anywhere, has had a waiting list grow as big as Britain‚Äôs: from 4.4 million pre-pandemic, it will keep getting worse for two years and peak at about 9.2 million, according to NHS modelling ‚Äì that‚Äôs equivalent to one in five adults.¬†A top-down health service is more easily disrupted if it‚Äôs ordered to transform into a Covid service (and people are told to ‚Äúprotect the NHS‚Äù by not using it). Sweden‚Äôs waiting lists, 130,000 pre-pandemic, hit 170,000 last October. Even adjusting for population, it‚Äôs nowhere near the size of Britain‚Äôs problem.Sweden will not declare victory. No one was properly prepared for Covid, and The country‚Äôs failure to protect care home residents is still seen as a national scandal. Sweden also took a bigger hit than its neighbours: Denmark, which did lock down, has more to shout about when it comes to combining a lower Covid hit with minimal economic disruption.¬†But, as Tegnell would say, it‚Äôs still too early to say ‚Äì with any finality ‚Äì who got it right and who didn‚Äôt.More from NewsBanning gendered terms such as Sir and Miss ‚Äòcompletely unnecessary‚Äô says Department for EducationRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: bbcs absurd attempt prove belongs us exposes vanity
story: Somebody in the BBC hierarchy must have thought this was a great idea. And quite a lot of people inside the organisation must have agreed ‚Äì given the innumerable committee meetings that it would have passed through to gain approval.Having seen the overwhelming triumph of the campaign to protect the NHS by presenting it as a national institution that belongs to all of us, the Corporation has now launched an embarrassingly desperate public relations onslaught with precisely the same theme.It is, believe it or not, ‚Äúyour BBC‚Äù ‚Äì even when it righteously screens out what it regards as your unacceptable views, or imposes its particular version of social virtue on the nation, or refuses to apologise for what you may see as an offensive anti-Semitic slur.The clumsily worded slogan ‚Äì ‚ÄúThe BBC is something that belongs to all of us‚Äù (something? what exactly?) ‚Äì is apparently to become a ubiquitous refrain in its endless self-promotion, but if you want the full length version, you can view a video on iPlayer entitled This is our BBC.This opus is obviously designed to be hilarious, proffering the subtext ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt really take ourselves too seriously‚Äù when, in fact, what it reveals is that the BBC sees itself as a sacrosanct mainstay of British identity.Whatever you may have been tempted to conclude, it insists, we are not an out-of-touch, self-regarding purveyor of our own particular worldview which regards much public opinion as beneath contempt.Listen to what we are saying now about how we view ourselves and, above all, be aware that we cannot carry out this mission without your participation.That somebody ‚Äì indeed, lots of people ‚Äì within the organisation felt that this absurd exercise was appropriate tells you something about the state of mind at Broadcasting House.The Corporation has reacted to the threat to its future and its antiquated funding model in precisely the wrong way. Instead of listening with a semblance of respect to the criticisms made of its attitude and judgment, it has become more arrogant and aggressive.In its news and current affairs programming, it has become more insular and enclosed. What passes for discussion on the news consists of a BBC presenter interviewing a BBC correspondent who repeats a pre-scripted version of what the presenter has just provided.Instead of opening itself up to genuine arguments or to alternative opinions that are enlivening public discourse in the real world, it shuts down any possibility of disagreement. The result is predictable, anodyne and anti-democratic.In much of what should be apolitical programming ‚Äì entertainment and lifestyle genres ‚Äì it inserts themes and directives which clearly have a political intent and treats any public resistance to this as a form of heresy.Who do they think they are fooling? The BBC isn‚Äôt yours ‚Äì it‚Äôs theirs.More from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: exploits dunkirk hero told nation family share cigarette case
story: An RAF hero of Dunkirk cheated death when his cigarette case stopped a bullet aimed at his chest, his granddaughter has revealed after appearing on Antiques Roadshow.Flight Lieutenant William Gregory went on to fight in the Battle of Britain and on D-Day, serving as a gunner and wireless operator onboard Bristol Blenheim bombers and Mosquito night fighters.His granddaughter, who wished to remain anonymous, took Gregory‚Äôs medals, cigarette case, logbooks and other prized possessions onto the BBC programme.She was shocked to learn that the medals, consisting of the Distinguished Service Order, Distinguished Flying Cross and Bar, and Distinguished Flying Medal, as well as a 1939-45 Star with a Battle of Britain clasp, were valued at ¬£100,000.Speaking on the show, filmed at Portchester Castle near Portsmouth, Hants, she said: ‚ÄúHe was my grandfather Billy and my mother recently passed away. They were her most prized possessions.‚ÄúHe was a lovely man who was proud that he joined up with the war effort. He was brilliant.‚ÄùGregory was born in 1913 in Hartlepool, County Durham, and worked as a plasterer before joining the RAF Volunteer Reserve in 1938.He had a number of brushes with death, including over Dunkirk in May 1940, when a Luftwaffe bullet entered the aircraft only to be stopped by his luckily placed cigarette case.Later, he was shot down over Liverpool by friendly fire while intercepting a bombing raid. He bailed out at 16,000ft, landing on the roof of Lime Street Station, where passengers ‚Äúroughed him up‚Äù having mistaken him for a German.In May 1944, he had to ditch his Mosquito 70 miles off the Norfolk coast after being hit by a German Messerschmitt Bf 109.Despite those many close calls, Gregory survived the war and only retired from the RAF in 1964. He died aged 87 in 2001.He flew more than 100 operational sorties and shot down 23 German aircraft during the war.Speaking of the medals, antique expert Mark Smith said: ‚ÄúThey are some of the highest gallantry awards the country can give you and he has so many. They are spectacular.‚ÄúHe was one of the people who saved the country in 1940 without any shadow of a doubt, and this group is worth ¬£100,000.‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter about their value, it‚Äôs about what it means to the country.‚ÄùIt‚Äôs unknown if the family plans to sell them.More from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: lockdown debate skewed sceptical scientists shunned social media
story: Anti-lockdown scientists were viewed as having ‚Äòfringe‚Äô ideas because those calling for draconian restrictions had more followers on social media, a study has shown.Professor John Ioannidis, of Stanford University, an expert in data science and the reliability of research, studied the expertise of authors who signed the Great Barrington Declaration (GBD) compared with signatories of the John Snow Memorandum.The GBD called for vulnerable people to be shielded while allowing immunity to build up in the rest of the public to avoid huge costs to society, education and public health.In contrast, the John Snow Memorandum (JSM) argued that such a policy of herd immunity was unethical.Prof Ioannidis said he wanted to examine the prevailing narrative that the Great Barrington Declaration was a minority view among experts, and found that Twitter firepower had helped shape the conversation.In an article published in BMJ Open Research, he found that both letters were authored by very influential experts, but that the John Snow Memorandum authors had a far greater reach on social media, which made it appear that their view had more support.By November 2021, just four key signatories of the GBD had more than 50,000 Twitter followers, compared with 13 of the key authors of the JSM.Prof Ioannidis concluded: ‚ÄúBoth the Great Barrington Declaration and John Snow Memorandum include many stellar scientists, but JSM has far more powerful social media presence and this may have shaped the impression that it is the dominant narrative.‚ÄúGBD is clearly not a fringe minority report compared with JSM, as many social media and media allude.‚ÄúIf knowledgeable scientists can have a strong social media presence, massively communicating accurate information to followers, the effect may be highly beneficial.‚ÄúConversely, if scientists themselves are affected by the same problems (misinformation, animosity, loss of decorum and disinhibition, among others) when they communicate in social media, the consequences may be negative.‚ÄùProf Ioannidis also said signatories of the JSM had contributed to the vilification of authors of the GBD through their tweets and op-eds.Angus Dalgleish, professor of oncology at St George's, University of London, who was one of the GBD signatories, said: ‚ÄúI am not at all surprised at this.‚ÄúOf course it is a problem that should not be. I personally have actively avoided using social media and Twitter accounts, initially because of data leaks but then due to this being no way to conduct science, nor influence policy.‚ÄùMore from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersVirgin Galactic sells spaceflights at ¬£330,000 for 90-minute tripMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: mi5 admits missed intelligence manchester arena bomber overstretched
story: MI5 was ‚Äúoverstretched‚Äù when it missed red flags on the Manchester Arena bomber in the months leading up to the attack, an inquiry has heard.¬†Salman Abedi killed 22 people when he detonated a homemade device in the arena foyer following an Ariana Grande concert in May 2017.¬†One month earlier, MI5‚Äôs north west investigative team went into ‚Äúamber‚Äù on its workload dashboard, meaning ‚Äúit was in a period of stress and high capacity‚Äù, a public inquiry into the attack heard on Tuesday.¬†The increased workload, which had been a growing problem since the declaration of the caliphate in 2014, prompted MI5 agents in the north west to suspend some casework in April and May 2017 and request assistance from another regional team.¬†One MI5 operative had warned his bosses he was worried ‚Äúsomething could potentially get through‚Äù due to the amount of intelligence they had to assess.By May 15 ‚Äì exactly one week before the bombing ‚Äì much of the unit‚Äôs work had been taken up by another regional station, the inquiry was told.¬†Witness J, a senior figure in MI5, agreed that that investigative team was ‚Äúoverstretched‚Äù but that the agency ‚Äúwas under pressure across the board‚Äù.¬†Families of those who died in the attack said they were ‚Äúdeeply shocked and appalled‚Äù at the revelation that MI5 was ‚Äústruggling to cope‚Äù.¬†‚ÄúAll of this is profoundly concerning,‚Äù said Kim Harrison, a lawyer representing some of the families. ‚ÄúAnti-terrorism work should never be under-resourced. If further resources are needed to keep our country safe, it is essential that they are provided as a matter of urgency.‚ÄùThe new details on the security service‚Äôs stretched resources formed part of previously secret evidence that was heard behind closed doors last year on the grounds of national security. On Tuesday, a gist of the secret evidence was made public.The inquiry has previously heard how MI5 was passed two pieces of intelligence in the months leading up to the bombing that were initially assessed as being ‚Äúnon-nefarious‚Äù, but later transpired to be ‚Äúhighly relevant‚Äù to the planned attack.This gist revealed that one of the MI5 agents responsible for assessing the intelligence admitted that it could have been understood at the time to ‚Äúindicate activity of pressing national security concern‚Äù.The inquiry also heard that Abedi had talked about killing people ‚Äúin a public space‚Äù for years but nobody took it seriously.¬†A prison officer, known only as PO1 for legal reasons, told the inquiry that he spoke with Abedi‚Äôs friend and convicted terrorist Abdalraouf Abdallah ‚Äì known as Abs ‚Äì in December last year in his cell.¬†During the five-minute conversation, PO1 sat on Abdallah‚Äôs bed as he told him that the terror atrocity was done by ‚Äúone of his boys‚Äù and that Abedi had talked to friends and family for years about harming others but everyone thought ‚Äúhe would never go through with it‚Äù.In a police statement made after the conversation, PO1 said: ‚ÄúAbs said for years the lad had said about killing people in a public space but all this lad‚Äôs friends and family had shrugged it off as just bravado, it had been said that often.‚ÄùAbdallah was jailed in 2016 for helping four men from Manchester travel to Syria where three of them fought for the so-called Islamic State.Abedi twice visited him in jail, the second time just months before the arena bombing, and the pair used a smuggled mobile phone to exchange thousands of messages, including discussing ‚Äúmartyrdom‚Äù.Abdallah, a paraplegic who was injured fighting against Gaddafi forces in the 2011 Libya uprising, has denied any involvement or knowledge of the arena attack.The public inquiry has now adjourned until a later date after the final day of evidence on Tuesday.More from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between title: revealed hrt may prevent dying covid
story: Hormone replacement therapy may protect older women from dying of Covid, a study suggests.Swedish and Finnish researchers at the University of Umea and the U1niversity of Helsinki, studied the records of 14,685 women aged between 50 and 80 who contracted coronavirus between February and September 2020.They found that women taking HRT were 54 per cent less likely to have died from their infection than those who were not using oestrogen supplementation.They also discovered that breast cancer sufferers who were taking drugs to help control their disease by suppressing oestrogen had more than double the risk of death.Around one in 10 women (10.1 per cent) on oestrogen suppressing drugs died during the study period compared with about one in 50 (2.1 per cent) of women on HRT and one in 20 (4.6 per cent) for the control group.The link with oestrogen may also explain why fewer women have died during the pandemic than men, the researchers said, suggesting the hormone has a protective effect.In a paper published in BMJ open, the authors conclude: ‚ÄúThis study shows an association between oestrogen levels and Covid-19 death.‚ÄúConsequently, drugs increasing oestrogen levels may have a role in therapeutic efforts to alleviate Covid-19 severity in postmenopausal women and could be studied in randomised control trials.‚ÄùEven after accounting for potentially influential factors, such as age, annual disposable income, educational attainment and existing health conditions, the odds of dying from Covid-19 remained significantly lower (53 per cent) for women on HRT.However, British experts urged women to be cautious before turning to HRT to protect them from Covid-19.Stephen Evans, professor of pharmacoepidemiology at the London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine, said: ‚ÄúThe findings are apparently dramatic. However, it must be remembered that there is a long history of observational studies, especially in relation to hormone therapy, making dramatic claims of benefits that have not been confirmed in randomised trials.‚ÄúThere are short-term benefits of hormone therapy but women should not, based on this or other observational studies, be advised to take hormone therapy for a supposed benefit on death from Covid-19.‚ÄùResearchers also found that age was significantly associated with the risk of dying from the virus, with each extra year associated with 15 per cent greater odds, while every additional coexisting condition increased the odds of death by 13 per cent.Those with the lowest household incomes were nearly three times as likely to die as those with the highest.More from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: russian withdrawal may sign vladimir putin thinks has already
story: Vladimir Putin wrongfooted the world again on Tuesday with the surprise announcement Russia is withdrawing some of its troops from around Ukraine.The question facing the West now is whether the move is a sign the crisis is abating ‚Äî or just another tactical manouvre on the part of the Kremlin.On the face of it, the announcement appears to fit the view that the presence of the troops has always been a bluff on Mr Putin‚Äôs part.‚ÄúFebruary 15, 2022, will go down in history as the day when Western war propaganda failed,‚Äù a Russian foreign ministry spokeswoman crowed on Tuesday. ‚ÄúThey were humiliated and defeated without a single shot.‚ÄùThe taunt was directed at US predictions Russia would invade on Wednesday, but it may have contained a deeper message.Mr Putin has every reason to believe he has secured a major strategic victory without going to war.He has reasserted Russia as a superpower, brought Western leaders scurrying to meet with him in Moscow and left the whole world hanging on his next move.He appeared to give the game away with Monday's weird staged meeting for the television cameras, in which his foreign minister, Sergei Lavrov, reported back that the chances of a diplomatic solution were ‚Äúfar from exhausted‚Äù and Russia should keep going.Indeed, Mr Putin has been transparent about this tactic for months. In November he told Russian diplomats ‚Äútensions‚Äù with the West were a good thing and that it was ‚Äúimportant for them to remain in this state for as long as possible.‚ÄùBut the question is: why stop now? Perhaps, like an experienced gambler, Mr Putin just wants to quite while he is ahead. But the timing seems odd.Only a day ago he seemed on the verge of an even bigger win, after the Ukrainian ambassador to Britain suggested his country could be ready to abandon its ambitions of Nato membership to avoid war, only for Kyiv to slap him down.That was Mr Putin‚Äôs central demand, yet now he appears to be backing down just when it is within reach.One possibility is that negotiations are taking place than we don't know about. Ukraine‚Äôs ambassador to Germany made an intriguing comment on Tuesday when he called for Olaf Scholz to ‚Äúbang with his first, but maybe also with his shoe if necessary‚Äù on Mr Putin‚Äôs table during his visit to Moscow.It was an odd remark that seemed designed to call to mind Nikita Kruschchev, who famously banged his shoe on a desk at the United Nations, and who was Soviet leader during the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis, the moment the US and the Soviets came closest to war.The Cuban Missile Crisis was resolved with a secret deal agreed via back channel negotiations led by Robert F Kennedy.It is possible there are talks being conducted through similar back channels of which we know nothing today.It is worth noting that Boris Johnson and Joe Biden said there was still hope for a diplomatic solution on Monday night, just ahead of Russia‚Äôs announcement it was pulling troops back.But it is important to be cautious about reading too much into Russia‚Äôs announcement.‚ÄúAll warfare is based on deception,‚Äù Sun Tzu wrote in The Art of War. ‚ÄúWhen using our forces, we must appear inactive when we are near, we must make the enemy believe we are far away when far away, we must make him believe we are near.‚ÄùFar from being a sign that the crisis is over, a Russian withdrawal could be a classic feint. Mr Putin could be laying the ground to claim he was pulling his forces out when he was forced into action against his will.It is a little too soon to declare the crisis over yet.Sign-up to our Russia-Ukraine crisis webinar and chat to  journalists on Wednesday February 16 at middayMore from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: scientists solve 5000 year old cold case testing stone age skeleton
story: British scientists have cracked a 5,000-year-old cold case by testing for algae in the bone marrow of a Stone Age skeleton.Experts from the University of Southampton applied the technique to the man who was found in a mass grave on the Chilean coast, but whose cause of death remained a mystery.They hope that the technique can be used on historic coastal mass graves across the world.¬†Prof James Goff of the University of Southampton, who led the study, said: ‚ÄúMass burials have often been necessary after natural disasters such as tsunamis, floods or large storms.‚ÄúHowever, we know very little about whether prehistoric mass burial sites near coastlines could be the result of natural disasters or other causes such as war, famine and disease.‚ÄúThis gave us our light bulb moment of developing an enhanced version of a modern forensic test to use on ancient bones.‚ÄùThe Chilean man, it turned out, was not the victim of a natural disaster or major catastrophe.¬†Test results found a variety of marine particles which suggested he drowned in saltwater, which included fossilised algae, parasite eggs and sediment.Others in the mass grave, meanwhile, did not have the same markers, suggesting that they did not drown and that this was an isolated incident.Further evidence, including the condition of the inidual‚Äôs bones which showed signs of frequent harpooning, rowing and harvesting of shellfish, and his age of between 35 and 45, suggested that he was a fisherman.He was also likely to have drowned in shallow water, said Prof Goff.‚ÄúWe could see that the poor man swallowed sediment in his final moments and sediment does not tend to float around in sufficient concentrations in deeper waters.‚ÄùModern forensics can confirm drowning as the cause of death in recent victims by testing for diatoms - a group of algae found in oceans, freshwater and soils - inside the bones of the victims.If diatoms are discovered in the bones of victims‚Äô bodies, it is likely that they drowned because, had they died before entering the water, they would not have swallowed any.The test had, until now, never been successfully used to conclude drowning in prehistoric human remains.More from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: vaccination strategy leaving british families grounded
story: After mostly staying in Britain for holidays during the pandemic, including a chilly spell in Cornwall last year, Hannah Hope had thought this February half-term might have been her family‚Äôs chance to jet off. And so it could have been ‚Äì were it not for the complicated patchwork of travel rules governing entry to foreign destinations, many of which now require children to be jabbed.¬†If you live abroad, this is perhaps not a problem. The European Medicines Agency approved the Pfizer vaccine for 12 to 15-year-olds last May, and for children aged five to 11 in November. The US Food and Drug Administration also authorised the Pfizer jab for 12 to 15-year-olds in May, and for five to 11-year-olds in October.But in Britain, where the vaccine rollout for 12 to 15-year-olds started in late September, almost half of that age group are yet to receive their first jab. And children aged five to 11 are still awaiting a rule change that would enable them to be vaccinated ‚Äì despite countries such as Germany, Spain, Denmark and Greece making vaccines available to this age group at the end of last year. Here in the UK, messaging around children and vaccines has been branded ‚Äúabysmal‚Äù, while parents have been left confused and frustrated.As a result of these delays, longed-for foreign holidays have been scuppered for many British families, and Hope is among those who have struggled to book a getaway abroad.¬†It was November when the vaccine was given to pupils at her children‚Äôs secondary school. But her 13-year-old son had tested positive for Covid in October. This meant he was unable to have his first jab until January, and won‚Äôt be eligible for his second until mid-April. His 15-year-old brother, having received his first jab in December, then caught Covid a few weeks later, so must wait until May for his second one.¬†‚ÄúWe were looking to go away for a few days in Europe, but currently nowhere will let us in, apart from possibly Portugal or Denmark,‚Äù says Hope, 46, a nutritionist from St Albans. ‚ÄúEven a trip to Spain is out as they want a PCR test and, due to recent infection, we won‚Äôt have a clear PCR in time.‚ÄùSo instead, they are off to the Peak District this week. ‚ÄúI just wanted to get a few days away, but it‚Äôs very difficult to know where we can go. This half-term was a write-off because I didn‚Äôt know what we could do.‚ÄùThis is a problem for many parents in a similar position. Although Spain has just dropped its requirement for teenagers to be fully jabbed, this came too late for the many families who had already had to cancel half-term trips. In the current chaotic situation, it may seem safer to wait until the last minute to see what the latest rules are before booking an overseas holiday. But soaring prices make that prohibitive.¬†Yet booking ahead can feel risky ‚Äì not least for parents of children under 12 who don‚Äôt yet know if, or how quickly, their children might be jabbed, and whether it will be required for entry to certain countries later this year. It is already the case that to enter Israel, children aged one and over must be either fully vaccinated or recovered from Covid.‚ÄúI‚Äôm hoping to go to Israel in May for my brother‚Äôs wedding, but at the moment we can‚Äôt get my nine-year-old daughter there,‚Äù says Debbie Marks, who is among those affected by the UK‚Äôs ergence from other countries when it comes to vaccinating children.So why has Britain ‚Äì which had a head start in jabbing adults ‚Äì been lagging behind with its rollout of the vaccine to under-16s? In early September, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation (JCVI) said it was not recommending the vaccination of healthy 12 to 15-year-olds, amid fears of a rare side effect of heart inflammation. They wanted more information before giving the green light to jabs for teenagers.¬†The rollout to secondary school pupils did start later that month, but has made sluggish progress. In part, this slow uptake has been blamed on logistical difficulties but also, according to Professor Christina Pagel, the director of University College London‚Äôs clinical operational research unit, on a lack of clear messaging from bodies including the JCVI, the Cabinet and the chief medical officers.Now, following months of uncertainty, new advice on vaccinating five to 11-year-olds is expected imminently, suggesting parents should be given the option of having their young children vaccinated, on the grounds this could prevent a small number of hospital admissions. But the Government‚Äôs scientific advisers are understood to have agreed the jabs should be made available on a ‚Äúnon-urgent‚Äù basis. This follows a protracted period of wrangling, with the JCVI having been ided over whether the benefits are great enough to justify the rollout to healthy primary-aged pupils.¬†‚ÄúIt is a mystery to me why the UK has been so slow to offer a vaccine for children aged five to 11,‚Äù says Dr Simon Williams, a lecturer in psychology at Swansea University, who recently authored an article in the British Medical Journal headlined: ‚ÄúThe UK is an international outlier in its approach to Covid in children.‚Äù He believes the delay is ‚Äúhard to justify‚Äù, adding: ‚ÄúSo many regulatory authorities globally have approved or even officially recommended the vaccine in this age group, including the United States‚Äô Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, the European Medicines Agency and the World Health Organisation. The UK was in a fortunate position of having early access to vaccines, and relatively high uptake among adults, and yet it has been slow both to initially offer the vaccine for children aged 12 and above, and now to children aged five to 11.‚ÄùHe says there is a lack of clarity as to why it has not yet been made available ‚Äì and if and when it will be ‚Äì by the UK Government to all children in this age group. ‚ÄúOverall, the pandemic is going in the right direction in the UK and there is much to be optimistic about. However, this is masking the trends in schools and schoolchildren where rates are still very high ‚Äì with recent Office for National Statistics data showing one in nine younger children testing positive.‚ÄùIndeed, one argument for vaccinating young children has centred on the need to reduce the disruption the virus continues to cause to their education and social lives. Others suggest we are now past the point where jabs would make a difference to primary schoolchildren, with most having already had Covid. There are also concerns over the ethics of vaccinating children against a disease that is highly unlikely to make them severely ill, if the main reason would be to protect society as a whole.But Dr Deepti Gurdasani, a clinical epidemiologist at Queen Mary, University of London, suggests the UK‚Äôs delay in vaccinating younger children ‚Äúcertainly doesn‚Äôt seem evidence-based‚Äù. She says: ‚ÄúMillions of children this age across the globe have been vaccinated with no issue, and it‚Äôs very clear that vaccination protects against severe illness in children. We‚Äôve seen some of the highest rates of infection, absenteeism due to Covid-19, self-reported long Covid and hospitalisation among children in the past few weeks.¬†‚ÄúThe complacency around childhood vaccination in the UK is astonishing given how rapidly adult vaccination and booster programmes were carried out.‚ÄùMore from NewsRussia crisis: Ukraine joining Nato &#39not on the agenda&#39, says German chancellorPictured: Storms send 300ft Welsh wind turbine crashing to groundLockdown debate skewed because sceptical scientists were shunned on social mediaGCSEs and A-levels: What you need to know about how exams are changing in 2022Prince William sets up &#39life-changing&#39 meeting between grieving boy and his footballing hero after bonding over losing their mothersMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: joining union vital workers feeling
story: Joining a union is vital for workers feeling cost-of-living pinch, says Angela RaynerBritish workers pay packets are not stretching far enough, despite them working harder than ever. Thats why its important to join a trade union to protect yourself at work, writes Labours Deputy Leader Angela RaynerA wasted decade of low growth in our economy under the Conservatives has unsurprisingly come alongside a decade of stagnant pay Image: NurPhoto PA ImagesopinionByAngela Rayner:,  Feb |commentsWe have a serious issue right now in Britain.There is an inflation crisis created in Downing Street that is driving up the cost of utility bills, food, petrol, transport and everyday necessities. Almost daily, I hear from my constituents in Ashton-under-Lyne quite how seriously they are feeling the pinch. Their pay packets are just not stretching far enough. These people range from care workers to young city types, from nurses to supermarket staff, and they all tell me that while they work harder than ever, they are struggling more to make ends meet. We know Brits have needed a pay rise for a very long time, after a decade of wage stagnation and the rise of new insecure forms of work people are left struggling. I know that is not good enough for the families in Ashton-under-Lyne, or families anywhere in Britain.Trade Unions exist to collectively empower workers - and it is that goal that took the Labour Party to Parliament. The Labour Party‚Äôs links with the Trade Unions aren‚Äôt just historic, they are more relevant than ever in these precarious times for British workers and their families.When people need decent pay to keep afloat, flexibility to manage their family le, and the confidence to challenge inequality, Trade Unions are more important than ever. I know that working families are the backbone of our economic growth. A wasted decade of low growth in our economy under the Conservatives has unsurprisingly come alongside a decade of stagnant pay. They have chosen to become the party of high taxes because they are the party of low growth.I also know that despite the barriers the Conservatives have put in the way, good employers and businesses already work closely with Trade Unions because they care about their workers. When I was a Trade Union representative, we only saw victories because businesses understood they needed happy and healthy staff. But those workplaces where people are overworked, unable to switch off, or are paid poverty wages cannot be left unchecked. It is when we come together that we are strongest and achieve the most. Security at work, prosperity in decent pay, and all workers treated with respect. That is Labouraposs New Deal for Working People and the driving mission of the Labour movement. Almost every workplace will have a Trade Union you can join. Find yours on the TUC website.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Conservative PartyLabour PartyBritish economyPoliticsTrades Union CongressAngela Rayner" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: keir starmer promises boost british
story: Keir Starmer promises to boost British manufacturers with a vital shot post-BrexitThe Labour leader will head to Burnley on Tuesday as part of his tour across the North and West Midlands this week. Figures show , jobs were lost in the Midlands over the last decade Image: Getty ImagesByAletha AduPolitical Correspondent:,  Feb |commentsKeir Starmer has promised to deliver a vital shot into Britainaposs economy and boost manufacturing businesses that once powered the nation. Britainaposs manufacturing sector has slumped after a decade of Tory rule as jobs have fallen by , since .Figures published by Labour show , jobs were lost in the North of England and , jobs were lost in the Midlands.In a striking comparison, Germany added almost one million manufacturing jobs between  and .‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not enough to just leave the EU and think the job is done: we must now make Brexit work. That means backing the places that powered our country to get our economy motoring again, Mr Starmer will say in Burnley. The Labour leader continues his tour across the North and West Midlands this week, sharing his plans to deliver security, prosperity and respect for all, directly with voters. Burnley was once a major centre of engineering and the heart of the textiles industry. Mr Starmer will add: The next Labour government would support our manufacturers with practical plans to buy, make and sell in Britain. We would be as ambitious for towns and cities across the country as they are for themselves, investing in skills, technology, and quality jobs - so that people once again feel the benefits of British industry.  This is personal to me. My dad was a toolmaker, so I know the pride that comes with creating and building things ‚Äì and the pain felt when the Tories dismantle that hard work. That‚Äôs why it‚Äôs a crucial part of my contract with the British people, which will build a new Britain that guarantees security, prosperity and respect for all.‚ÄùMr Starmeraposs tour comes as Boris Johnson uses parliamentaposs half-term break to embark on a levelling up tour of the UK.He started in Scotland, with visits to a manufacturing site and research and development projects.
