title: statistical-look-womens-test-cricket-england-host-south-africa-june
story: England Women will play South Africa in a Test match in June as part of a multi-format series.It will be another welcome outing in a rare format for female players and here, the PA news agency takes a statistical look at women‚Äôs Test cricket.Slow decadevw,vw,px, px"Opportunities for Test action have been limited in the women‚Äôs game There have been only  women‚Äôs Test matches in the last  years, with the format grinding to a virtual halt.All  of those have involved either England , Australiaor India , with South Africa the only other nation to feature when they took on India in November .Since a relative peak between  and , with  games in those four years including five separate two-Test series,  and  are the only years to see more than one Test played.This year will join that list but there were none at all in , , ,  or, more understandably given the Covid- pandemic, .There have been only  women‚Äôs Tests ever ‚Äì including two abandoned without a ball bowled ‚Äì since the first one in  between England and Australia.England Womens summer  fixtures have landed!Details and ticket information ‚¨áÔ∏è‚Äî England CricketFebruary , Those two nations lead the way in terms of involvement with England playing in almost two-thirds of all women‚Äôs Tests, , and Australia in .New Zealand and India have played  and  respectively, while South Africa‚Äôs outing in Taunton this summer will be their th and take them one ahead of the West Indies.No other nation has played more than Pakistan‚Äôs three, with Sri Lanka alongside Ireland and Holland in playing a solitary Test. Among Test-playing nations in men‚Äôs cricket, Bangladesh, Zimbabwe and Afghanistan have never played a women‚Äôs Test.The case for five daysThere has been an increasing push in recent months, intensying since the thrilling drawn Test in the Women‚Äôs Ashes, for Tests to be played over five days as in men‚Äôs cricket, rather than four..removeWhen that match ended after four days with all four results possible until the closing overs, it concluded a fth successive drawn women‚Äôs Test ‚Äì a figure which accounts for all fixtures since Australia‚Äôs win over England in August .That is not a new problem, as  per cent of all women‚Äôs Tests excluding the two abandonments have been drawn ‚Äì , compared to only  producing a positive result.An incredible Test match ends in a draw.#Ashes| #AUSvENGpic hTzVkHPaa‚Äî England CricketJanuary , New Zealand and India lead the way with draw percentages in the s, with the White Ferns drawing  out of  Tests and India  out of .Australia‚Äôs win ratio of  per cent is the highest in the format, at least among those to play more than once, while they are alongside England on a record  wins with no other nation managing more than five.One encouraging sign for June‚Äôs match is that six of South Africa‚Äôs previous  Tests have ended in a result, albeit with a solitary win and five defeats.The International Cricket Council‚Äôs laws state that the duration of women‚Äôs Test matches is four days. They do allow for the possibility of a reserve dayan entire day‚Äôs play is lost but play cannot take place on more than four days..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: A statistical look at women us Test cricket as England host South Africa in June

title: golda-film-producer-admits-stirring-jewish-casting-controversy
story: Film producer Michael Kuhn said he was ‚Äústirring‚Äù the controversy around whether non-Jewish actors could play Jewish characters in his latest film.The -year-old, who honoured for services to the film industry, said the controversy over his latest picture, Golda, a biopic about Israeli first female PM Golda Meir,¬†was good for publicity.The lead, the character of Meir, who was Jewish, is played by Dame Helen Mirren." data-title"Golda Meir " data--holder"PA Archive" data--notice"PA Archive PA Images" data-credit"PA" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Golda Meir Mr Kuhn said he made the confession to the Princess Royal as he collected his CBE at an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle on Tuesday.The -year-old told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúI just mentioned about the film I‚Äôm finishing now with Helen Mirren and she obviously knew about all the controversy there had been with ‚Äòcan a non-Jew play a Jew‚Äô and I told her I was stirring it as much as I could for publicity and she seemed quite amused by that.‚ÄùActor Dame Maureen Lipman criticised the casting, the Jewish Chronicle reported." data-title"Helen Mirren as Golda Meir" data--holder"PA Media" data--notice"PA Media" data-credit"Jasper Wolf Assemble publicity" data-usage-terms"PICTURE DESK USE ONLY. NO SALES" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production cdaffadcddYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMMDUx ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production cdaffadcddYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMMDUx ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production cdaffadcddYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMMDUx ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Dame Helen Mirren portraying Israel‚Äôs first female prime minister, Golda Meir She said: ‚ÄúWith that I disagree, because the Jewishness of the character is so integral‚Äù, according to the paper.‚ÄúI‚Äôm sure shewill be marvellous, but it would never be allowed for Ben Kingsley to play Nelson Mandela.‚ÄúYou just couldn‚Äôt even go there.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Golda film producer admits to  ustirring u Jewish casting controversy

title: starmer-pm-needs-get-house-order-dirty-russian-cash
story: The Government needs to ‚Äúget its house in order‚Äùit is serious about tackling ‚Äúdirty money‚Äù from Russia coming into the UK, Keir Starmer has said.The Labour leader also called for the Government to ‚Äúgo now and go hard‚Äù with sanctions against Russia, as he said the Prime Minister shouldall ‚ÄúRussian-linked‚Äù donations to the Conservative party over the last  years.Sir Keir made the comments after the Prime Minister announced a new Economic Crime Bill would ‚Äúhit companies‚Äù laundering Kremlin-linked Russian money through Britain.It comes after Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said UK sanctionsMoscow invades Ukraine would be severe in targeting ‚Äúoligarchs‚Äù and ‚Äúcompanies across Russia‚Äù.Sir Keir said Labour ‚Äústands united‚Äù with the Government against Russian aggression, but also said: ‚ÄúFor a decade, the Tories have not just failed to challenge Russian influence ‚Äì they have enabled it.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúIf Boris Johnson is now serious about tackling Russian dirty money and influence, he should immediately get his own house in order.‚ÄúThat means ing the millions of pounds of Russian-linked cash that has been donated to the Tories and their MPs since he became Prime Minister, and reversing his plans to allow unlimited donations from abroad.‚ÄùSir Keir also called for the Government to take other steps to limit the spread of corrupt cash, including reforming Companies House, creating a register of overseas entities and a register of foreign agents, and bringing forward new counter-espionage laws.In an interview with Channel  News, Sir Keir added: ‚ÄúWe should go now and hard with the sanctions.‚ÄúIt is important, I should say that we stand united with our allies in the face of Russian aggression. It‚Äôs very important we stand united in the United Kingdom in the face of Russian aggression. ‚ÄùConservative MPs were also critical of what they have perceived to be a lack of action on honing in on Russian money being invested in the UK..removeBob Seely, a member of the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee , said Britain was ‚Äúa decade behind the times‚Äù on the threat posed by Russian financial influence.We need a long-term and coherent plan and a strategy to deal with a dangerous world. Our states need to understand how neo-authoritarian states use the full spectrum of state power military, economic, energy, espionage, political, etc. We are not there yet.  ‚Äî Bob Seely MPFebruary , The Isle of Wight MP told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúOn Russia, we have known about this problem for years.‚ÄúThe problem is that the front line with Ukraine is the border, the front line with Germany is the gas pipeline ‚Äì and the front line with the UK is the City of London.‚ÄúWe need to be wiser about how the Putin regime acts and the potential threat to our institutions and values, and how we can protect them against a potential tsunami of questionable money.‚ÄùMr Seely also said any legislation should be widely targeted enough to incorporate the growing threat posed by China.FAC chairman Tom Tugendhat said it was time to clean out money from British politics that had originated in Russia.‚ÄúFrankly, get it out and get it out now,‚Äù he told Times Radio.There was cross-party agreement that the changes being proposed in the Government‚Äôs economic crime legislation had been needed well before the crisis with Ukraine developed.Senior Labour MP Chris Bryant, who is also an FAC member, told PA: ‚ÄúThis should have been in place before this whole saga, not after.‚ÄúTalk about the horse having bolted.‚ÄùMr Bryant said warnings about Russian money had come from the Foreign Affairs Committee in  with its Moscow‚Äôs Gold report, as well as ‚Äôs Intelligence and Security Committee report on Russian influence in Britain‚Äôs democracy.He added: ‚ÄúIt is like the Prime Minister has finally woken up to contraception the day after conception.‚ÄùBut the Prime Minister, speaking after a Cobra meeting about Ukraine and Russia border tensions, defended the UK‚Äôs record on tackling Russian monetary influence at home.He told broadcasters: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs fair to say the UK hasn‚Äôt done a huge amount on dirty money, whether it‚Äôs from Russia or anywhere .‚ÄùMr Johnson added: ‚ÄúWhat we want to do is strengthen now the package that we have, strengthen the measures we have against potential ill-gotten Russian money, whether here or anywhere for‚Ä¶ which we have responsibility, with new measures that will hit the companies and concerns that I‚Äôve talked about.‚ÄúBut also open up the Matryoshka doll,you like ‚Äì you know what I‚Äôm talking about ‚Äì so that we see ‚Ä¶ who really owns the companies that we‚Äôre talking about, who really owns the properties that we‚Äôre talking about, and those measures, yes, we will be bringing forward from the Economic Crime Bill.‚ÄùHe signalled that the Bill would be brought forward in the next Queen‚Äôs Speech..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Starmer: PM needs to  uget his house in order on dirty Russian cash u

title: rail-services-end-early-scotland-prepares-storm-dudley
story: Train services in Scotland will end at pm on Wednesday as the country braces itself ahead of being hit by the first of two storms.ScotRail announced on Tuesday its services would end early on Wednesday due to Storm Dudley, the forecast for which has led to the Met Office issuing an amber weather warning for the north of England and the central belt and south of Scotland.Gusts could rise as high as  miles per hour in coastal areas, with the amber warning due to come into force at pm tomorrow and expire at midnight, when it will be downgraded to a yellow warning until am on Thursday.Storm Dudley will be immediately followed by Storm Eunice later this week.‚ö†Ô∏èTHREAD: Scotland is bracing itself for #StormDudleytomorrow. The welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most @ScotRailtrain services will shut down from  on Wednesday .   pic QGGxZWpFA‚Äî ScotRailFebruary , Deputy First Minister John Swinney said the weather could cause disruption to travel and power supplies as well as danger from falling trees.‚ÄúWe expect another period of disruption this week, with Storms Dudley and Eunice set to bring strong winds to Scotland,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúHigh winds may cause issues on roads and bridges, disruption to power supplies and danger from falling trees. We would urge everyone to plan their journeys in advance, exercise caution on the roads, and follow the latest travel advice.‚ÄùFollowing a meeting of the Scottish Government‚Äôs Resilience Room, the Deputy First Minister said they would continue to monitor the situation as the storms approach.Services running in the far north, Kyle of Lochalsh, and Aberdeen-Inverness lines will continue to run as usual because the areas are outside the boundaries of the weather warning.‚ÄúScotland is bracing itself for Storm Dudley tomorrow,‚Äù the rail operator said on Twitter.‚ÄúThe welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most ScotRail train services will shut down from  on Wednesday.‚Äù.removeThe RNLI warned adverse weather conditions could make seas ‚Äútreacherous‚Äù, urging people to take extra care in coastal areas.‚ÄúThe expected storms could make our seas treacherous, increasing the risk for those visiting the coast around the UK and Ireland,‚Äù RNLI national water safety partner, Samantha Hughes, said.‚ÄúIn a normal year, around  people lose their lives at the coast and we know that more than half of those never intended to be in the water.‚ÄúSo, whether you are walking, running or cycling at the coast, please be extra responsible and avoid taking unnecessary risk or entering the water.‚ÄúIn particular, we ask people to stay well back from stormy, wintery seas and clf edges, check tide times before you go, take a phone with you, and call  or  and ask for the Coastguardyou or someone  is in trouble.‚ÄùMeanwhile, the Woodland Trust Scotland urged people to stay away from wooded areas during the high winds.‚ÄúPlease do not enter woodland when winds are high and be cautious when entering woodland after a storm,‚Äù said spokesman, George Anderson.He added: ‚ÄúEven fully toppled trees are best avoided when newly felled as they are often not completely settled and still have the potential to move or tip.‚ÄúWe know a felled tree can be fascinating, especially to children, but it is not safe to clamber about on or under them.‚ÄúWoodland Trust Scotland manages  sites across the country and, in the aftermath of any storm, public safety is our first concern.‚ÄúWhere paths are blocked, we will have them cleared as quickly as possible but, in the meantime, we call on the public to heed all path ersions and safety notices on sites.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Rail services to end early as Scotland prepares for Storm Dudley

title: covid-vaccine-offered-five-11-year-olds-wales-minister-says
story: Wales has become the first country in the UK to announce it will be offering the Covid- vaccine to all five to -year-olds.Wales‚Äô health minister Eluned Morgan said she had read the ‚Äúyet to be published‚Äù report by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationand would be further rolling out the jab.There are reports the JCVI announcement of its decision on whether to expand the immunisation programme to younger children has been delayed due to a disagreement with the UK Government.Responding to questions during a Plenary session at the Senedd on Tuesday, Baroness Morgan called the hold-up a ‚Äúshame‚Äù and ‚Äúperplexing‚Äù.She said: ‚ÄúIn relation to vaccination of children, the JCVI has yet to publish its report, although there are lots of clues inand other places where there seems to have been lots of leaks come out.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame and it‚Äôs perplexing to understand why that has not been published yet.‚ÄúBut I have seen a copy of that advice and we will be commencing the rollout of vaccinations for five to -year-olds.‚ÄùThe minister has not set out a timetable for when youngsters will be able to get the jab, and told Senedd members: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to do that as a matter of urgency, as we did over the Christmas period. That‚Äôs partly because the risk isn‚Äôt as great to that cohort.‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre also waiting to hear from the JCVI to see whether they‚Äôll need a booster on top of the booster for older age groups in the spring.‚ÄùShe added: ‚ÄúOf course, it‚Äôs likely to have been a very dficult decision for the JCVI, because generally, children have a milder illness and fewer hospitalisations. But, of course, they have to balance that against the prospect of missing school.‚ÄúWe have to consider very dferent issues when it comes to the vaccination of children as young as five years old, of course, so we‚Äôll be in a position where we will expect those children to be accompanied by an adult. There will be a need for informed consent, but there will be an opportunity for siblings, for example, to be brought at the same time.‚Äù.removeBaroness Morgan said children would receive the vaccine in health centres.The UK medical regulator, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency , approved the Pfizer Covid- vaccine for use in children aged five to  last year.The dose approved for children is lower than that used for adults and older children.After the announcement, the JCVI said that the vaccine should be offered to at-risk children in this age group. It is yet to announce its decision about wider use among children aged five to .Over . million dosages of the vaccine have already been administered to five to -year-olds in the US alone.A Government spokesperson in Westminster said: ‚ÄúWe are reviewing the JCVI‚Äôs advice as part of wider decision-making ahead of the publication of our long-term strategy for living with COVID-. More detail will be set out shortly.‚ÄùThe Government in England is expected to make an announcement next week.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government urged Westminster to quickly publish the advice, saying they ‚Äústand ready‚Äù to implement any JCVI recommendation.‚ÄúWhen the UK Government publishes the final advice on vaccination for  to -year-olds we stand ready to take it forward,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúFollowing the update from the Welsh Government on this matter in the Senedd, we hope that the UK Government will publish the JCVI advice as quickly as is practicable.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Covid vaccine to be offered to all five to -year-olds in Wales, minister says

title: top-5-date-ideas-scotland-valentines-day
story: The most romantic day of the year is here! If you‚Äôre still having a think over ideas to mark the occasion with a special someone, not to fret - we‚Äôve pulled together a round-up of romantic and offbeat date ideas around Scotland that are sure to impress.. Explore the Black Linn Falls at the HermitageTake a trip to the Black Linn Falls. Nestled in the leafy growth of The Hermitage, nestled amongst giant Douglas Firs , enjoy a romantic walk and take in the stunning scenery.If you really want to impress your date, the best place to view the cascading falls is at the viewing spot: ‚ÄòOssian‚Äôs Hall of Mirrors‚Äô. The Georgian building erected in  hosts a painting of Romantic poet Ossain, and a hall of mirrors which gives the illusion of being surrounded by water at all angles.https:www.visitscotland info see-do the-hermitage-pImage credit: Paul Farmer. Book in for a drink at the Summerhall drinks labThe Summerhall Drinks Lab in Edinburgh are renowned for their idiosyncratic experiences - from gin cruises, to whiskyand vegan cheese tastings, to classes on creating your own mixer.Pop in for a drink - and a gt voucher for one of their experiences would make the perfect additional surprise for your special someone.https:summerhalldrinkslab ¬†,  px px  rgbamargin: pxmax-width: pxmin-width: pxpadding: width: .%width: -webkit-calcwidth: calc"" fill"#"View this post on InstagramtranslateY"translateX translateYwidth: .pxflex-grow: margin-right: pxmargin-left: px"translateY"translateY rotate"""translateX"A post shared by Summerhall Drinks Lab . Stargaze at the Galloway Forest ParkPerhaps the most famous stargazing spot in Scotland - and for good reason! - the Galloway Forest Park contains plenty of Dark Sky Discovery Points. These are places that are removed from local light pollution, provide stunning views of the skyline, and have good public access - including for wheelchair users.The nearby Clatteringshaws Visitor Centre overlooks the darkest part of the Forest Park - the perfect spot for some truly spectacular gazing.https:forestryandland.gov.scot visit forest-parks galloway-forest-park dark-skies¬†. Escape to a secret treehouse getaway.removeNestled in the wilderness of Lanrick, these eco-friendly treehouse getaways are perfect for an unforgettable trip away from it all. These fairytale-esque accommodations provide the perfect blend of luxury comforts and wild nature - they really must be seen to be believed.They‚Äôre perfectly located to explore the nearby Trossachs National Park - just a short drive away - with activities like mountain climbing, wild swimming and canoeing providing ample opportunity for quality time.https:www.lanricktreehouses ,  px px  rgbamargin: pxmax-width: pxmin-width: pxpadding: width: .%width: -webkit-calcwidth: calc"" fill"#"View this post on InstagramtranslateY"translateX translateYwidth: .pxflex-grow: margin-right: pxmargin-left: px"translateY"translateY rotate"""translateX"A post shared by The Treehouses at Lanrick . Not your ordinary cinematic experienceSo the idea of a film might on the surface sound cliche - but this is a cinematic experience with a twist. At Everyman cinema in Glasgow you can arrive early to woo your date over cocktails - and thenyou really want to pull out the big guns, order food and drinks to be delivered straight to your seat at the cinema. The seats in question are sofas - perfect for cuddling up to your loved one.And oh - don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs nothing for youyou‚Äôre single and a bit over Valentine‚Äôs Day. Everyman are screening a special ‚ÄúPalentine‚Äôs‚Äù day screening to mark Superbad‚Äôs th anniversary too.

title: pupils succumb to table topping kilsyth
story: Campbeltown Pupils competed well last Saturday at home to Division Four league leaders Kilsyth Athletic ‚Äì but still came up short in a six-goal affair.Counting the cost of several absences due to long-term injuries and Covid- infections, the Pupils named a relatively inexperienced squad but there were still familiar faces at Kintyre Park.This included theof Donald McCallum for his first start since August, and Ryan Deans ‚Äì scorer from the Pupils# last outing, on December , against Harthill Royal ‚Äì playing as a lone frontman in a --- formation.McCallum and Deans linked up well in the opening stages and, along with Crossan and Robertson in central midfield, worked hard on a heavy Kintyre Park pitch to keep the team moving forward against the dominant side in the ision so far this season.However, no goal could be found for the Pupils in the first half and it was the visitors who led at the break, -, after the Pupils conceded a penalty, when the Kilsyth number nine got the wrong side of a Pupils defender and was brought to ground.The Kilsyth striker dusted himself down to slot his kick low to keeper Lorne Paterson#s left-hand side.A notable debutant in goal for the McFadyens-sponsored Pupils, young keeper Paterson acquitted himself very well after being called into the squad at short notice, one of the community football club#s successful under-s side doing so much good work in their regional Sunday league this season.Four minutes into the second half, Paterson¬†pounced to make a stunning point-blank save from a close-range effort from Kilsyth, before sending the ball forward, after which Ryan Deans pounced on some defensive indecision to run through on goal and equalise for the Pupils.In a one-v-one situation with the Kilsyth keeper, Deans kept his composure, feigning a chip to wrong-foot the keeper, before calmly passing a low shot into the right side of the goal.However, the Pupils# plans were undone due to a madcap -minute spell which saw them concede three goals, with visitors# recent signing Joseph Bevan scoring two of an eventual hat-trick after some classy finishing on his favoured left foot.The Feathers-Inn sponsored Pupils tried again to rally at - and had a good chance to score when Robertson freed John McCallum to play in Andrew Renton.Renton advanced on the left side of the box, but the youngster#s touch when bearing down on goal was just on the heavy side, and allowed the keeper to lunge at his feet and collect the ball at the last moment.Kilsyth made it - with  minutes remaining to end the match as a contest, giving the score line a harsh look from a Pupils# perspective, having competed well with their lofty opponents for an hour of the contest.And while such defeats are always tough for a team#s players and management, they still offer valuable on-field experience for the young Pupils players in the squad, as they adjust to a higher, more physically demanding level of football in the West of Scotland FL.The Pupils have nine fixtures left to play this season ‚Äì five at home and four away ‚Äì and are on the road again tomorrowagainst second-placed Finnart FC, at Springburn Park. Kick off is .pm.Campbeltown Pupils# squad: Lorne Paterson, Conner Brown, Jamie Burns, Ross Souden, Craig Johnstone, John McCallum, Stuart Crossan, Donald McCallum, Ellis Robertson, Kenny Kerr, Ryan Deans. Subs : Matthew Lang, Andrew Renton, Calum McKillop.

title: thought for the week january 21 2022
story: We#ve been watching the BBC television series Saving Lives at Sea.One episode, filmed last May, showed the Thames RNLI team who had been called to help Minnie the minke whale calf.The little whale, having swum into the river, had beached itself on a weir.With the use of an inflatable raft, after several hours of team effort, the whale was re-floated.However, during their attempt to tow the animal back down-river to the sea, it managed to free itself.The following day, Minnie was spotted again but this time it had swum further up-stream and was stranded at Teddington Lock.Sadly, during that day, in spite of the efforts of RNLI, coastguard, fire brigade and river authorities, the animal became too weak to rescue.If only Minnie had been able to understand that those efforts of kindness, to coax it, and lead it and guide it, were all directed to provide freedom and le the cool clear Atlantic waters whales are designed to enjoy.Perhaps the raft did feel restrictive, perhaps at times the slings felt uncomfortable. How much trust would have been required for the whale to submit to its rescuer The bible tells us that we are just like Minnie: we want to be free, but think freedom is to be found by going our own way, the way we all choose by nature.But the bible tells us that the way to freedom is actually not to escape, but to trust and submit to our rescuer the Lord Jesus.He didn#t only spend hours of effort and skill to liberate us he spent himself.Jesus said: #If the Son sets you free, you will be free indeed.#Why not turn and trust Him

story: In the first group out Ailie McBrayne and Katharine Hardman set a good pace and carded scores of and respectively.In the following group last month#s medal winner, Linda Arkell, continued her winning form and ed an impressive score of  .Despite valiant efforts, the remaining players were unable to match Linda#s score.Results:  Linda Arkell #  Ailie McBrayne  Elizabeth Marrison BIH  Katharine Hardman  .
