title: driving-ban-drink-driver-pulled-longniddry
story: Oliver Moss, of College Way, was pulled over by police officers at Main Street in Longniddry on December  last year.Moss gave officers a roadside breath test reading of mg of alcohol in ml of breath.The legal limit is just mg.The -year-old appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Tuesday, where he was banned from driving for  months.Sherf Peter McCormack also imposed a community payback order and told Moss he must complete  hours of unpaid work in the community

title: hamish-mcmenemy-scaling-north-berwick-law-charity
story: Hamish McMenemy, , who has ADHD , is taking on the challenge to raise money for CAMHS .Hamish, of Lady Jane Road, got the idea when he climbed the Law with his friends, and told his mum Jane he wanted to climb it for charity.Jane said: ‚ÄúHe was wanting to do something for charity we mentioned CAMHS and he said: ‚ÄòLet‚Äôs do something for that.‚Äô‚ÄùHe and friends from his primary six class will now challenge themselves to climb the Law every day in March to raise as much cash as possible. and friends ready to tackle the Law" alt"East Lothian Courier: Hamish McMenemyand friends ready to tackle the Law" class"editor-image"Hamish McMenemyand friends ready to tackle the Law CAMHS is an NHS-run service that helps treat young people with a iety of challenges.Mental health treatment has suffered during the pandemic and many children have struggled to be referred and diagnosed, said Hamish‚Äôs mum.Jane said: ‚ÄúIt was an absolute fight to get a referral for Hamish, as it is for everybody. I have spoken to so many parents who have kids and such a massive backlog of waiting to be seen.‚ÄúHamish was diagnosed the day before lockdown, in March , so we were lucky to have got through that.‚ÄùMany children in the county remain undiagnosed and unable to receive treatment as a result of the added strain on the NHS caused by Covid, Jane added.Tracey McKigen, services director of Royal Edinburgh and Associated Services for NHS Lothian, said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very grateful that Hamish has chosen CAMHS.‚ÄúWe‚Äôll ensure the money he raises contributes to supporting children and young people, and their families, and we wish him the absolute best of luck.‚ÄùA JustGiving page for donations to Hamish is due to be set up.

title: lengthy-link-dunbar-royal-british-legion-recognised
story: David Bolton has held a iety of roles in the organisation since first linking up in the late s.He was chairman for  years from  to , and spent a further six years as the branch president.His connection was marked at the Legion‚Äôs AGM last month, when he stepped down from the role.Mr Bolton, who lives in the town with his we Elizabeth, who was previously the Legion‚Äôs secretary, was presented with a special commemorative silver crown coin to mark his  years of service by branch chairman Duncan Laing.Mrs Bolton told the Courier that her husband had held a iety of roles, ranging from bingo caller to vice-chairman.Mr Bolton, , had previously worked as a joiner with East Lothian Council for  years, before retiring  years ago.Since then, he has been heavily involved at the Legion, off the town‚Äôs High Street.A new president is yet to be selected.

title: tribute-paid-former-honest-lass-may-wright
story: Born into a loving family at Fisherrow in , she was ‚Äúextremely proud‚Äù of her home town and heritage, and was described as ‚Äúa good friend and role model to many‚Äù by Alison Elgin, president of the Honest Toun‚Äôs Association and a past Honest Lass.She said: ‚ÄúMay was so special ‚Äì the Musselburgh Festival will not be the same without her and all the laughter and joy she brought.‚ÄùMay‚Äôs father Tom was an insurance agent and her mother Chat , who had been in service, was a homemaker. Her sister Margaret and brother Edward then arrived as the family grew.May, right, dressed as a fisherwoman May was described as ‚Äúa lively, affectionate girl‚Äù who was soon doing chores for her mum and running errands for her aunts. She often claimed that she attended up to seven Sunday church services in one day and loved singing hymns.She was a keen scholar and did well at school, eventually working in an office on Edinburgh‚Äôs George Street. She recounted that during the war years, on the bus home, when people had to extinguish all lights including street lights, it was ‚Äúa hit or miss‚Äù whether you managed to get off at the desired stop.In , May was in a picture house enjoying a film when the house lights came on suddenly and the manager announced that war was over and peace had been declared. She recalled that ‚Äúeveryone started dancing and hugging amidst tears of joy and happiness‚Äù.In , at the age of , she was elected as Musselburgh‚Äôs Honest Lass, along with her Honest Lad David Howie.May, left, with her mother and two aunts dressed in costume on the theme of the th century ballad The Four Marys This was a prestigious honour and May was said to have taken to it ‚Äúlike a duck to water‚Äù. As Honest Lad and Honest Lass, they attended many civic receptions as part of their duties.On one such outing, May found herself on a boat in the middle of Fisherrow Harbour with a megaphone addressing a crowd of over , townsfolk!Another of her tasks during the festival week was to ride a horse in the traditional Ride Out, which included galloping across the River Esk. She rose to the challenge, taking a crash course in horse riding.May went on to keep a close connection with the Honest Toun‚Äôs Association throughout the rest of her le.She met her future husband John while serving teas after local rugby games and they married in .May and John on their wedding day in  John, from Edinburgh, was working as transport controller for Dalkeith Transport and the couple lived briefly in Bonnyrigg, where their son William was born. They later moved to Pathhead, where they welcomed their other son David and daughter Yvonne to the family.In , Dalkeith Transport moved to Fordel and the family moved to Whitehill Farm. May passed her driving test and began a new phase of le as manager of Fordel Garage and Campsite.In , her beloved husband John passed away.When Dalkeith Transport moved to Newtongrange, May, described as a people person, made her final and possibly most enjoyable career move when she became a market researcher.In , she was devastated by the loss of her daughter Yvonne and her sister Margaret, and drew on the loving support of her family.May, who latterly lived in Rosewell, was fiercely independent, keeping house and making meals, but her energy levels suddenly dropped. She rallied to enjoy family celebrations on Christmas Day  but, on December , she passed away at the Royal Infirmary of Edinburgh.May as Honest Lass in  Her son David described her as ‚Äúan incredible woman, passionate, caring, considerate and a real party girl‚Äù.He added: ‚ÄúShe was interested and interesting. Her le touched so many others in such a positive way always a smile, always a kind word. She will be sadly missed by her family, friends and all who knew her.‚ÄùMay, a great grandmother of three, is survived by her sons William and David and grandsons Mike, Alistair, Jonny and Jamie. She was predeceased by her husband John and their daughter Yvonne.May‚Äôs funeral took place at Mortonhall Crematorium on January .

title: torness-power-station-call-support-hundreds-employees
story: The nuclear power station is the workplace for about  people, with a further  subcontractors.At the end of last year, it was confirmed that the EDF station would close Torness in  ‚Äì two years earlier than previously expected.Kenny MacAskill, MP for East Lothian, has already called for support to be given to those employed at the station.Now he has been backed by the Nuclear Free Local AuthoritiesScotland Forum.Mr MacAskill said: ‚ÄúNuclear power station sites are selected by governments and they‚Äôve a duty to meet costs when they close.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs just not good enough for the UK Government to wash their hands and walk away.‚ÄúGreat service has been given by staff and support shown by the community. It‚Äôs important, therefore, that financial assistance is provided to the council and community to allow for transition.‚ÄùConstruction at the power station, to the east of Dunbar, began in .Power has been generated since  and, in , it generated enough low-carbon electricity for . million homes.Decommissioning work is expected to take several years.Feargal Dalton, convenor of the NFLA Scotland Forum, said: ‚ÄúThe NFLA is totally opposed to the continuance of civil nuclear power in Scotland as we are convinced that our nation‚Äôs energy needs can be met through renewables.‚ÄúHowever, we also recognise that in communities, such as Hunterston and Torness, where a nuclear plant closes there will be an impact upon the local economy but this can be fully mitigated through decommissioning work and the skilled workforce transferring to the expanding renewables sector.‚ÄúNuclear businesses such as the outgoing operator EDF Energy and the incoming Nuclear Decommissioning Agency receive a great deal of public funding.‚ÄúWe want to see a part of that funding directed to ensure that there are the right resources in place to retain and retrain as many local employees as want them in new jobs in defueling and decommissioning, and, for those employees who wish to leave, access to specialist job search support to secure alternate, well-paid employment where.‚ÄùIn , the station‚Äôs operational le was extended by seven years to .EDF said that remained under constant review and inspections had now given ‚Äúa clearer picture of letime expectations‚Äù for Torness.

title: pencaitland-ambulance-worker-recognised-act-bravery
story: Neil Spiers was recognised at the Scottish Government‚Äôs Brave@Heart Awards, which celebrate incredible acts of bravery by blue light service workers.When Neil arrived early for his sht as a call handler, he heard a woman shouting for help as she had fallen into freezing water.Neil immediately called for assistance and gave the woman his jacket to keep her warm until emergency services arrived.Later the same day during his sht, he received a call from a member of the public who had found a man in the water.Neil gave CPR instructions over the phone until an ambulance arrived.Neil was one of five Scottish Ambulance Service staff members to receive the award and their bravery has been celebrated by bosses.Pauline Howie, Scottish Ambulance Service chief executive, said: ‚ÄúThe actions of these staff are commendable, and they each showed extraordinary bravery.‚ÄúAll our staff do amazing, lesaving work each day, and this is a small sample.‚ÄúThe staff are all wonderful ambassadors for the Scottish Ambulance Service and fully deserving of their awards.‚Äù

title: flags-signs-advertise-blindwells-site-raised
story: Construction work on homes at Blindwells is well under way, with nearly  affordable homes to be included at the former opencast mine.Now, ious signs and flags are planned to advertise the site, and East Lothian Council is considering the proposals from Hargreaves Services , which would see ‚Äú hoarding boards, three totem signs and  flags‚Äù.Consent is already in place for , new homes at the site, between Tranent and Longniddry, as well as shops, restaurants, leisure facilities and a new primary school.Various developers, including Bellway, Cruden and Persimmon Homes, are involved in building the new homes.

title: tablets-available-need
story: The group bought more than a dozen of the devices in  to help people who were isolating at the height of the coronavirus pandemic to keep in touch with loved ones.The devices were ided between Haddington Care Home, Hilton Lodge Nursing Home and Our Community Kitchen, all based in the town.Chris McEwan, chairman of the community council, said: ‚ÄúWe have had some tablets ed to us, which were redistributed ‚Äì three of those to a family for Christmas.‚ÄùEach of the devices will be reset to factory settings and attempts are being made to find new homes for them.For more information, email all@haddingtoncc.org.uk

title: east-lothian-ev-chargers-hoggers-issue-tackled
story: East Lothian Council has joined forces with vehicle chargepoint management  Fuuse to install sensors at town centre charging sites at the Gracefield and Shorthope Street car parks, where use of the bays is restricted to plugged-in vehicles only.Sensors will detect the presence of parked vehicles and the Fuuse‚Äôs technology will alert the council‚Äôs parking management teamany of those vehicles are not plugged in.The project is part of the council‚Äôs wider strategy to provide ‚Äúattractive charging solutions‚Äù for people without a driveway or safe place to charge at home.Additional sensors will be installed nearby at Esk- side East, where the council will deploy further bollard-style ‚Äòon-street‚Äô chargers following successful trials last year.These chargers will continue to have no parking restrictions next to them, as the council says it recognises parking is at a premium in many residential areas.To address the fear these kinds of charger are frequently blocked, the Fuuse App will display the availability of parking spaces and not just the status of the chargers themselves.EV drivers who remain in charging spaces beyond a permitted duration ‚Äì or after their session is complete ‚Äì can also receive notications to vacate the space, allowing others to access the charger and avoiding fines.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Council transport spokesperson, said: ‚ÄúFor those who don‚Äôt have a safe place to park and charge at home, seeing live, on-street status in their area will address potential concerns over finding an attractive space close to their home.‚ÄúWe know this can deter people from switching to EVs.‚ÄúFor those that choose to use our many destination or journey-charging sites such as Gracefield car park ‚Äì where use of bays is restricted to plugged-in cars only ‚Äì they‚Äôll know that any hogging or blocking will be detected and addressed by our parking team.‚ÄùDan Lucy-Lloyd, product director at Fuuse, said: ‚ÄúThis project with East Lothian offers the perfect test bed for how advances in chargepoint management can optimise existing infrastructure.‚ÄúUtilising the long range of LoRaWan [long range wide area network] technology, the solution will be easily scalable across urban and rural environments.‚ÄúThis means East Lothian Council will be able to easily monitor and demonstrate the accessibility of their entire network and will be setting an innovative example to local authorities throughout the UK.‚ÄùThe project is funded by Transport Scotland and managed by Scottish Enterprise through the Can Do Innovation Low Carbon Challenge.

title: winton-castle-says-goodbye-head-gardener-toby-subiotto
story: Winton Castle, near Pencaitland, is on the lookout for a head gardener after Toby Subiotto retired following  years in the role.Toby had previously worked at Kew Gardens, The Royal Botanic Garden and private gardens, and had helped restore and replant much of the garden.Sir Francis Ogilvy, owner of Winton Estate, wanted visitors ‚Äúto be wowed as soon as they drive through the gates‚Äù.He said: ‚ÄúThe setting alone should be tempting to an ambitious gardener: a historic landscape with woodland gardens, a loch, wild garden and flower meadow.‚ÄúThe warm, south-facing terraces have a rose garden, dahlia borders and mixed herbaceous and shrub borders.‚ÄúAdd to the mix a .-acre walled garden with extensive colourful borders and a wisteria pergola.‚ÄúThe walled garden is linked closely with the recently rejuvenated Potting Shed events venue, which is popular for garden parties and weddings.‚ÄùWinton opens its gardens to the public on April  under Scotland‚Äôs Garden Scheme.The closing date for applications is Friday .For more information, go to wintoncastle

title: haddington-festival-set-return-summer
story: The staple of the town‚Äôs social calendar has been cancelled or scaled back the last two years due to the coronavirus pandemic.However, with restrictions easing, organisers are busy working behind the scenes to ensure the town has something to celebrate this summer.Volunteer members of Haddington Events Group have already met, with a view to the festival taking place from May  to June .Chris McEwan, chairman of Haddington‚Äôs community council, is involved with the Edinburgh and Lothians Mini Owners Club, which was regularly part of the festival‚Äôs fun day in Neilson Park.Haddington Festival fancy dress parade He told the Courier that work had started to plan the festival, with ious events already pencilled in.Mr McEwan stressed the importance of the annual event and said: ‚ÄúThe festival is our gateway to the summer.‚ÄúIt is something that has been traditional since .‚ÄúIt is a chance for the town to see and do things together, a chance for businesses to take part just like the Christmas window competition, get people round the town, and it is a chance to showcase our town to the greater country and to invite people along.‚ÄúWhen I did the car show, we had people from all over Scotland coming with cars. That brought in tourism, visitors, but at the end of the day, for me, it is giving families and the kids a good day out.‚ÄùThe week-long Haddington Festival is a central point of the town‚Äôs summer celebrations.Preparations are under way for the festival fun day in Neilson Park and a number of vendors have been approached.The Haddington Festival is usually one of the highlights of the towns events calendar A shop window competition, organised by Haddington Business Community Partnership , is also being planned.Regular features of the festival week, including a quiz night, bingo night and boat race, are all being planned as well.A tree could also be planted at the end of the festival to mark the Queen‚Äôs platinum jubilee.One challenge facing organisers is the lack of a central venue, as refurbishment works take place at Haddington Town House and the nearby Corn Exchange is used by NHS Lothian as a Covid- vaccination centre.That could see the traditional pet show become an online event.Mr McEwan was hoping to overcome as many hurdles as possible to ensure that the town was celebrating this summer.He said: ‚ÄúWe are hoping the fun day is going to be as traditional as possible, with a fun fair and car show.‚ÄúIt is all going to be dependent on who is going to come along.‚ÄúI very much doubt we are going to have as many Covid restrictions to scupper us.‚ÄúThe programme will be delivered out to everybody in round about May.‚Äù

title: knox-academy-praised-face-coronavirus-pandemic
story: Various restrictions over the past near two years have made it challenging for pupils to continue learning in a traditional manner.Robert Flood, curriculum leader ‚Äì social subjects at Knox Academy, attended a recent meeting of the towns community council.He said: ‚ÄúEveryone has worked really hard to try to keep things as normal as possible and as many activities happening in the school and extra-curricular activities as well.‚Äù

title: john-muir-birthplace-hosts-anna-davis-exhibition
story: Anna Davis will see her work on display at John Muir‚Äôs Birthplace from February .‚ÄòWater-way Following the Papana Water to Belhaven Bay‚Äô features paintings, drawings and writing.The artist, who is based in West Barns, has created a limited edition book that is a journey of impressions, writing and images from the Lammermuirs to Belhaven Bay.The book Water-way follows the journey of the Papana Water through East Lothian.

title: work-starts-new-east-linton-railway-station
story: Network Rail was given permission for the station by East Lothian Council in September last year.When complete, it will be the first time the village has had a railway station since .Campaigners have been calling for a station tofor more than two decades.¬†üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å≥Û†Å£Û†Å¥Û†Åø Scotlands Railway is expanding. ‚Å∞‚Å∞üèóÔ∏è Work on a brand new station in East Linton, @ELCouncil has begun. title: lego-unveils-spice-girls-tribute-set---buy
story: The major toy retailer has unveiled the special collection to celebrate the th anniversary of the iconic Spiceworld album.¬†The¬†LEGO¬†BrickHeadz‚Ñ¢ Spice Girls has immortalised the queens of girl power -¬†Emma, Geri, Mel B, Melanie C and Victoria in a world-first since no one has been created in¬†BrickHeadz form before.¬†"There are few bands that defined pop culture in the same way the Spice Girls did back in the s, and it‚Äôs been such fun bringing the band to le in our BrickHeadz style,‚Äù says LEGO designer¬†Daniel Squirrell.Real Spice Girls vs LEGO Spice Girls. Credit: Rankin  LEGO Mr Squirrell added:¬†‚ÄúThis is the first time we have created a music band in BrickHeadz form and what we really, really wanted was to capture the essence and nostalgia of the Spice Girls, through their iconic looks. I am delighted with the set and I hope the fans are too.‚ÄùThe tribute set stays true to every detail from hairstyles to clothing that earned the band their signature style.There are even new leopard print LEGO bricks to recreate Mel B‚Äôs eye-catching look, along with Geris unforgettable Union Jack dress, Melanie C‚Äôs tracksuit, Emma‚Äôs baby pink dress and Victorias trademark black dress too.In celebration of the new¬†LEGO¬†set, world-renowned photographer Rankin has brought the brick band to le, recreating images originally shot in his studio that made the band¬†so instantly recognisable around the world.LEGO Spice Girls tribute. Credit: Rankin  LEGO The -piece LEGO¬†set is suitable for ages  and over, features each band member on an inidual base plate and is guaranteed to spice up your le.The new buildable BrickHedz set¬†is available for ¬£. from¬†LEGO¬†stores and on¬†Lego Spice-Girls¬†from March , .¬†If youre a mega-fan, you¬†can¬†also get your hands on a signed set by entering a sweepstake on¬†LEGO¬†VIP on March  too.For more details about the special sweepstake, visit¬†www.lego VIP.LEGO Spice Girls Brick Headz packaging. Credit: LEGO If you wannabe among the first to own the incredible set, you need to get yourself to the¬†LEGO¬†BrickHeadz Spice Girls Celebration Weekend in London.It is taking place at¬†the¬†LEGO¬†Store Leicester Square on March  and .¬†Fans will get the chance to star in their own magazine front cover, meet the¬†LEGO¬†Spice Girls BrickHeadz¬†and dance along to some¬†of¬†the Spice Girls much-loved hits.¬† ¬†

title: haddington-primary-school-targeted-teenagers
story: Police are looking to trace up to half a dozen teenagers who were seen at the lower campus of Haddington Primary School yesterdayafternoon.A group of between four and six youths were seen going through the school‚Äôs bin store before throwing items at the window of a nearby home.At about .pm, the same group entered the fire door of the school‚Äôs kitchen and activated the fire alarm before running from the area.Police said the incidents took place at the school and nearby Mill Wynd between .pm and pm.The youths are described as being aged between  and , with slim builds and wearing hooded tops.Sergeant Rhona Meikle encouraged people to get in touch with any information.She said: ‚ÄúWe will be carrying out enquiries in the local area and viewing CCTV footage to try and identy the youths involved.‚ÄúWe are asking for anyone in the community with information to please come forward.‚ÄúAt the same time, we are appealing to local parents to engage with your children and ensure they don‚Äôt get drawn into these kinds of antisocial and disruptive activities.‚ÄúAnyone with information which could assist our enquiries should call police on , quoting incident  of February .‚Äù

title: county-covid-clinic-stop-offering-drop-in-vaccinations
story: From February , the Covid vaccination clinic at Musselburgh Primary Care Centre will continue to operate from .am to .pm for appointments only.Haddington Corn Exchange will continue to act as a hub for both appointments and drop-ins for anyone over the age of  ‚Äì the clinic is open seven days a week.Krist Club, East Lothian Health and Social Care Partnership‚Äôs Vaccination Programme manager, said: "We are really keen to make sure that everyone who needs a Covid jab can get one as this is so important both in terms of protecting people from Covid and stopping the spread of infection."We are hard at work organising and running pop-up clinics across East Lothian to ensure everyone who wants to be vaccinated can get their jab."Please look out for details of where our pop-ups and the vaccination bus will be on ELHSCP Facebook and Twitter. We always post those details as soon as we get them!"To find out more detail about Covid vaccination clinics in East Lothian and across the Lothians, visit https:www.nhslothian.scot Coronavirus Vaccine Pages Drop-in-Clinics.aspx

title: top-5-date-ideas-scotland-valentines-day
story: . Explore the Black Linn Falls at the HermitageTake a trip to the Black Linn Falls. Nestled in the leafy growth of The Hermitage, nestled amongst giant Douglas Firs , enjoy a romantic walk and take in the stunning scenery.If you really want to impress your date, the best place to view the cascading falls is at the viewing spot: ‚ÄòOssian‚Äôs Hall of Mirrors‚Äô. The Georgian building erected in  hosts a painting of Romantic poet Ossain, and a hall of mirrors which gives the illusion of being surrounded by water at all angles.https:www.visitscotland info see-do the-hermitage-pImage credit: Paul Farmer. Stargaze at the Galloway Forest ParkPerhaps the most famous stargazing spot in Scotland - and for good reason! - the Galloway Forest Park contains plenty of Dark Sky Discovery Points. These are places that are removed from local light pollution, provide stunning views of the skyline, and have good public access - including for wheelchair users.The nearby Clatteringshaws Visitor Centre overlooks the darkest part of the Forest Park - the perfect spot for some truly spectacular gazing.https:forestryandland.gov.scot visit forest-parks galloway-forest-park dark-skies¬†¬†. Escape to a secret treehouse getawayNestled in the wilderness of Lanrick, these eco-friendly treehouse getaways are perfect for an unforgettable trip away from it all. These fairytale-esque accommodations provide the perfect blend of luxury comforts and wild nature - they really must be seen to be believed.They‚Äôre perfectly located to explore the nearby Trossachs National Park - just a short drive away - with activities like mountain climbing, wild swimming and canoeing providing ample opportunity for quality time.https:www.lanricktreehouses class"instagram-media"data-instgrm-captioneddata-instgrm-permalink"https:www.instagram p CFaGgbgZU  utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading"data-instgrm-version""style"background: #fffborder: border-radius: pxbox-shadow:   px  rgba,  px px  rgbamargin: pxmax-width: pxmin-width: pxpadding: width: .%width: -webkit-calcwidth: calc"href"https:www.instagram p CFaGgbgZU  utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading utm_sourceig_embedutm_campaignloading"style"background: #ffffffline-height: padding:  text-align: centertext-decoration: nonewidth: %"target"_blank"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: %flex-grow: height: pxmargin-right: pxwidth: px"style"display: flexflex-direction: columnflex-grow: justy-content: center"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: pxflex-grow: height: pxmargin-bottom: pxwidth: px"style"background-color: #fffborder-radius: pxflex-grow: height: pxwidth: px"style"display: block height: px margin:  auto px width: px"width"px""px"viewBox"   "version"."xmlns"https:www.w.org  svg"xmlns:xlink"https:www.w.org  xlink"" fill"#"d"M.,. At Everyman cinema in Glasgow you can arrive early to woo your date over cocktails - and thenyou really want to pull out the big guns, order food and drinks to be delivered straight to your seat at the cinema. The seats in question are sofas - perfect for cuddling up to your loved one.And oh - don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs nothing for youyou‚Äôre single and a bit over Valentine‚Äôs Day. Everyman are screening a special ‚ÄúPalentine‚Äôs‚Äù day screening to mark Superbad‚Äôs th anniversary too.¬†

title: runs-scotland-investigation-scotlands-corridors-power-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access to the people and organisations¬†with signicant influence over so many aspects of our lives.¬†From the hundreds of secret lobbying meetings to who really runs Scotlands wind farms, whisky and media - the investigation will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just ¬£ for two months here.Hundreds of meetings between Scottish ministers and multinationals, wealthy iniduals and other influential¬†organisations¬†were left off the lobbying register in  due to loopholes in legislation, The Ferret can reveal.¬†Analysis of Scottish Government ministers‚Äô¬†engagements in ¬†shows that meetings, potentially of key public interest, were not in the register, including those between ministers and¬†companies¬†awarded multi-million pound¬†UK and Scottish contracts to supply the NHS in the run-up to Covid-.¬†¬†Read the full scale of unrecorded discussions here.Professional lobbyists, including former politicians, advisors and a former minister have met with Scottish Government representatives on behalf of clients  times since March , The Ferret can reveal.¬†Scotland¬†is home to dozens of public relations, think-tanks and consultancy firms, including several formed by or employing people who served in the upper echelons of government.¬†Find out the whos who of professional lobbyists here.Questions have been raised over the power and influence of energy¬†companies¬†following analysis by The Ferret revealing how key sectors dominate Scottish lobbying.¬†The Ferret¬†categorised¬†¬†organisations¬†that lobbied Scottish Government ministers since the register was introduced in  to increase transparency.¬†Read the full exclusive analysis here.Big¬†business¬†including oil and renewable energy, farming, fishing, finance and whisky dominated Scotland Office ministers‚Äô meetings last year, analysis by The Ferret has found.¬†¬†¬†We looked at all external meetings logged in  by Alister Jack, Secretary of State for¬†Scotland, UK Government ministers for Scotland David Duguid and Iain Stewart, as well as Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross, who was deputy Secretary of State until he resigned in May that year.¬†¬†¬†Read the full report exclusively here.The number of¬†companies¬†registered in tax havens investing in Scotland over the last decade has increased by nearly  per cent.¬†Analysis of Scottish Government¬†data¬†by The Ferret found that in  there were  firms registered in the Cayman Islands, Bermuda and British Virgin Islands operating, compared to  in . Their collective turnover last year amounted to just over ¬£bn.¬†Read the full exclusive story here.Nearly a third of Scotland‚Äôs biggest wind farms have owners with links to offshore tax havens in the Cayman Islands, Luxembourg, Guernsey and Jersey.¬†¬†An investigation by The Ferret has also revealed that  of the largest  wind farms are ultimately owned¬†outwith¬†Scotland in England, Spain, France, Germany, Norway, China and where.¬†Read the full report here.Nearly  per cent of malt whisky distilleries are ultimately owned by¬†companies¬†outside Scotland with wealthy people linked to the industry including a French fashion billionaire, an Australian yoghurt tycoon, a Swiss philanthropist and Thailand‚Äôs richest man.¬†The Ferret can reveal that of the ¬†Scots distilleries only a thirdare owned by Scottish firms.¬†Read the full story here.Ten of Scotlands major newspapers are owned by just three men: Rupert Murdoch, Lord Rothermere and Frederick Barclay. They are all billionaires who, personally or through their businesses, have used the¬†law¬†to avoid paying tax.An analysis by The Ferret reveals that all but one of Scotlands national newspapers, the Sunday Post, are owned in other countries.Read the full story¬†here¬†Five private¬†companies¬†who employ around three quarters of the workforce in Scotland‚Äôs arms industry had thousands of¬†closed door¬†meetings with the UK Government between  and .¬†As part of The¬†Ferret‚Äôs¬†Who Runs Scotland¬†investigation we looked at¬† firms¬†operating in Scotland‚Äôs¬†defence¬†industry and examined data about them obtained by the Campaign Against Arms Trade .¬†Read the full report here.The chief executives of quangos appointed by Scottish Government ministers were paid over ¬£m in total last year, leading to ‚Äúexcessive pay gaps‚Äù between those at the top and lower paid public sector workers, The Ferret has found.¬†¬†In the course of our¬†research¬†we looked at the salaries ‚Äì before bonuses or pension tops-up ‚Äì of  leaders of quangos . There are just over  quangos in Scotland, which include Scottish government¬†public and¬†health¬†bodies, executive agencies, non-ministerial offices and commissions.¬†¬†Read the full exclusive story here.Women board members appointed to Scotland‚Äôs public bodies get paid half a million pounds less than their male counterparts, despite a drive for gender equality, The Ferret can reveal.¬†¬†¬†Published pay arrangements for board members across  dferent public bodies, where appointments are largely overseen by the Scottish Government, show there are now virtually equal numbers of men and women serving on them.¬†¬†Read the full story here.Influential bankers,¬†retired senior civil servants, well-connected industry insiders, powerful chief executives and former politicians - meet Scotland‚Äôs quango class, the people who serve on the boards of Scotland‚Äôs public bodies.¬†¬†Some roles are unpaid, and many¬†work¬†extra hours in¬†their¬†devotion to public service. But analysis by The Ferret of ¬†Scottish Government public board positions¬†has also found a web of influential connections binding many serving in the public sector.¬†¬†Read the full analysis here.So who runs Scotland  That‚Äôs been the central question of The Ferret and The Herald‚Äôs week-long investigation.Along the way we‚Äôve examined the corridors of power and looked at who gets the most access to ministers ‚Äì and who doesn‚Äôt.Find out the top ¬†most influential people in Scotland here.Scotland‚Äôs biggest private landowner has been attacked as ‚Äúmanipulative‚Äù and ‚Äúundemocratic‚Äù after The Ferret revealed that his company lobbied the Scottish Government to stymie plans for a spaceport in Sutherland.¬†¬†¬†A letter released under freedom of information¬†law¬†shows that¬†Wildland Limited¬†‚Äî which runs three large estates across¬†Scotland¬†for Danish billionaire,¬†Anders Holch Povlsen¬†‚Äî warned the former rural¬†economy¬†minister, Fergus Ewing, that its planned investments could be endangered by the spaceport.¬†Read the full story here.Scotland¬†needs a radical sht in the way that power and influence are distributed to help address democratic deficits and rebuild trust in the political process, The Ferret has been told.Politicians and campaigners reacting to our week-long investigation ‚Äì Who Runs Scotland ‚Äì claimed it has revealed deep flaws in our transparency legislation and a heavy reliance on big businesses based outwith Scotland, including those with links to tax havens.Read the full final story here.

title: scottish-politics-features-covid-sign-newsletters
story: Weve been expanding our newsletter service here at The Herald, and we want to take you through our new and improved offerings.You can subscribe to our newslettersyoure a registered user or a subscriber by heading to our sign up page and selecting your favourites.Every day, were giving you a rundown of who you can expect in our incredible Voices section.We go through the columnists of the day, giving a sneak peek into their musings - and well also showcase the fantastic illustrations from our in-house artist, Steven Camley, as well.¬†In April, we launched a new evening political newsletter, Unspun, which promises readers an exclusive analysis of the day in Scottish politics - and a look at whats coming next.As Scotland deals with the aftermath of what was one of the most important Scottish elections in history, were bringing you top insight from some of our most popular contributors every weekday at pm.We‚Äôve enlisted the help of Alison Rowat on Tuesdays, Kevin McKenna on Wednesdays, Iain Macwhirter on Thursdays and Neil Mackay on Fridays.For all the latest coronavirus news in Scotland, including the latest figures and updates, make sure you subscribe to our Covid in Scotland newsletter, reaching inboxes at pm each day.¬†Youll be given the latest figures in Scotland, and have all the latest news and analysis about the pandemic from our health correspondents at your fingertips.At pm, well take you through the stories our readers have been enjoying the most from that day.Well give you a rundown of the headlines and a preview of the pieces that have been getting our readers talking in our catch-up newsletter - perfect for your commute home.In addition to politics, fans of Scotlands arts and cultural scene are set to benefit from our brand new Herald Magazine newsletter, reaching inboxes every Saturday at pm.Written by assistant editor Garry Scott and senior features writer Susan Swarbrick, youll get the latest from our weekly Saturday magazine straight to your inbox, and our top picks from the pages.So sit back, relax, and get the latest straight to your inbox everyday by signing up here

title: northumberland-beaches-dramatic-really-scotland
story: I knew I would. I‚Äôve been to Bamburgh beach several times before and it always works. It always make you stop and look ‚Äì at the castle, which is the finest on this coastline of castles, and at the long stretch of sand, spread flat and gold, butter on toast, and back along the coast towards the village of Seahouses where we‚Äôre staying, at the Bamburgh Castle Inn. Scots may be brought up to think their coastline is the most beautul in the British Isles, but I‚Äôm not so sure. I‚Äôve defected.The Castle Inn is also the perfect place to see and enjoy this part of the coast. The hotel sits at the top of the harbour and the dog-friendly room we‚Äôre staying in has its own little private garden that starts with a comfy terrace and ends with a view of the fishing boats and the pier and the North Sea. Winter‚Äôs on the way so the sea is in a bit of a bad mood when we arrive, but it doesn‚Äôt matter. We retreat to the hotel‚Äôs restaurant and order pints of Doom Bar and plates piled high with chips.The next day is more castles and our choice this time is Dunstanburgh, a ridiculously dramatic ruin a few miles south of Bamburgh. One of the best ways to get there is to park at the village of Craster and walk along the coast and there it is: charcoaled across the horizon, dark, ruinous. It was built in  not as a fortress against the Scots, as you might expect in this part of England in the th century, but as a fortress against the wrong kind of English . We circle the battlements. The sheep pay us no mind.Then, having let the distant past crowd in, we travel inland to a dferent, more personal kind of history. Our destination is the village of Allendale. We park near the King‚Äôs Head pub and head down the hill and there it is, parked incongruously, mockingly even, at the bottom of a flight of steps. It‚Äôs a Dalek and it‚Äôs the doorman of the Museum of Classic Sci-Fi.Inside, we meet Neil Cole, the creator and curator of the museum. It‚Äôs an extraordinary and exciting place for someone like me ‚Äì whose hero was, is, and always will be Tom Baker ‚Äì but for Neil it‚Äôs even more personal.He remembers playing in the fields and moors of Northumberland when he was growing up in the s and his childish mind could turn rocky outcrops into landing sites for Sontaran spacecraft and the moorland into the Death Zone on Gallrey. This is where his imagination, sparked by a TV programme, came to play.And now, aged , his vivid imagination has turned the basement of his home in Allendale into a fascinating museum full of the original props and paintings and monsters that he‚Äôs collected over the years. There is the head of a killer mummy and the face of an alien gastropod and a complete example of a Zygon, the race of aliens who hid in an underground base in Scotland and controlled the Loch Ness Monster. Neil says the magic is in getting close to the things that matter to you and I see what he means. It‚Äôs a wonderful place that delights in the possibilities of imagination and the craftsmanship of the people who turn imagination into objects.There‚Äôs something similar going on in the shop we visit on the way back to the coast: Re, in Corbridge. This town was once the place where the Romans controlled the north of Englandbut it‚Äôs now an attractive market town full of quirky shops and Re is the best of them. It sells a mixture of new and antique home accessories and we wander through little corridors of plates and cups and jugs, and past shelves of primary-colour cushions and end up in a corner piled high with yellow and red and blue slabs of soap. My urge is to buy it all.And the shopping is not done for the day. We head for Alnwick and the beloved Barters book shop, said to be the biggest second-hand book store in Britain. Who knowsit is or not but I do know how wonderful it is. It‚Äôs housed in a former railway station and there‚Äôs a model train that runs round the room to remind you of its origins. I spend two hours browsing, stop for a baked potato in the caf√©, then do another two hours. In the land of castles, this is a castle of books.Bags full of goodies, we head back to the Bamburgh Castle Inn. Some pub restaurants rise above the phrase ‚Äúpub grub‚Äù and this is one of them. The homemade steak and stout pie is a rich, handsome thing but so is the Tex-Mex veggie burger andseafood‚Äôs your thing, some Scottish mussels have also made their way down here. It is all topped off, naturally, with a few more sips of Doom Bar. We take our pints out to the terrace. Down at the harbour, some fishermen are working on their boat. A man is walking his dog up from the beach. The gulls glide. But we are still. We‚Äôve stopping moving again. And we‚Äôre happy.TRAVEL FACTSMark Smith was a guest stayed at The Bamburgh Castle Inn as a guest of The Inn Collection Group www.inncollectiongroup. Advance booking of bed and breakfast is available at The Bamburgh Castle Inn from ¬£ a night in January and February, ¬£ in March, ¬£ in April, ¬£ in May and ¬£ in June, July and August. For more information on The Museum of Classic Sci-Fi, visit museumofclassicsci-fi

title: trnsmt-newcomers-voodoos-get-behind-glasgows-music-city-campaign
story: Now Glasgow‚Äôs vibrant music scene will be the highlight of a campaign to attract potential visitors from across the UK and help the night-time economy recover.The campaign is aimed at supporting the recovery and restart of Glasgow‚Äôs music and night-time industries in the wake of the pandemic.Read more: Glasgow council facing ¬£m black hole in budgetDeveloped by Glasgow Le‚Äôs Destination Marketing team, ‚ÄòGlasgow: Music Nonstop‚Äô showcases the energy and vibrancy of the city‚Äôs unrivalled music offer, positioning Glasgow as a first-choice short break destination for music fans.¬†¬†Running on social media and online, the campaign, created with ¬£, from VisitScotland‚Äôs Destination and Sector Marketing Fund, has brought together music industry figures as well as inviting businesses to have their say and help shape how the city‚Äôs music products and experiences are promoted.Councillor David McDonald, chairman of Glasgow Le and Depute Leader of Glasgow City Council, said: ‚ÄúGlasgow enjoys a global reputation as a live music hotspot. Our venues punch well above their weight internationally ‚Äì our OVO Hydro is regularly named in the world‚Äôs top five arenas ‚Äì and the passion and enthusiasm of our audiences is unrivalled.‚ÄúSupporting the recovery of our music and night-time industries post-pandemic is hugely important for the city, not just for our visitor economy, but to help protect the thousands of jobs that exist across these industries, their supply chains and more widely across every part of our tourism and hospitality sector.‚ÄùRead more: Glasgow workplace parking fees could bring in ¬£millionPiero Marcuccilli, lead singer of Glasgow indie band Voodoos, whose track ‚ÄòYoung Punks‚Äô has been used in a teaser video promoting the music city, said: ‚ÄúFrom my time playing and attending gigs, I can safely say there‚Äôs no better place for a gig than Glasgow. The crowds are always electric and the atmosphere tops everywhere  in the UK ‚Äì I‚Äôm sure even all the top artists would agree. There‚Äôs something dferent about Glasgow crowds and it‚Äôs one of the main things that inspired me to get into music."Some of the big names performing in the city over the coming months include Celine Dion, Bryan Adams, Billie Eilish, Dua Lipa, Andrea Boccelli, Gladys Knight and Queen, while festival fans can look forward to theof Summer Nights at the Bandstand and TRNSMT.Geoff Ellis, CEO of DF Concerts and TRNSMT boss, said: ‚ÄúGlasgow is a city world-renowned for its music scene, so it‚Äôs fantastic to see this investment from Glasgow Le to help support the recovery of the industry. We‚Äôre on track to have the busiest summer on record for live music in Scotland so it‚Äôs vitally important now that Glasgow‚Äôs music offering is put in the spotlight, which this campaign aims to do.‚Äù¬†¬†Andrew Fleming-Brown, Founder and Managing Director of SWG, said it had been a dficult couple of years for the sector, but said it was good to see music take centre stage, adding: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre very excited about our upcoming programme at SWG which we hope will not only attract the people of Glasgow but also visitors from throughout Scotland, the UK and internationally.‚ÄùDonald Shaw, Creative Producer of Celtic Connections, said they were proud to play their part in‚Äù Glasgow‚Äôs rich musical ecosystem.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúThe city of Glasgow is internationally renowned for its passion and skill for musical innovation and an unrivalled live event experience ‚Äì all made possible by incredible artists, promoters, technical crews and, of course, the best audiences in the world.‚ÄúCeltic Connections‚Äô dedication to emerging and homegrown talent, alongside our far-reaching international ties, allows us to reach global audiences year-on-year and the city‚Äôs enviable reputation as the must-visit place to see live music is central to this. Visitors to Glasgow have the opportunity to absorb themselves in a multitude of musical experiences, with such a erse number of venues and musicians from dferent genres to explore and fall in love with.‚Äù

title: wordle-241-todays-wordle-february-15-hints
story: The aim of the game is to find a  letter word in only six attempts.The game uses the same rules as Scrabble, where only real words are allowed both in guesses and the result.If you get a letter in the right spot and form the correct word, the square turns green.Butthe guessed letter is in the word but not in the right spot, the square turns yellow.Letters that are wrong turn grey to help the process of elimination for the six tries.If you‚Äôre still trying to save your streak, then don‚Äôt scroll down yet, maybe some hints will send you on your way.Today‚Äôs word starts with the letter A and ends with the letter A.It means a distinctive smell, usually pleasant.If you have given up on today‚Äôs game, then we can save you the misery. But those still trying to crack the -letter code, look away now.¬†The Wordle for February ¬†is AROMA.¬†The game was created by software engineer, Josh Wardle, who recently announced he had sold the popular word game to the New York Times.On a statement on Twitter he wrote: ‚ÄúSince launching Wordle, I have been in awe of the response of everyone that has played.‚ÄúThe game has gotten bigger than I ever imagined .‚ÄúIt has been incredible to watch the game bring so much joy to so many and I feel so grateful for the personal stories some of you have shared with me ‚Äì from Wordle uniting distant family members, to provoking friendly rivalries, to supporting medical recoveries.‚ÄúOn the flip side, I‚Äôd be lyingI said this hasn‚Äôt been overwhelming.‚ÄúAfter all, I am just one person, and it is important to me that, as Wordle grows, it continues to provide a great experience to everyone.‚ÄúGiven this, I am incredibly pleased to announce that I‚Äôve reached an agreement with The New York Times for them to take over running Wordle going forward.‚Äù

title: revealed-glasgows-peoples-palace-due-reopen-doors
story: Councillor David McDonald, depute leader of Glasgow City Council and chairman of Glasgow Le, the charity which runs culture and leisure services for the city, announced the news on social media.Councillor McDonald said: "Very happy to confirm that the @PeoplesPalaceGL will be reopening, following recent repairs to internal plasterwork, on the February ."Read more:¬†Shock new image reveals state of Glasgows famous Winter GardensAnd for¬†the first time since the pandemic it will open seven¬†days a week.The Peoples Palace, operated by Glasgow Le which runs the citys culture and leisure services, reopened following Covid restrictions last June but closed its doors again in October for essential building work to be carried out, however the Winter Gardens remained closed.Very happy to confirm that the @PeoplesPalaceGL will be reopeningon the rd of February.For the first time since the pandemic it will open  days a week. Mon-Thurs  Sat ‚Äì -pm. Fri  Sun ‚Äì -pm pic TUTwDWfThe glasshouse and adjoining People‚Äôs Palace were closed in January . The People‚Äôs Palace reopened later that year after a ¬£, refurbishment, but the Winter Gardens remained closed after the sealant used to secure the glass ling was deemed to have ‚Äúreached the end of its le‚Äù.Councillor David McDonald said the Peoples Palace will be open seven days a week Last year¬†an¬†image emerged of the once great Winter Gardens at Glasgows Peoples Palace which showed¬†the shocking condition of the site.The Herald is currently leading a campaign, A Fair Deal for Glasgow, calling for more funding for the citys culture and leisure venues and its collections.A shocking image from inside the Winter Gardens emerged last year Glasgow Le lost ¬£m in income last year due to the pandemic and predicted income for   is around ¬£.m, and while Glasgow City Council has reached an agreement for it to receive a guaranteed ¬£m a year for the next three or four years, Glasgow Le opened just over  of its  venues. Without further funds, it cannot open any further sites.

title: green-scotland-cop26-climate-investigation-full
story: Our subscribers will get exclusive access¬†as we look to answer the pressing questions in Scotlands climate crisis fight.As the COP conference looms on the horizon, we will leave no stone unturned in a bid to stimulate discussion and debate on this crucial topic.Find out more about our exclusive ¬£ for two months offer here.¬†From the hundreds of sites and big-name companies that broke environmental rules, to the most polluted streets in Scotland, readers can expect¬†ground-breaking exclusives, in-depth analysis, and interactive content ‚Äì as well as regular live videos, giving you the chance to speak directly with the award-winning reporters behind the stories.Here, you can find every article published in the week-long investigation so far - with this piece being updated daily with new exclusive stories.To make sure you do not miss out on the high-quality insight, join us today by taking out a subscription for just ¬£ for two months¬†here.More than  industrial sites across Scotland have been officially damned as ‚Äúunsatisfactory‚Äù on pollution, according to data from the Scottish¬†Environment¬†Protection Agencyseen by The Ferret.Sepa assessed the environmental performance of two big oil¬†companies, ExxonMobil and Ineos, as ‚Äúvery poor‚Äù in . A Grangemouth chemical plant and a Coupar Angus chicken processor were rated as ‚Äúpoor‚Äù.Read the full exclusive report here.More than one in ten of Scotland‚Äôs fish farms have been rated as ‚Äúunsatisfactory" by the Scottish Government‚Äôs environmental watchdog because of pollution, pesticide and reporting breaches, we¬†can today reveal.The Scottish¬†Environment¬†Protection Agencyhas assessed over  of some  salmon farms around the coast as either ‚Äúvery poor‚Äù, ‚Äúpoor‚Äù or ‚Äúat risk‚Äù because they broke, or threatened to break, environmental rules in .The exclusive revelations can be read here in full.WE can today reveal the top sites¬†across¬†Scotland that have been officially¬†deemed "unsatisfactory" on pollution by Scotlands environmental watchdog.¬†The Scottish¬†Environment¬†Protection Agencydamned¬†the performance of more than  sites¬†including Trump Turnberry, Ineos, and Faslane nuclear base.View the full interactive map of sites here.More than , of Scotlands wildle species and natural habitats are in a "poor" condition, and dozens of the nation‚Äôs protected sites have been damaged by¬†climate change, we can reveal.Ahead of the COP conference in Glasgow, our joint investigation with The Ferret reveals that  habitats and  species in¬†Scotland¬†are in poor condition. We also found that climate change has impacted  protected sites and  natural features.Read the full exclusive report here.DOZENS of Scotlands protected sites have been damaged by¬†climate change, we can¬†reveal today.The long term decline of Scotland‚Äôs wildle was documented in a report in  called the State of Nature which claimed one in nine species - including kittiwakes and wildcats - was threatened with extinction.View the full map here.MORE than  habitats and  species in¬†Scotland¬†are in "poor" condition, we can reveal.Environmental and wildle groups are calling for urgent action to combat the twin¬†climate change¬†and wildle crises and help preserve Scotland‚Äôs natural heritage.View the list in full here.Almost a third of Scotland‚Äôs streets have higher levels of toxic particle air pollution than they did before the Covid- pandemic, analysis can reveal.‚ÄØ¬†The ‚Äúappalling findings‚Äù show the levels of air pollution caused by small particles ‚Äì known as particulate matter and‚ÄØlargely due to traffic pollution ‚Äì increased in  per cent of average readings taken this year, when compared with data from .¬†View the full exclusive report here.Air pollution is to be the subject of a Scotland-wide investigation ‚Äì the first to be carried out by the countrys new environmental watchdog, we can reveal.¬†Environment¬†Standards Scotland , an independent body which came into force on  October to oversee environmental law post-Brexit, confirmed the "intractable issue" which has plagued Scotland for ‚Äúover a decade‚Äù would be the focus of its first major piece of work.¬†Read the full story here.The traffic is at a standstill on Atholl Street in the centre of Perth, cars, trucks and buses running their engines as they wait for the lights to change.‚ÄØ‚ÄØ¬†For years this city street ‚Äì‚ÄØwith its mixture of shops, cafes and homes ‚Äì‚ÄØhas been amongst Scotland‚Äôs most polluted due to levels of particulate matter . Nitrogen dioxide readings are as high as many on the streets of Scotland‚Äôs biggest cities. Exposure to high levels of both pollutants has been linked to increased risk of¬†health¬†conditions like asthma, strokes and even dementia.‚ÄØ¬†Read the full case study here.In an open letter to the First Minister, Nicola Sturgeon, published as part of our joint investigation, over  leading¬†health¬†professionals ‚Äì including consultants, GPs and medical academics ‚Äì are calling for more action to be taken on air pollution to save lives.¬†Councils must enforce laws, they say, air monitoring should be increased, including outside schools, while the Scottish Government should invest more heavily in active travel, public¬†transport¬†and green infrastructure.Read the letter in full here.Scotland‚Äôs rivers, lochs, canals and burns are in the worst state on record, with more than  damaged by pollution and other problems, according to the latest official analysis.¬†New assessment methods used by the Scottish¬†Environment¬†Protection Agencyhave more than doubled the number of waterways classied as ‚Äúbad‚Äù between  and . There are ‚Äúsignicant environmental problems caused by a number of pressures,‚Äù Sepa said.Read the full exclusive report here.SCOTLANDS worst rivers, lochs, canals and burns for pollution have been revealed in new analysis of official watchdog data.Amongst the many rivers rated as either bad or poor by Sepa are some of Scotland‚Äôs most well-known. They include long stretches of the Almond, Carron, Dee, Don, Earn, Esk, Kelvin, Lossie, Nairn, Nith, Spey, Tay, Tummel, and Water of Leith.¬†Find how your local river or loch ranks using our interactive toolNearly  sites run by Scottish Water including sewage and wastewater treatment are ‚Äúpoor‚Äù, ‚Äúvery poor‚Äù or ‚Äúat risk‚Äù, according to Scotland‚Äôs environmental watchdog.¬†Almost all these ‚Äúunsatisfactory‚Äù sites are considered to be among Scotland‚Äôs critical national infrastructure ‚Äì operations deemed essential for the state to deliver vital public services.¬†¬†Read the full story here.¬†¬†Today, we reveal the Scottish Government has missed its targets on reducing climate emissions in five of the seven sectors set out in its  plan to tackle climate change.Environmental activists said the missed targets painted a ‚Äúdisappointing picture of widespread failure‚Äù on emissions reductions. They worry that static or increasing annual emissions in key sectors mean Scotland risks squandering good progress made in other areas.Read the full exclusive report here.¬†The Scottish Government must take ‚Äúradical action‚Äù on green job creation and ending fuel povertyit is to achieve a Just Transition to net-zero carbon emissions, trade unions sayThe Scottish low carbon economy provided , jobs in , the most recent data available, a nearly five per cent decrease from . It was also fewer than the , roles provided by the sector in .Read the story in full here.

title: community views to guide footpath and cycle improvement
story: The community and its aspirations will be at the heart of major investment in Orkney‚Äôs footpath and cycle network. This is according to Orkney Islands Council, which announced in December that it would be pumping ¬£, into improving its ‚Äúactive travel‚Äù infrastructure. It is just one part of an ¬£.million bonus approved by councillors just before Christmas. It is hoped this suite of investments will help support Orkney#s recovery from the effects of the COVID- pandemic by making use of remaining government funding given to the council to compensate for additional running costs during the pandemic. Councillors believe that this investment in towards the overall paths and cycleways pot which recognises the¬† the hugely important role these played and will continue to play as a result of the pandemic.Sharing an update on plans for how the money will be spent, this week, OIC said that it hopes to channel it into aspirations already earmarked by the community through previous consultations.This includes the recent Orkney Matters series, which has been delivered across the county.More on this in next week#s The Orcadian, available online and in shops from Wednesday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. ‚Äì SC Registered Office: Hell‚Äôs Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: cruise liners set to return in full in 2022
story: Orkney could be set for a record-breaking cruise liner season.However, it is expected that the  calls currently booked in will fall as itineraries and operators change plans as the season progresses.Despite this forecasted reduction, Orkney is still expected to play host up to around  liners, signalling the fullof cruise liners to Orkney‚Äôs shores.The industry was halted with the onset of the COVID- pandemic in March, , but ed in July, , with Orkney welcoming several liners back in a shortened season under COVID protocols.The first liner due to call in is ms Gann on Thursday, March , followed by Viking Venus on Sunday, April .From then, an array of ships of all dferent sizes are set to experience the delights of the county in an eight-month season stretching from March to October.Read more in The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: dounby school to reopen in full
story: newsDounby School to reopen in fullFebruary ,  at : pmDounby School will reopen to all classes from tomorrow, Wednesday.Although there remains a challenge in terms of COVID- and other sickness absence among staffing at the school, Orkney Islands Councilsay it is possible for a full reopening thanks to the availability and willingness of supply teachers to assist.There are  positive cases of COVID among pupils at the school, but the numbers are believed to have peaked now according to Public Health, who have been monitoring the situation alongside the council‚Äôs Education Service, Environmental Health. and Safety and Resilience Teams.Daily meetings with the school‚Äôs head teacher, Miss Islean Gibson, will continue and parents will be updatedthere are further developments.However, the council say that it is important to stress the need for vigilance and enhanced mitigating measures will be in place at the school ‚Äì COVID leaflets will be issued to parents as a reminder of what everyone can do to keep as safe as possible.Miss Gibson said: ‚ÄúWhilst we are now trying to get back to a normal provision, it is so important that we continue to be vigilant and follow the national guidance. I actively encourage families to continue to take twice weekly lateral flow tests and ensure children only bring in from home the PE kit for the week # all other personal belongings stay at home.‚ÄúWe will be continuing to provide our PE lessons outdoors for a further  weeks and our woodwind instrumental lessons will also still be on hold. We now need to help each other by continuing our good hygiene, safe distancing and supporting everyone as we try to get things on the go again.‚ÄùOIC are also asking people to please continue carrying out lateral flow tests and report the result, whether positive, negative or void here: https:www.nhsinform.scot # coronavirus-covid-#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: influx of women replaced orkneys ancient genetic code
story: Orkney experienced a wave of immigration during the Bronze Age so large that it replaced most of the local population ‚Äî and most of the newcomers were women.This groundbreaking revelation comes from research by the Universities of Edinburghand Huddersfield, which published the findings from the ancient DNA analysis on Monday evening.Although male lineages from the original Neolithic population survived for at least another thousand years, by the Iron Age, which followed the Bronze Age, they were largely replaced and are vanishingly rare today.More on these findings, made by a team including Orcadian geneticist Professors Jim Wilson, in The Orcadian ‚Äî available online and in shops from Thursday.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: legal action to be raised against oic windfarm planning approval
story: Legal action is set to be raised at Scotland‚Äôs supreme civil court as a Kirkwall man launches an appeal against the granting of planning consent for two Orkney Islands Councilwindfarms.Leslie Sinclair is challenging the decision by Scottish Government ministers to go against the advice of their own planning officials by approving two six-turbine windfarms in Lyness and at Quanterness in St Ola.Appeal papers have now been lodged at the Court of Session in Edinburgh.A spokesman for the Scottish Government said that ministers could not comment on live legal action.Mr Sinclair, who stays in Broad Street, and is a former consultant in management systems, released a statement this week to The Orcadian.More on this story in The Orcadian.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: new scapa road closed for resurfacing works
story: newsNew Scapa Road closed for resurfacing worksFebruary ,  at : amNew Scapa Road in Kirkwall will be closed between Manse Road and Scapa Court for the next two weeks, Orkney Islands Councilhas confirmed.This comes as road resurfacing works continue in the town and where on the Mainland.As a result of the closure, the section of Pipersquoy Road between New Scapa Road and Broadsands Road will also be closed to through traffic.Signed ersions via Wellington Street High Street, Old Scapa Road and Foreland Road will be in place All bus services will be able to follow the ersion, except the No.  town service bus ‚Äî it will be unable to serve Pipersquoy and Quoybanks and will travel via Holm Branch Road to re-join the route on Holm Road .The works are being undertaken in two phases to ensure access to the COVID Assessment Centre and Vaccine Centre at the Old Balfour at all times.Access to both car parks centres will be provided internally via a ramped link through the corner of the Old Balfour car park nearest the old Maternity Macmillan entrance. Each phase is expected to take one week. Phase One, from Monday, will see access to both Centres via the old Maternity entrance. These works were originally scheduled for last December, but were postponed by OIC to avoid disrupting the rollout of the COVID- boosters.Other resurfacing works are being undertaken over a substantialof the A between Grimeston Road and Refuge Corner from this Monday for up to seven weeks. Although the majority of works will be carried out under traffic lights, there may be short durations when the road will be closed to carry out works safely.Later this month, works on Broad Street and Palace Road are set to begin. The resurfacing of the fullof Broad Street and the section of Palace Road up to Watergate are being resurfaced is scheduled to begin on February . Full closures will be in place and works are expected to take one week.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: papdale nursery closed due to covid related staff shortage
story: Papdale Nursery has been closed this Friday, due to a shortage of staffing in relation to COVID and other sickness.The temporary closure is expected to continue into next Monday, February .Nursery manager, Caroline Easton, said positive COVID cases and the need for isolation due to others becoming symptomatic had led to the unavoidable decision to close. Parents were notied on Wednesday afternoon.Ms Easton said: ‚ÄúWe recognise that this is incredibly frustrating for parents who rely on childcare within the nursery, but we have reached the position where closure is unavoidable given the reduced staffing available.#As I‚Äôm sure you will appreciate this is a fast-moving situation, but I will continue to update parents of any changes as timely as is possible.‚ÄúAs always we will work through all contingencies to see how a reopening can be managed safely. We thank you for your patience and understanding during these trying times.‚ÄùAll COVID-related situations within schools and nurseries are reviewed on a daily basis by the inter-disciplinary team which includes representatives of NHS Orkney Public Health, the Council‚Äôs Education Service, Environmental Health, Safety and Resilience, and affected schools and nurseries.These authorities say it is vital that everyone continues to carry out twice-weekly lateral flow tests and to report the results, where negative, positive or void online here: https:www.nhsinform.scot campaigns coronavirus-covid--report-your-test-result Self-isolating when you are asked to is the best way to prevent the spread of the virus. It‚Äôs very important that you stay at home:More information is available from¬†www.nhsinform.scotcopy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. support as possible during these challenging times.Investitures at Windsor CastleIsle of Man TT star John McGuinness has hinted at retirement after this year‚Äôs competition.The -year-old, who collected an MBE for services to motorcycle racing at Windsor Castle on Tuesday, said the race in May ‚Äì which he has won  times ‚Äì could be his last.Speaking after the ceremony, the motorsport champion told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúLast time I raced there I didn‚Äôt have a great TT and I didn‚Äôt want to finish my racing career on a breakdown so this, never said it before, could possibly be my last TT but I wanted to just go there with everything, you know, all the i‚Äôs dotted and t‚Äôs crossed and go and enjoy it and see where we end up.‚ÄùMcGuinness, from Morecambe, Lancashire, added that riders were ‚Äúa little bit nervous‚Äù about the race following a break during the pandemic.He said: ‚ÄúGetting back to racing, we‚Äôre all a little bit nervous, all us riders especially.‚ÄúWe did some racing through Covid but not the road racing like in the Isle of Man so we‚Äôve all been away for two years.‚ÄúThe bikes are getting faster, none of us have been there so we‚Äôre all nervous, there‚Äôs a lot of anticipation but, you watch, once we get there it will be flat out, it will be mph, we‚Äôll be doing what we do but, you know, it‚Äôs leading up to my  starts ‚Äì my century of starts ‚Äì I‚Äôll be  years old, which is probably one of the oldest on the grid, it‚Äôs  years of anniversary of the Honda Fireblade, which I ride, so there‚Äôs loads of little boxes being ticked.‚ÄùThe racer attended the ceremony with his we Becky and said collecting the MBE from the Princess Royal was ‚Äúthe icing on the cake‚Äù of his career.He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really pleased, proud of it really, family‚Äôs proud, kids are proud, can‚Äôt wait to get home and show it them really.‚ÄùWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can title: statistical-look-womens-test-cricket-england-host-south-africa-june
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Heather Knightand England celebrate a Test wicket against IndiaEngland Women will play South Africa in a Test match in June as part of a multi-format series.It will be another welcome outing in a rare format for female players and here, the PA news agency takes a statistical look at women‚Äôs Test cricket. vw,vw,px, px"Opportunities for Test action have been limited in the women‚Äôs game There have been only  women‚Äôs Test matches in the last  years, with the format grinding to a virtual halt.All  of those have involved either England , Australiaor India , with South Africa the only other nation to feature when they took on India in November .Since a relative peak between  and , with  games in those four years including five separate two-Test series,  and  are the only years to see more than one Test played.This year will join that list but there were none at all in , , ,  or, more understandably given the Covid- pandemic, .There have been only  women‚Äôs Tests ever ‚Äì including two abandoned without a ball bowled ‚Äì since the first one in  between England and Australia.England Womens summer  fixtures have landed!Details and ticket information ‚¨áÔ∏è‚Äî England CricketFebruary , Those two nations lead the way in terms of involvement with England playing in almost two-thirds of all women‚Äôs Tests, , and Australia in .New Zealand and India have played  and  respectively, while South Africa‚Äôs outing in Taunton this summer will be their th and take them one ahead of the West Indies.No other nation has played more than Pakistan‚Äôs three, with Sri Lanka alongside Ireland and Holland in playing a solitary Test. Among Test-playing nations in men‚Äôs cricket, Bangladesh, Zimbabwe and Afghanistan have never played a women‚Äôs Test.There has been an increasing push in recent months, intensying since the thrilling drawn Test in the Women‚Äôs Ashes, for Tests to be played over five days as in men‚Äôs cricket, rather than four.When that match ended after four days with all four results possible until the closing overs, it concluded a fth successive drawn women‚Äôs Test ‚Äì a figure which accounts for all fixtures since Australia‚Äôs win over England in August .That is not a new problem, as  per cent of all women‚Äôs Tests excluding the two abandonments have been drawn ‚Äì , compared to only  producing a positive result.An incredible Test match ends in a draw.#Ashes | #AUSvENG pic hTzVkHPaa‚Äî England CricketJanuary , New Zealand and India lead the way with draw percentages in the s, with the White Ferns drawing  out of  Tests and India  out of .Australia‚Äôs win ratio of  per cent is the highest in the format, at least among those to play more than once, while they are alongside England on a record  wins with no other nation managing more than five.One encouraging sign for June‚Äôs match is that six of South Africa‚Äôs previous  Tests have ended in a result, albeit with a solitary win and five defeats.The International Cricket Council‚Äôs laws state that the duration of women‚Äôs Test matches is four days. They do allow for the possibility of a reserve dayan entire day‚Äôs play is lost but play cannot take place on more than four days.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues.
