These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Film producer Michael Kuhn Film producer Michael Kuhn said he was ‚Äústirring‚Äù the controversy around whether non-Jewish actors could play Jewish characters in his latest film.The -year-old, who honoured for services to the film industry, said the controversy over his latest picture, Golda, a biopic about Israeli first female PM Golda Meir,¬†was good for publicity.The lead, the character of Meir, who was Jewish, is played by Dame Helen Mirren." data-title"Golda Meir " data--holder"PA Archive" data--notice"PA Archive PA Images" data-credit"PA" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Golda Meir Mr Kuhn said he made the confession to the Princess Royal as he collected his CBE at an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle on Tuesday.The -year-old told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúI just mentioned about the film I‚Äôm finishing now with Helen Mirren and she obviously knew about all the controversy there had been with ‚Äòcan a non-Jew play a Jew‚Äô and I told her I was stirring it as much as I could for publicity and she seemed quite amused by that.‚ÄùActor Dame Maureen Lipman criticised the casting, the Jewish Chronicle reported." data-title"Helen Mirren as Golda Meir" data--holder"PA Media" data--notice"PA Media" data-credit"Jasper Wolf Assemble publicity" data-usage-terms"PICTURE DESK USE ONLY. title: starmer-pm-needs-get-house-order-dirty-russian-cash
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Sir Keir StarmerThe Government needs to ‚Äúget its house in order‚Äùit is serious about tackling ‚Äúdirty money‚Äù from Russia coming into the UK, Keir Starmer has said.The Labour leader also called for the Government to ‚Äúgo now and go hard‚Äù with sanctions against Russia, as he said the Prime Minister shouldall ‚ÄúRussian-linked‚Äù donations to the Conservative party over the last  years.Sir Keir made the comments after the Prime Minister announced a new Economic Crime Bill would ‚Äúhit companies‚Äù laundering Kremlin-linked Russian money through Britain.It comes after Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said UK sanctionsMoscow invades Ukraine would be severe in targeting ‚Äúoligarchs‚Äù and ‚Äúcompanies across Russia‚Äù.Sir Keir said Labour ‚Äústands united‚Äù with the Government against Russian aggression, but also said: ‚ÄúFor a decade, the Tories have not just failed to challenge Russian influence ‚Äì they have enabled it.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúIf Boris Johnson is now serious about tackling Russian dirty money and influence, he should immediately get his own house in order.‚ÄúThat means ing the millions of pounds of Russian-linked cash that has been donated to the Tories and their MPs since he became Prime Minister, and reversing his plans to allow unlimited donations from abroad.‚ÄùSir Keir also called for the Government to take other steps to limit the spread of corrupt cash, including reforming Companies House, creating a register of overseas entities and a register of foreign agents, and bringing forward new counter-espionage laws.In an interview with Channel  News, Sir Keir added: ‚ÄúWe should go now and hard with the sanctions.‚ÄúIt is important, I should say that we stand united with our allies in the face of Russian aggression. It‚Äôs very important we stand united in the United Kingdom in the face of Russian aggression. ‚ÄùConservative MPs were also critical of what they have perceived to be a lack of action on honing in on Russian money being invested in the UK.Bob Seely, a member of the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee , said Britain was ‚Äúa decade behind the times‚Äù on the threat posed by Russian financial influence.We need a long-term and coherent plan and a strategy to deal with a dangerous world. Our states need to understand how neo-authoritarian states use the full spectrum of state power military, economic, energy, espionage, political, etc. We are not there yet.  ‚Äî Bob Seely MPFebruary , The Isle of Wight MP told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúOn Russia, we have known about this problem for years.‚ÄúThe problem is that the front line with Ukraine is the border, the front line with Germany is the gas pipeline ‚Äì and the front line with the UK is the City of London.‚ÄúWe need to be wiser about how the Putin regime acts and the potential threat to our institutions and values, and how we can protect them against a potential tsunami of questionable money.‚ÄùMr Seely also said any legislation should be widely targeted enough to incorporate the growing threat posed by China.FAC chairman Tom Tugendhat said it was time to clean out money from British politics that had originated in Russia.‚ÄúFrankly, get it out and get it out now,‚Äù he told Times Radio.There was cross-party agreement that the changes being proposed in the Government‚Äôs economic crime legislation had been needed well before the crisis with Ukraine developed.Senior Labour MP Chris Bryant, who is also an FAC member, told PA: ‚ÄúThis should have been in place before this whole saga, not after.‚ÄúTalk about the horse having bolted.‚ÄùMr Bryant said warnings about Russian money had come from the Foreign Affairs Committee in  with its Moscow‚Äôs Gold report, as well as ‚Äôs Intelligence and Security Committee report on Russian influence in Britain‚Äôs democracy.He added: ‚ÄúIt is like the Prime Minister has finally woken up to contraception the day after conception.‚ÄùBut the Prime Minister, speaking after a Cobra meeting about Ukraine and Russia border tensions, defended the UK‚Äôs record on tackling Russian monetary influence at home.He told broadcasters: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs fair to say the UK hasn‚Äôt done a huge amount on dirty money, whether it‚Äôs from Russia or anywhere .‚ÄùMr Johnson added: ‚ÄúWhat we want to do is strengthen now the package that we have, strengthen the measures we have against potential ill-gotten Russian money, whether here or anywhere for‚Ä¶ which we have responsibility, with new measures that will hit the companies and concerns that I‚Äôve talked about.‚ÄúBut also open up the Matryoshka doll,you like ‚Äì you know what I‚Äôm talking about ‚Äì so that we see ‚Ä¶ who really owns the companies that we‚Äôre talking about, who really owns the properties that we‚Äôre talking about, and those measures, yes, we will be bringing forward from the Economic Crime Bill.‚ÄùHe signalled that the Bill would be brought forward in the next Queen‚Äôs Speech.We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate title: rail-services-end-early-scotland-prepares-storm-dudley
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A ScotRail train waiting at a stationTrain services in Scotland will end at pm on Wednesday as the country braces itself ahead of being hit by the first of two storms.ScotRail announced on Tuesday its services would end early on Wednesday due to Storm Dudley, the forecast for which has led to the Met Office issuing an amber weather warning for the north of England and the central belt and south of Scotland.Gusts could rise as high as  miles per hour in coastal areas, with the amber warning due to come into force at pm tomorrow and expire at midnight, when it will be downgraded to a yellow warning until am on Thursday.Storm Dudley will be immediately followed by Storm Eunice later this week.‚ö†Ô∏èTHREAD: Scotland is bracing itself for #StormDudley tomorrow. The welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most @ScotRail train services will shut down from  on Wednesday .   pic QGGxZWpFA‚Äî ScotRailFebruary , Deputy First Minister John Swinney said the weather could cause disruption to travel and power supplies as well as danger from falling trees.‚ÄúWe expect another period of disruption this week, with Storms Dudley and Eunice set to bring strong winds to Scotland,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúHigh winds may cause issues on roads and bridges, disruption to power supplies and danger from falling trees. We would urge everyone to plan their journeys in advance, exercise caution on the roads, and follow the latest travel advice.‚ÄùFollowing a meeting of the Scottish Government‚Äôs Resilience Room, the Deputy First Minister said they would continue to monitor the situation as the storms approach.Services running in the far north, Kyle of Lochalsh, and Aberdeen-Inverness lines will continue to run as usual because the areas are outside the boundaries of the weather warning.‚ÄúScotland is bracing itself for Storm Dudley tomorrow,‚Äù the rail operator said on Twitter.‚ÄúThe welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most ScotRail train services will shut down from  on Wednesday.‚ÄùThe RNLI warned adverse weather conditions could make seas ‚Äútreacherous‚Äù, urging people to take extra care in coastal areas.‚ÄúThe expected storms could make our seas treacherous, increasing the risk for those visiting the coast around the UK and Ireland,‚Äù RNLI national water safety partner, Samantha Hughes, said.‚ÄúIn a normal year, around  people lose their lives at the coast and we know that more than half of those never intended to be in the water.‚ÄúSo, whether you are walking, running or cycling at the coast, please be extra responsible and avoid taking unnecessary risk or entering the water.‚ÄúIn particular, we ask people to stay well back from stormy, wintery seas and clf edges, check tide times before you go, take a phone with you, and call  or  and ask for the Coastguardyou or someone  is in trouble.‚ÄùMeanwhile, the Woodland Trust Scotland urged people to stay away from wooded areas during the high winds.‚ÄúPlease do not enter woodland when winds are high and be cautious when entering woodland after a storm,‚Äù said spokesman, George Anderson.He added: ‚ÄúEven fully toppled trees are best avoided when newly felled as they are often not completely settled and still have the potential to move or tip.‚ÄúWe know a felled tree can be fascinating, especially to children, but it is not safe to clamber about on or under them.‚ÄúWoodland Trust Scotland manages  sites across the country and, in the aftermath of any storm, public safety is our first concern.‚ÄúWhere paths are blocked, we will have them cleared as quickly as possible but, in the meantime, we call on the public to heed all path ersions and safety notices on sites.‚ÄùWe title: covid-vaccine-offered-five-11-year-olds-wales-minister-says
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A vial of Covid- vaccineWales has become the first country in the UK to announce it will be offering the Covid- vaccine to all five to -year-olds.Wales‚Äô health minister Eluned Morgan said she had read the ‚Äúyet to be published‚Äù report by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationand would be further rolling out the jab.There are reports the JCVI announcement of its decision on whether to expand the immunisation programme to younger children has been delayed due to a disagreement with the UK Government.Responding to questions during a Plenary session at the Senedd on Tuesday, Baroness Morgan called the hold-up a ‚Äúshame‚Äù and ‚Äúperplexing‚Äù.She said: ‚ÄúIn relation to vaccination of children, the JCVI has yet to publish its report, although there are lots of clues inand other places where there seems to have been lots of leaks come out.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame and it‚Äôs perplexing to understand why that has not been published yet.‚ÄúBut I have seen a copy of that advice and we will be commencing the rollout of vaccinations for five to -year-olds.‚ÄùThe minister has not set out a timetable for when youngsters will be able to get the jab, and told Senedd members: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to do that as a matter of urgency, as we did over the Christmas period. That‚Äôs partly because the risk isn‚Äôt as great to that cohort.‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre also waiting to hear from the JCVI to see whether they‚Äôll need a booster on top of the booster for older age groups in the spring.‚ÄùShe added: ‚ÄúOf course, it‚Äôs likely to have been a very dficult decision for the JCVI, because generally, children have a milder illness and fewer hospitalisations. But, of course, they have to balance that against the prospect of missing school.‚ÄúWe have to consider very dferent issues when it comes to the vaccination of children as young as five years old, of course, so we‚Äôll be in a position where we will expect those children to be accompanied by an adult. There will be a need for informed consent, but there will be an opportunity for siblings, for example, to be brought at the same time.‚ÄùBaroness Morgan said children would receive the vaccine in health centres.The UK medical regulator, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency , approved the Pfizer Covid- vaccine for use in children aged five to  last year.The dose approved for children is lower than that used for adults and older children.After the announcement, the JCVI said that the vaccine should be offered to at-risk children in this age group. It is yet to announce its decision about wider use among children aged five to .Over . million dosages of the vaccine have already been administered to five to -year-olds in the US alone.A Government spokesperson in Westminster said: ‚ÄúWe are reviewing the JCVI‚Äôs advice as part of wider decision-making ahead of the publication of our long-term strategy for living with COVID-. More detail will be set out shortly.‚ÄùThe Government in England is expected to make an announcement next week.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government urged Westminster to quickly publish the advice, saying they ‚Äústand ready‚Äù to implement any JCVI recommendation.‚ÄúWhen the UK Government publishes the final advice on vaccination for  to -year-olds we stand ready to take it forward,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúFollowing the update from the Welsh Government on this matter in the Senedd, we hope that the UK Government will publish the JCVI advice as quickly as is practicable.‚ÄùWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: sessions and sail to bring music to the swan later this year
story: An experience combining sailing and live music sessions will come to the isles for the first time in April. between th and th April.It will coincide with the th Shetland Folk Festival celebrations.The first voyage for Sessions and Sail took place in , but this is the first time it has been brought to the isles.Musician Nisbet said that the trip, initially booked for , had been #a long time coming#.#I‚Äôve run trips further south and have always been keen to bring Sessions and Sail home,# he said. being such a well-known Shetland vessel, and having sailed on her regularly myself, I know she will be the perfect boat to partner with.#I am also delighted that for the sailing we will be under the command of skipper Maggie Adamson, who is a top class Shetland musician as well as an excellent sailor.#Swan Trust Trustee Brian Wishart said they were #delighted# to bring Sessions and Sail to the isles. is no stranger to musical sessions, with many a memorable night aboard.#We hope this trip may become an annual event, adding to the wide range of high-quality musical experiences on offer in Shetland.#..Twelve young Shetlanders will take part in the Tall Ships Races  which set off from Aalborg in Denmark next month.A group of  youngsters set off for an adventure of sailing and racing on board the Swan this afternoon ‚Äì their first destination Hirtshals#Keen sailor Scott Sandison saw off global competition to be named Sail Training International Sail Trainer of the Year .Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: wirdle is the word of the week
story: It is the web-based word game that has taken the world by storm, but now a Shetland version of Wordle has made an appearance.#Wirdle# follows the same basic rules as the original game, but challenges the player to identy a Shetland dialect word instead., which describes itself as #a gadderie# dedicated to studying, describing and documenting dialect, or #Shaetlan#.For the uninitiated, Wordle gives players six attempts to guess a five-letter word, with feedback given for each guess in the form of coloured tiles.The colours of the tiles indicade when letters match or, with even more luck, actually occupy the correct position.But for those who know the dference between a #spret# and the #dorts#, Wirdle might provide an ideal dialect-based alternative...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.A Brae High School pupil has been nominated for a new award celebrating the best of Scottish dialect.A new manual to help children and adults with communication dficulties has been launched for the isles.The promoters of the Rhoda Bulter Award are reminding anyone planning to take part in this year#s competition that there are just over three weeks#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: tobar an dualchais brides day the birthday of
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na Daoine or ‚Äòthe dead month‚Äô.   or Saint Bride‚Äôs Day. This falls in with ‚ÄòCandlemas‚Äô on nd February as a Christian festival and a traditional end of the Christmas season. Candlemas commemorates the presentation of the infant Jesus at the Temple in Jerusalem as described in St Luke‚Äôs Gospel and when some denominations bring candles to their church. Candlemas is also one of the so-called ‚ÄòQuarter-days‚Äô marking the changing seasons of winter, spring, summer and autumn. It is followed by Whitsun, Lammas Day and Martinmas as the term-days with their administrative and legal implications for the payment of rents and flittings. Saint Bride or Saint Bridget has been one of the most popular of the saints of the celtic church. Of course, there were many ‚ÄòBridgets‚Äô, but the one whose festival date is on st February was ‚ÄòBridget of Kildare‚Äô in Leinster whose death was dated to AD . Bridget was one of the patron saints of Ireland and is remembered in the tradition of plaiting rush crosses around st February to set over doors and windows to protect the home from fire and other danger.   or the endearing ‚ÄòBride‚Äôs little fosterling‚Äô.‚Äô .¬†‚ÄòBride‚Äôs Day, the birthday of spring‚Äô. century, traditions of Saint Bride were collected by Alexander Carmichael among his prayers, hymns, blessings and charms from the Hebrides. He suggests that accounts of Saint Bride were not easily recovered and summarised the tradition: ‚ÄòThe serpent is supposed to emerge from its hollow among the hills on St Bride‚Äôs Day, and a propitiatory hymn was sung to it. Only one verse of this hymn has been obtained, apparently the first. It dfers in dferent localities: [Early on Bride‚Äôs mornThe serpent shall come from the hole, I shall not molest the serpent, Nor will the serpent molest me.‚Äô¬†The snake is a powerful element in mythology and religion and a creature to be respected as the ‚Äòhymn‚Äô makes clear. Familiar in the snake coiled round the rod, it is a symbol of medicine and healing, and the appearance of the adder or snake on Saint Bride‚Äôs Day offers a feeling of hope and transformation, and of turning the corner with the ening of the days. . century. .!... !

title: special donnie munro concert to bring skye live back with a
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineThe island#s premier music festival is set toin style on Thursday th May # following a two-year break due to the pandemic # with an opening night extravaganza # ‚ÄòComing Home: An Evening with Donnie Munro and friends‚Äô and featuring special guests in the form of multi-award-winning Gaelic supergroup M√†nran.The show will be Donnie‚Äôs first in his hometown since  and will see him perform with a full eight-piece band line-up on the spectacular Skye Live Festival site at Am Meall in Portree.¬†The singer said: #This offers me a fantastic opportunity to bring this amazing line-up, featuring some of Scotland‚Äôs top musicians together, for an exclusive performance to open this year‚Äôs Skye Live Festival.He added: #It has been fantastic to watch the festival grow in strength, year on year, in what must be one of the most special and unique festival locations anywhere in the world, and to see it become internationally recognised as, ‚Äòone of the best boutique festivals in the country‚Äô, is just fantastic for the island, and it is such a great honour for me to be invited to be a part of it all and to be bringing the music back home here to where it all began.#Joining Donnie Munro on the night will be M√†nran, internationally recognised as one of the most iconic and respected Scottish bands on the road today. With three hugely successful studio albums under their belt, in October  the band released their fourth, titled √ôRAR to critical acclaim, and adding to their success, lead female vocalist, Kim Carnie was crowned ‚ÄòGaelic Singer of the Year‚Äô at the  Hands up for Trad Awards.M√†nran founder and accordionist Gary Innes said: #Playing on the Isle of Skye has always been a special night for M√†nran over the years but joining Donnie and his band as their special guests for Skye Live will certainly be a night to remember.#.

title: island couple fly the flag for skye in
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineA Skye couple who are embarking on a trip of a letime in Antarctica have proudly flown the official island flag this week while camping at the earth#s southernmost continent.Melanie and Bob Mossfrom Camastianavaig, near Portree, left the island on th January in the first leg of an epic journey which saw them arrive late last week at the landmass which is almost wholly ice-covered, spans . million kilometres, and is located more than , miles south of Skye.Speaking to the Free Press from their camp at Kerr Point, Melanie detailed her and Bob#s incredible voyage so far.She said: #On the th January we flew to Santiago, Chile and arrived in mid-morning of the th. We stayed in quarantine overnight . On the th we flew from Santiago south to Punta Arenas at the tip of Chile to meet our ship.#Melanie and Bob are sailing on the MS Roald Amundsen which is a Hybrid powered expedition ship owned by the Norwegian company Hurtigruten.#We are at sea for  days in total, exploring the Antarctic Peninsula,# she said.#We aren#t exactly known for traditional beach holidays on the Costas, so this voyage was perfect for us. Going to rarely visited places at the end of the earth, to see things only a few other people have ever seen.‚ÄúIt also helps I love penguins.‚ÄùMelanie said that by sailing by expedition ship, they had the opportunity to explore remote parts of Antarctica on foot and from small zodiac boats, getting close to nature and the beautul wilderness.She added: #We are one of the very few passenger ships to get below the Antarctic Circle this season, so it was a privilege to spend three days down there. The photo of me holding the flag on the balcony below the Antarctic Circle at .¬∞ south.#Earlier this week, Melanie alerted the Free Press about their adventure asking: #@WHFP do you know how far any of the fantastic new Skye Flags have travelled  Ours left Camustianavaig with us last month and crossed the Antarctic Circle to ¬∞ South and last night we camped with it at Kerr Point Antarctica ¬∞ South.#Melanie explained: #I took the flag as it hangs in my ‚Äòden‚Äô at home and when I was researching the trip it was always catching my eye.#It dawned on me one day that I#d be travelling further south than Skye is north and I should take the flag with us. When Bob and I got the opportunity to camp at Kerr Point ¬∞ south we just had to fly the flag proudly.‚ÄùShe added: #Only  guests had the opportunity to camp the night in Antarctica, so we were very lucky. Our camp neighbours were from Germany and asked us about the flag as they did not recognise it. We were very proud to explain where we came from and how new the flag is to the Isle of Skye.#I also work seasonally as an instructor at ACE Target Sports, Portree and we have photos of playing cards customers have won at ACE and taken with them around the world. I have taken a couple of ACE#S with me, taken photos and sent them back to Mattto add to the album! So, we are flying the flag for ACE as well.#Melanie and Bob are due to arrive back on Skye next Wednesday #All in all, an epic trip, never to be forgotten and full of amazing memories. Even the eye-wateringly cold Antarctic plunges we have both done down here!# she addedThe couple#s flying of the Skye standard will no doubt be a proud moment for young islander Calum Alasdair Munro from Kilmuir. The youngster‚Äôs design was selected as the official flag following a competition which lasted  months, attracted  entries and received more than , public votes.Calum Alasdair raised the flag at an official and socially distant unfurling ceremony at the Nicolson memorial in August .

title: centenary sailor dolan caps his 100th birthday in
story: An T√¨r, An C√†nan, ‚ÄòS na DaoineA resident in An Acarsaid care home in Broadford, Skye, ‚ÄòDolan‚Äô as he is known, was asked by staff what he wanted for his special birthday He was proud to wear his answer at Armadale Pier, where he was greeted on the MV Loch Nevis by master and fellow Lewisman Iain Mackenzie, who lives in Kyleakin.As well as the cap, Dolan was also given a bag of CalMac goodies. February  at Flesherin, Point, Dolan worked with his dad making Harris Tweed before getting an apprenticeship with a bakery in Stornoway.However, his ambition was always to join the Merchant Navy, which he did in  in Glasgow.Not long after, he joined the crew of the British-India ship SS Manela which sailed to South Africa during World War Two.Dolan said: ‚ÄúI also went to America, Canada and Australia while at sea and could be away for up to two years at a time, but it was always great to get on the boat in Glasgow and head home to Lewis.‚ÄúI ed to Lewis for a time after the war and spent many happy years living with my sister Mary Ann down in Back. I loved going down to the pier and watching the ferries come and go when we went to town, many a journey I enjoyed with CalMac.#I have a small picture of the #Sulivan# in my room # the sea and boats have always given me so much joy.‚ÄùMaster Mackenzie added: ‚ÄúIt was a pleasure to help Dolan mark his special birthday, we were delighted to welcome him on board.#He is a really interesting character who has travelled the world, and me and the crew were privileged to talk to him and listen to his wonderful stories.#I am from Aird, a nearby village in Point, and it was my pleasure to present the hat and goodies to a fellow rubhach.‚ÄùLast Sunday , Dolan enjoyed his birthday party in An Acarsaid, surrounded by family and friends and delighted members of staff. The Lord Lieutenant of Ross and Cromarty, Joanie Whiteford, also visited as Dolan received his card from the Queen.Care home manager Margaret Mackinnon told the Free Press it is a pleasure to have Dolan staying in An Acarsaid.‚ÄúHe loves good banter and is keen on his music,‚Äù she added. ‚ÄúHe plays the mouth organ and the piano and especially loves listening and dancing to ceilidh music. He also loves listening to the accordion.#He is a huge character with us here at An Acarsaid and has a quiet, happy outlook on le.#He enjoys his Golden Virginia smokes and a nice dram. Dolan participates in all our activities and remains a very competitive dominoes player. He loves to win and is loved by all.‚Äù

title: ballymena author pens a new novel
story: A Ballymena man has penned a new novel which has been published by Hobart Books. Sam Burnside was born in Ballymena is now living in Londonderry Derry where he where he was founder and first Director of the Verbal Arts Centre, an educational charity established in  to promote literature in all its forms. Sam‚Äôs latest book is set in Northern Ireland at the height of The Troubles, and against the background of social and political change and energetic economic and cultural development of the time It explores the nature of loss, grief and guilt, and examines memory, accountability and the place of forgiveness and truth.The story involves Ruth Porter who was killed in a bomb blast in central Belfast. Now, as the day of their th birthday approaches, her twin sister Rebecca is compelled to meet her killer, a man who has been freed from jail as a result of the Good Friday Agreement.Rebecca‚Äôs troubled instinct is to retreat from the ghosts who inhabit her world. Her two closest friends take her by car from Belfast to West Donegal, to Slieve League, the highest sea clfs in Europe. Here high above the Atlantic, on the edge of the world, she attains a startling clarity of vision. The question is, has she the strength to step forward into a new future  Described by the Derry Journal as ‚Äòone of the most important literary figures living in the north west‚Äô, his work has received praise for its craftsmanshipand for the ways in which it sympathetically explores the experience of living in Northern Ireland. He is the author of ‚ÄòThe Cathedral‚Äô a long poem that won the Sunday Tribune Hennessy Literary Award for Poetry in . His work has attracted a number of literary prizes, including an Allingham Poetry Prize, the University of Ulster‚Äôs McCrea Literary Award for Literature and a Bass Ireland Award. His poetry has been published and broadcast widely.Sam was awarded an MBE in  for services to the arts.

title: rates to rise by 3 64
story: COUNCILLORS in Mid and East Antrim say they have achieved below inflation changes to business and domestic rates next year - but it will still mean a rise in bills for ratepayers already witnessing eye watering hikes in the cost of living.The new rate will increase by .% or p per week. This will mean an additional payment of around pound. a year for householders.A meeting, chaired by Deputy Mayor Matthew Armstrong, heard that the local authoritys aim was to minimise the impact on local ratepayers while delivering signicant investment and improvements.Proposing the new rate, Chair of Council‚Äôs Policy and Resources Committee, Alderman Billy Ashe MBE, said: ‚ÄúWe will continue to face challenges but we remain steadfast in our commitment to recovery and regeneration across all areas of our society.‚ÄùHe was seconded by UUP Cllr. Keith Turner. A recorded vote resulted in the proposal being passed by  votes to . Cllr. Timothy Gaston, seconded by Ald. Stewart McDonald, had proposed an increase of .%Council‚Äôs portion of the rates amounts to % of the rates bills received by residents and .% of businesses rates bills in Mid and East Antrim, with the remainder of each set by the Stormont Executive.In a release issued after the meeting, Council stated: Despite the sustained financial impact of the Covid- crisis and rising inflation, Council remains committed to growing the local economy by investing in ambitious and innovative projects to drive and sustain the future of the area in key growth sectors such as renewable energy and digital technologies. This vital work is aimed at improving skills, creating jobs and boosting our economy.Just this month, for example, a ‚Äòrevolutionary‚Äô Hydrogen Training Academy was launched in Mid and East Antrim, which was a first-of-its-kind project enabling the Borough to fully maximise opportunities associated with hydrogen as the emerging leading sustainable energy solution.Major development opportunities are also moving another step forward with the signing of the Belfast Region City Deal in recent weeks.The deal unlocks poundbn of transformative co-investment, which will deliver more than  highly ambitious projects and programmes, including the re-development of Carrickfergus as a destination town, a major extension of The Gobbins clf path and the iC Innovation Centre within the wider St Patrick‚Äôs Barracks initiative in Ballymena.The total investment in Mid and East Antrim from City Deal will be almost poundm, with Council contributing pound.m.A range of exciting capital projects will also help our local community to enjoy more opportunities for outdoor play and recreation, with work underway on new and improved play facilities across the Borough, including play parks and multi-use sporting facilities.Businesses in Mid and East Antrim will also continue to benefit from key training, investment and innovation programmes over the last twelve months, and plans are well advanced to provide further opportunities for growth in several sectors as the post-pandemic recovery phase progresses.

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220214news56 of ni pet owners would ditch their partners for their pets
story: Men have been warned to be on their best behaviour on Valentine‚Äôs Day or face a visit to the dog house, according to a survey of pet owners and their relationships. Women are more likely to ditch their partner than their pet, found a poll for nationwide pet retailer Jollyes. Asked about their relationship with their partner and their pet and which one they would ditch first,  per cent said they would ditch their partner against  per cent who would ditch their pet. Men were more loyal to their partners, with  per cent saying they would ditch their pet and  per cent saying they would ditch their partner. Overall,  per cent would ditch their partner first and  per cent said the pet would go first. The study was carried out by Jollyes to gauge humans‚Äô attitudes to romance and relationships as it launches the search on social media for a canine couple to take part in a romantic dinner for two at its doggy dates diner, ‚ÄúC‚Äôest Jollyes‚Äù, open for one day only on  February at its Runcorn store in Cheshire . Two dogs will get the chance to enjoy a three course dinner featuring a menu from Jollyes Artisan Lestage range including angus beef with sweet potato, venison and salmon, and duck with sweet potato. The survey showed some big dferences in attitudes to pets and partners around the UK. People in North East England were more likely to ditch their partnerover their pet, followed by London , Northern Ireland , South West . [See table in editor‚Äôs notes below for regional breakdown.] Owners were asked what they loved most about their pets, with loyalty, unconditional love, loving nature, affection and a warm heart among the qualities cited. No matter how much love an animal gives, most pet ownerswould prefer a romantic Valentine‚Äôs night with their partner than one spent with their pet. Of male respondents,  per cent chose a night with their partner, compared with  per cent of female respondents. The figures were broadly similar across the country. Among the other popular traits cited by pet owners were: ‚Äúthey are so loyal and loving. And cute!‚Äù ‚Äúunconditional love and loyalty‚Äù ‚Äúthey comfort me when I‚Äôm feeling blue‚Äù ‚Äúdoesnt argue or answer back‚Äù ‚Äúthey always cheer me up‚Äù ‚Äúwaggy tail and warm heart‚Äù and ‚Äúher loving nature, always there for me when I need her‚Äù. One said: ‚ÄúSometimes playful, sometimes cuddly, intelligent, independent, sometimes dangerous. All rather like my partner really.‚Äù Not everyone was totally enamoured with their pet. One said: ‚ÄúNothing, it hates me, only loves my we‚Äù. And not all pets‚Äô traits would make for a romantic night out ‚Äì one said: ‚Äúhassle free‚Äù, another said ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt answer back‚Äù and one said ‚Äúit‚Äôs a tortoise and he‚Äôs as indferent to use as we are to him‚Äù. Phil Turner-Naylor, head of marketing at Jollyes, said: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre known as a nation of animal lovers and this goes to prove it. When it comes to relationships, a lot people would choose their pet over their partner. ‚ÄúThe good news for romantics though is that a big majority choose people over pets. What it does show, especially for men, is that partners have to work hard to keep the romance going or they might find themselves in the dog house. Women are looking for a romantic night with their partner on Valentine‚Äôs, butthe men don‚Äôt get it right, they had better watch out.‚Äù

title: wwwballymenaguardiancouknews20220214newsremaining northern ireland coronavirus laws lifted
story: The remaining coronavirus restrictions and face-covering regulations are to be scrapped, Health Minister Robin Swann has confirmed. They are to be replaced by guidance after Mr Swann obtained support for the move from his fellow ministers. Social distancing, regulations on the number people allowed in homes and the COVID passport scheme are also gone. There are only a small number of restrictions left in place, said Mr Swann, who is isolating after testing positive for coronavirus, in his statement to the Assembly. In light of the current situation, and remembering the commitment that restrictions would only be in place as long as they are needed, I have decided that those remaining measures should no longer be set out in regulations. Instead, they should be placed in guidance to be followed by the public. I shall therefore be making an order on Tuesday, February  revoking the remaining restrictions and face-covering regulations. The relevant guidance will be updated.‚Äù He added that the changes do ‚Äúnot mean that Covid- has gone away or that we as a community are safe from its harm‚Äù. Mr Swann continued, ‚ÄúIt is vitally important that we continue to observe the sensible measures we have all learnt to protect ourselves and others. Even with these powers in place however, it would almost certainly be impossible to introduce new restrictions in the absence of an Executive.

title: all covid 19 restrictions to be lifted in northern ireland
story: Health Minister Robin Swann. Picture: Peter Morrison PA WirePA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHealth Minister Robin Swann. Picture: Peter Morrison PA WireLisa SmythTwitterFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailAll Covid- legal restrictions in Northern Ireland will be replaced by guidance from Tuesday, Health Minister Robin Swann has announced.Among the Covid- restrictions being removed from law are the requirement to wear a face covering in public places and the use Covid certicates in nightclubs ‚Äì although their use in all hospitality and entertainment will continue to be encouraged.Mr Swann also reiterated his position that there are currently no plans for changes to the current arrangements for testing, contact tracing and isolation in Northern Ireland.The decision to scrap Covid- laws follows consideration of legal advice from the Attorney General and consultation with Executive ministers and moves the pandemic response in Northern Ireland into a new phase.However, announcing the swathe of relaxations, the UUP minister also stressed the continuing need for caution and vigilance as a further , cases and two deaths linked to the virus were recorded.Mr Swann, who revealed at the weekend that he had tested positive for Covid, said: ‚ÄúWith the reduced threat from the Omicron iant, we can move away from an emergency and legalistic framework to a new approach where making safer choices is embedded in our daily lives.‚ÄúThat means all of us continuing to do our best to cut down risks of infection and transmission.‚ÄúIt means looking after each other by following the public health guidance. It must always be remembered that taking unnecessary risks with Covid may affect people who are particularly vulnerable to the virus.‚ÄúSo please do not jump the gun and start behaving asthe pandemic is over. That is not the case.‚ÄúWhile omicron is less severe than previous strains of the virus, community transmission remains very high and hospital pressures signicant.‚ÄúThe most vulnerable as a result of underlying disease remain susceptible to severe illness and it is important that we all do what we can to protect them.‚ÄùMr Swann warned that coronavirus ‚Äúis likely to stay with us in some form for some time‚Äù but he said emergency restrictions cannot remain in place indefinitely.He continued: ‚ÄúA large part of what we currently do to protect ourselves is already covered by guidance rather than regulations.‚ÄúThis includes self-isolating when infected and taking lateral flow tests before meeting up with others.‚ÄúThe guidance will continue to emphasise all the steps that we should keep taking to protect each other.‚ÄúI will, of course, keep the situation on regulations under ongoing and detailed review. We cannot rule out a new iant emerging down the line with new interventions being required. I very much hope that will not be the case.‚ÄùMr Swann has made the announcement having received the latest public health assessment from the Chief Medical Officer and Chief Scientic Adviser.‚ÄúThe expectation from the public health assessments is that no signicant rise in ICU occupancy is expected,‚Äù he continued.‚ÄúWhile many people will very much welcome my decision on regulations, I know there will be concerns. Community transmission is still very high and our hospitals remain under severe pressure.‚ÄúA sustained effort to follow the public health guidance will help reduce infection numbers and support our health service.‚ÄùAs the hospitality sector will continue to be encouraged to use Covid certicates, Mr Swann said the importance of wearing face coverings in health and social care settings, on public transport and in enclosed indoor settings ‚Äúwill continue to be strongly emphasised‚Äù.Vaccine certication will continue to be available to the public ‚Äì including for those who need it for travel abroad to satisfy entry requirements of countries they are visiting.Related topicsRobin SwannMore On Robin SwannBusinesses annoyed work from home guidance remainsNorthern Ireland‚Äôs Covid rules Credit: Liam McBurney PA Wire FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueProtection: A young woman puts on her mask as she walks past a Covid- safety message in Belfast city centre. Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhen the books are written and history students look back on the early s, they‚Äôll be forgiven for thinking they‚Äôre studying science fiction instead.Had a man with a sandwich board been shouting ‚Äúthe end is nigh‚Äù outside Belfast City Hall in February , it would have looked like he had a point. It was the end of the world as we knew it.Read MoreNiamh Campbell:OpinionImportant day forto some kind of normalityNorthern Ireland‚Äôs Covid rules scrapped and replaced with guidance‚ÄúThe end is nigh‚Äù means something dferent today, and we can all breathe a little easier.There is no doubt that without the restrictions we would be looking back on a lot more lives lost to Covid than the official figure of over ,.For many, their last moments were spent alone. For those who mourned, they watched from afar. That was one of the hardest restrictions to bear.Pulling our bedroom curtains closed on Monday, March , , we did so wondering what sort of world would await when we opened them the next morning.The UK death toll stood at , three of them here.St Patrick‚Äôs Day had already been cancelled, giving the first hint of what was heading our direction. Then lockdown started.Farewells were said to those in nursing homes as the doors closed to visits. Businesses shut, save for those deemed essential.The queues outside supermarkets started. Our children spent their first day at home after the closure of schools.That was  days ago.We had all suspected it was coming, having watched images from around the world as the pandemic wave approached our shores.Shielding letters were sent to , of the most vulnerable, telling how they were to go into isolation.March ,  was furlough day as the Government committed to support % of wages for employees.Three days later gatherings of more than two people were banned. It was essential trips only.Thursday, March  saw the start of a weekly ritual as we clapped for carers. Communities made scrubs and masks for front line workers. On a bigger scale, companies were redeploying staff and taking on new workers to help the cause as fears over a lack of PPE rose.Then, at pm on Saturday, March  lockdown officially commenced.We said farewell to work colleagues, socially distanced ourselves from family and friends, and started to embrace a new style of community.Those of us with children became teachers overnight. Our children taught us a thing or two also, with crash courses on Zoom, Facetime and TikTok.The older generation had to embrace the technology the young had grown up with. Hands upyou logged in to a Zoom meeting hiding those pyjama bottoms under the kitchen table Maybe it was just as well for our egos the pubs and nightclubs were closed. Self-styled hair, out of necessity, was perhaps not the way to go.Strange as it may seem, being apart from other people actually brought us closer together.For the older among us, we instantly felt a need to hug our parents as soon as we were told we couldn‚Äôt. It would be a shame not to remember that. In a way, we all became heroes of a sort. ‚ÄúStay at home, save lives,‚Äù was the message. We stayed at home, while others manned the front line.Driving around was an eerie experience in those early days ‚Äî few cars on the road shops shut.And when we went out for a walk to get some exercise we actually heard the birdsong.Weddings were halted. Birthdays went uncelebrated. Holidays put on hold.And in the midst of all the sitting around doing not very much at all, a new vocabulary sprung up: furlough the R-rate PPE self-isolation shielding.Social distancing was no longer the domain of the school disco, where the boys sat on one side and the girls on the other.We all wanted to knowwe were a key worker. There was the unprecedented rolling out of guidelines, restrictions, support services and grants to keep businesses afloat.Confusion reigned: how many could meet in a garden  Where could airplanes take us to, and what did we need to get there  What was a ‚Äòwet‚Äô pub Little by little, the restrictions we were living with eased and chinks of light started to emerge.Cemeteries reopened on April  after a public outcry ‚Äî the first easing of curbs.Monday, May  saw garden centres reopen, with the promise of more rules being ltedthe downward trend in cases of Covid continued.All eyes were on the R-rate, but the same day saw the first signs of a lockdown breakdown.By the end of the month, with temperatures soaring, thousands headed for the seaside.Still, on May , for the first time since March , no deaths were recorded. Positive signs were emerging, and further lockdown easements saw le edging back, evenit was baby steps.But there were relapses. We were teased with the freedom of the pre-pandemic world, only to have it pulled back from us as new iants, second waves of the virus, kept arriving.Restrictions came, then were eased. But they never went away.For many, particularly in the business world, there has been a heavy price to pay.Some pub doors were shut, never to open again. Even big names such as Debenhams could not survive the pandemic, having battled for years against the growth in online retailing.Then there was the impact on people‚Äôs wellbeing.That many died having contracted Covid has been well documented, but lockdown brought with it the extra baggage of isolation. The mental state of people was a constant concern.Sure, it‚Äôll be over by Christmas, we said in . We said the same in .It wouldn‚Äôt be this placethe ending of restrictions didn‚Äôt bring with it some added confusion and doubt.With the Executive unable to meet due to the lack of a First and Deputy First Minister, the issue became a legal matter.In years to come there‚Äôll be plenty of stories told starting with the words: ‚ÄúDo you remember the time ‚ÄùThose history books  years from now will be filled with the facts and the figures, the bumps in the road, the scandals of those in public office.But we‚Äôve lived with it all, lived through it all, and come out the other side.We can all see a little more clearly now.The dark clouds have been replaced by that hopeful rainbow we‚Äôve been teased with several times over the past two years.There does come a time when we have to learn to live in the world as it is, as close as we can to the way we did.We might not be quite stepping into the brightest of bright days.Restrictions will change to guidelines and recommendations.There will still be many content to take the precautions they feel they need, and everyone should move forward at their own pace.Hopefully the last two years have taught the majority of us to appreciate the things in our lives that are most important to us ‚Äî our family and friends.Le moves fast. Hopefully, before long, the darkest days of Covid will be a memory.Being honest, a lot of people had left those memories behind some time ago.But think, too, of those who bring the memory of loved ones lost into a world their parent, husband, we, sister or brother is not there to enjoy beside them.Related topicsBelfast City CouncilMore On Belfast City CouncilCost sinks council plan to make Belfast public transport free for young people PremiumBBC NI presenters topping up pay packets with money-spinning external engagementsBelfast City council set to launch legal action over Poots‚Äô port checks move PremiumHolyland residents instruct Belfast law firm to take legal action against PSNI, council and Stormont department PremiumGail WalkerOpinionThe idea NI‚Äôs dficulty is nationalism‚Äôs opportunity is corrosive... title: coronavirus northern ireland do i have to wear a mask
story: Restrictions are being lted in Northern Ireland. Picture: Stock image FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRestrictions are being lted in Northern Ireland. Picture: Stock imageEimear McGovernTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailHealth Minister Robin Swann has said he will make an order to revoke all remaining Covid- restrictions on Tuesday.The remaining measures should no longer be set out in regulations and instead will take the form of guidance issued to the public.So how does this affect you Read MoreNorthern Ireland‚Äôs Covid rules scrapped and replaced with guidanceNorthern Ireland public reaction will ‚Äòy hugely‚Äô in restriction removal, says senior medicFace coveringsThe wearing of face coverings will no longer be a requirement in enclosed public areas. That includes shops, restaurants, caf√©s, bars and pubs, public transport, driving instruction and close contact services.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up But the importance of wearing face coverings in health and social care settings, on public transport and in enclosed indoor settings will continue to be emphasised.Hospitality and eventsCovid status certication will no longer be legally required in any settings and venues hosting events and conferences won#t have to collect visitor information. However, hospitality and entertainment venues will still be encouraged to use the mechanism. Vaccine certication will continue to be available to anyone who needs it to travel abroad.WorkplacesIt#s currently unclear what stance will be taken in the future on working from home. Workplaces will not have to collect visitor information. The requirement for offices to take reasonable measures for ft social distancing has already been removed, but soon risk assessments will no longer be required.Testing and self-isolationThere are no plans at this stage for changes to the current requirements around testing, contact tracing and isolation.The minimum self-isolation period for people testing positive for Covid- has already been reduced, subject to negative lateral flow tests on days five and six of a person#s isolation.SchoolsThe Department of Education as of yet has not made clear whether or not it will now remove its rules on social distancing and mask wearing in school settings and on school buses.Most ReadAll Covid- restrictions to be lted in Northern Ireland from TuesdayStephen Nolan explores ‚Äòheart-breaking‚Äô title: main work begins on belfasts 175m
story: Minister Nichola Mallon is pictured with Chris Conway, Translink Group Chief Executive and representatives from Farrans Sacyr JV, GRAHAM and Babcock. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMinister Nichola Mallon is pictured with Chris Conway, Translink Group Chief Executive and representatives from Farrans Sacyr JV, GRAHAM and Babcock.Christopher LeebodyTwitterEmailFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailBelfast‚Äôs Transport Hub in the city centre has taken a step closer on Tuesday with the commencement of the main works at the site.The major infrastructural scheme led by Translink stretches across , sqft, replacing the existing Europa and Great Victoria Street bus and rail stations and becoming the largest integrated transport hub on the island of Ireland.The hub will provide  bus stands,  railway s and an enhanced walking and cycling connectivity across the city.Read MorePlans submitted for Weavers Cross projectLocal construction company Farrans and Spanish infrastructure group Sacyr will jointly carry out the main works at the hub, with construction group Graham having conducted enabling works and¬†Babcock nearing completion on railway systems work.Infrastructure Minister Nichola Mallon visited the site on Tuesday and described the latest milestone in the project as ‚Äúexciting‚Äù, saying the Transport Hub will be a ‚Äúgame changer‚Äù for Northern Ireland.‚ÄúI have been clear that we need to see an increase in the use of public transport and encourage more people to consider active travel options so that we can tackle the climate crisis,‚Äù she said.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up ‚ÄúTo achieve that we need to have the right infrastructure in place.‚ÄúWhen completed the Belfast Transport Hub will be the largest integrated transport facility on the island of Ireland bringing together many aspects of how we travel including greener and cleaner travel by bus, rail and cycling.‚ÄúIn addition users of the new hub will enjoy modern spacious facilities inside with a large concourse and enhanced retail space.‚ÄùAnother project running alongside the Transport Hub at Weavers Cross close to Sandy row will also regenerate the .m square foot brownfield site in the area.Ms Mallon added: ‚ÄúWith an expected annual footfall of over  million, this important NI Executive flagship project will bring a host of benefits to support the economy.‚ÄúIt will improve connectivity for everyone in Northern Ireland and beyond, and will be a key driver of social, economic and environmental wellbeing for the local and wider community.‚ÄúI also welcome the social value element of the contract with Translink and contractors working closely with stakeholders to provide employment and training opportunities.‚ÄúThis project will therefore bring both immediate and long-term benefits for the entire region. I look forward to commencement of the main works and wish all our partners every success as we jointly deliver this key scheme for Northern Ireland.‚ÄùChris Conway, chief executive of Translink said the new hub will bring a ‚Äútop-class customer experience including enhanced cross border connectivity‚Äù and thanked residents in the area for their engagement in the project.‚ÄúIt will be a major transport gateway for NI, creating a sense of arrival for a modern, progressive region,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWe expect construction on the new facility to take around four¬†years to complete. During this time over  jobs will be created, and the scheme overall will be a major boost to the construction and engineering sector in Northern Ireland.‚ÄúTranslink is also committed to delivering the social benefits from this project and we are working closely with Belfast City Council and local community partners to provide local employment opportunities.‚ÄúWe are grateful to the local community in south and west Belfast for the positive way they have engaged with Translink as this project has evolved.‚ÄùRelated topicsNichola MallonDepartment for InfrastructureMore On Nichola title: northern ireland job market covid recovery continues as payroll employees reaches highest level
story: The Covid recovery is continuing. Photo: Pacemaker Press FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe Covid recovery is continuing. Photo: Pacemaker PressEimear McGovernTwitterEmailFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailJob market recovery is continuing in Northern Ireland as the number of payrolled employees is now higher than pre-Covid for the eighth consecutive month, according to new data.Payrolls are now risen by % year-on-year and the number of employees being paid through HMRC here in January is now , - the highest on record.However, the recovery from the impact of Covid is not yet complete, with total employmentand hours worked yet toto pre-Covid levels.Compared to the pre-pandemic levels in October-December , the total number of hours worked in October-December  was % below, whilst the employment rate was .% below.Both the unemployment and economic inactivity rates remain above the pre-pandemic position .In January , the seasonally adjusted number of people on the claimant count was , , a decrease of from the previous month‚Äôs revised figure. The January claimant count is % below the recent peak in May , and % higher than the pre-pandemic count in March .And the¬†economic inactivity rate¬†increased over the quarterand over the yearto .%.¬†Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Earnings from the HMRC PAYE indicated that NI employees had a median monthly pay of ¬£, in January , an increase of ¬£over the month and an increase of ¬£over the year.The labour market statistics were published on Tuesday by the Northern Ireland Statistics  Research Agency.Meanwhile, the proportion of people aged  to  in work or the employment rate increased by . percentage points over both the quarter and the year to .%. Neither the quarterly nor annual changes were statistically signicant.The economic inactivity rateincreased over the quarterand over the yearto .%.The latest HMRC payroll data showed that employee numbers were .% above those recorded in March  pre-COVID. All sectors with the exception of finance and insurance reported an increase over the year.The accommodation and food sector reported the largest percentage increase over the year , where employees in this sector are just abovethose recorded pre-pandemic.Most ReadAll Covid- restrictions to be lted in Northern Ireland from TuesdayStephen Nolan explores ‚Äòheart-breaking‚Äô family history in new BBC title: northern irelands covid rules scrapped and replaced with guidance
story: Health Minister Robin Swann hails ‚Äòmajor milestone in our recovery‚Äô from pandemic in announcementLisa SmythTwitterFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailHealth Minister Robin Swann has ripped up Northern Ireland‚Äôs Covid rulebook ‚Äî with all remaining legal restrictions replaced by guidance from Tuesday.Masks, Covid certicates in nightclubs and limits on numbers meeting indoors in private homes are among the measures to go in a bonfire of the pandemic laws.Read MoreMark Bain:OpinionThe end is nigh, and thankfully the world is looking brighter than two years agoNiamh Campbell:OpinionImportant day forto some kind of normalityBusinesses annoyed work from home guidance remainsInstead, regulations are being replaced with advice, although the guidance on working from home remains for now ‚Äî frustrating business leaders.The removal of legal restrictions leaves Northern Ireland on a par with England, which scrapped most of its rules last month, and ahead of Scotland, Wales and the Republic of Ireland, where some rules, including masks, remain.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up On Monday night the news was hailed as ‚Äúa major milestone in our recovery‚Äù from the Covid emergency.However, Mr Swann urged people to be cautious, stressing the pandemic was not over.He also reiterated his position that there are currently no plans for changes to the current guidance on testing, contact tracing and isolation in Northern Ireland.The decision to scrap Covid laws follows consideration of legal advice from the Attorney General and consultation with Executive ministers and moves the pandemic response in Northern Ireland into a new phase.However, announcing the swathe of relaxations, the UUP minister also stressed the continuing need for caution and vigilance as a further , cases and two deaths linked to the virus were recorded.Mr Swann, who revealed at the weekend that he had tested positive for Covid, said: ‚ÄúWith the reduced threat from the Omicron iant, we can move away from an emergency and legalistic framework to a new approach where making safer choices is embedded in our daily lives.‚ÄúThat means all of us continuing to do our best to cut down risks of infection and transmission.‚ÄúIt means looking after each other by following the public health guidance. It must always be remembered that taking unnecessary risks with Covid may affect people who are particularly vulnerable to the virus.‚ÄúSo please do not jump the gun and start behaving asthe pandemic is over. That is not the case.‚ÄúWhile Omicron is less severe than previous strains of the virus, community transmission remains very high and hospital pressures signicant.‚ÄúThe most vulnerable as a result of underlying disease remain susceptible to severe illness and it is important that we all do what we can to protect them.‚ÄùMr Swann warned that coronavirus ‚Äúis likely to stay with us in some form for some time‚Äù but he said emergency restrictions cannot remain in place indefinitely.He continued: ‚ÄúA large part of what we currently do to protect ourselves is already covered by guidance rather than regulations.‚ÄúThis includes self-isolating when infected and taking lateral flow tests before meeting up with others. The guidance will continue to emphasise all the steps that we should keep taking to protect each other.‚ÄúI will, of course, keep the situation on regulations under ongoing and detailed review. We cannot rule out a new iant emerging down the line with new interventions being required. I very much hope that will not be the case.‚ÄùMr Swann has made the announcement having received the latest public health assessment from the Chief Medical Officer and Chief Scientic Adviser.‚ÄúThe expectation from the public health assessments is that no signicant rise in ICU occupancy is expected,‚Äù he continued.‚ÄúWhile many people will very much welcome my decision on regulations, I know there will be concerns. Community transmission is still very high and our hospitals remain under severe pressure.‚ÄúA sustained effort to follow the public health guidance will help reduce infection numbers and support our health service.‚ÄùAs the hospitality sector will continue to be encouraged to use Covid certicates, Mr Swann said the importance of wearing face coverings in health and social care settings, on public transport and in enclosed indoor settings ‚Äúwill continue to be strongly emphasised‚Äù.The Covid- regulations in Northern Ireland are not due to expire until March , but had been reviewed by the Executive every three weeks.The resignation of First Minister Paul Givan complicated the process of lting the remaining rules.Mr Swann was advised on the potential legal complications of him replacing regulations with guidance, without the wider endorsement of an Executive.On Monday Sinn Fein deputy leader Michelle O‚ÄôNeill said Stormont ministers had given their unanimous support to Mr Swann to ease restrictions.Related topicsThe Executive OfficeRobin SwannMichelle O#NeillPaul GivanMore On The Executive Office PremiumCrown Court trials that were halted by pandemic set to resume this weekParties‚Äô apology for abuse victims ‚Äòwill be welcomed‚Äô PremiumNiamh CampbellOpinionImportant day forto some kind of normalityPoll‚Äôs negative comments on bonfires and flags in north Down title: price of potatoes could rise by 30 due to farming
story: Increase: Wilson‚Äôs Country agronomist Stuart Meredith and managing director Lewis Cunningham assessing a sodden crop of Piper seed potatoes near Moira FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueIncrease: Wilson‚Äôs Country agronomist Stuart Meredith and managing director Lewis Cunningham assessing a sodden crop of Piper seed potatoes near MoiraStaff ReporterFebruary   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPotato prices could rise by %, one of Northern Ireland‚Äôs top suppliers has warned.An unprecedented hike in costs ‚Äî including fertiliser prices, which have almost doubled in a year ‚Äî looks set to impact on consumers.Read MoreWe‚Äôre paying % more for petrol and % more for diesel since Lewis Cunningham, managing director of Wilson‚Äôs Country, said all sectors of the agri food industry are facing major increases in their cost base ‚Äî and even the humble spud is affected.‚ÄúSignicant hikes across all energy, fuel, growing inputs such as sprays and fertilisers, including land and labour costs, are now in train,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúSome of these factors have been impacting all manufacturing businesses over recent months including our packing, distribution and storage operations.‚ÄúWith the continued increases coming at us in , unfortunately, we have no option but to pass these increases down the line to our customers.‚ÄùAccording to the management team at Wilson‚Äôs Country, high costs are likely to be sustained throughout .Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Cunningham added: ‚ÄúThe reality is that farmers are also facing dramatic increases in the cost of all crop inputs at the present time.‚ÄúThe end result will be a signicant increase in the production cost of all potato crops coming out of the ground at harvest time this year.‚ÄùMr Cunningham said Northern Ireland ‚Äúis far from being alone in this regard‚Äù.He added: ‚ÄúFarmers and growers around the world are being impacted by fast increasing costs of production at the present time. This will have a universally strong impact on international food prices throughout .‚ÄùWilson‚Äôs Country agronomist Stuart Meredith cited how fertiliser prices have more than doubled over the past  months, with no sign of prices easing before planting of the first crops takes place over the coming weeks.‚ÄúSupply and demand may actually become an issue through March and April, which may drive further price rises.‚ÄúAs many potato growers rely heavily on annual rental agreements, buying up stocks of fertiliser last autumn wasn‚Äôt an option for them as much of the land wasn‚Äôt secured at that stage.‚ÄúLast year it was costing approximately ¬£-¬£ per acre to fertilise a potato crop, depending on dferent soil analysis: this year we could be looking at somewhere in the region of ¬£ ac.‚ÄùMr Meredith added that the demand for clean, virgin land has increased within all the agri sectors.He explained: ‚ÄúIn turn, this has pushed the price being paid by potato growers for the right land up by approximately ¬£ ac. Another input that has seen a signicant rise in price is fuel. It takes approximately L of diesel to produce an acre of potatoes.‚ÄúLast year, red diesel was hovering around  per litre: at the minute it‚Äôs closer to p L.‚ÄùMr Meredith said some of the chemistry used in potato production has also experienced huge increases in price over the past few months.‚ÄúSome products have doubled in price in the space of six months,‚Äù he added.Most ReadAll Covid- title: sinn fein ministers accused of sectarian decisions over stadium funding
story: DUP MLA for north Antrim Paul Frew at Stormont who has taken on the role as Northern Ireland Economy Minister, replacing Diane Dodds, as part of Edwin Poots first ministerial team at Stormont. FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueDUP MLA for north Antrim Paul Frew at Stormont who has taken on the role as Northern Ireland Economy Minister, replacing Diane Dodds, as part of Edwin Poots first ministerial team at Stormont.By David Young, PAFebruary   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA decision to halt a scheme to upgrade football stadia while continuing the redevelopment of Casement Park has been branded ‚Äúsectarian‚Äù by a DUP MLA.Former economy minister Paul Frew accused Sinn Fein‚Äôs Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey and Finance Minister Conor Murphy of making ‚Äúsectarian decisions‚Äù as he claimed they were treating one project dferently to the other.Mr Murphy responded by describing Mr Frew‚Äôs comments as an ‚Äúinsult‚Äù.‚ÄúNeither the GAA or the soccer fraternity are sectarian,‚Äù he said."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland  .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ca-d--be-ad_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland in line for a major redevelopment PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueThe derelict Casement Park in Belfast is in line for a major redevelopment North Antrim MLA Mr Frew raised the issue in exchanges with Mr Murphy in the Assembly chamber.On Monday, Ms Hargey told MLAs she would be unable to progress the ¬£. million programme to redevelop local sub-regional football stadia due to the absence of a ing executive.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up She claims while the funding has been secured for the initiative, the approval of the wider Executive is required before it can progress to allocating funding for projects at specic grounds.Ms Hargey has blamed the DUP for the situation, claiming the party‚Äôs decision to pull Paul Givan out of the first minister‚Äôs role meant the stadia programme had to be placed on hold until a ing administration is back in place.The DUP has disputed this position and contrasted it with the minister‚Äôs insistence that the redevelopment of the GAA‚Äôs Casement Park in west Belfast can continue despite the Stormont crisis.Both Ms Hargey and Mr Murphy moved on Tuesday to explain that the two projects were at dferent stages of progression, with the Casement redevelopment a live project that had been approved by the Executive, while the sub regional stadia programme had not reached the stage of identying what works would be undertaken.In the Assembly, Mr Frew accused accused the Sinn Fein ministers of ‚Äúplaying silly games‚Äù with the issue.‚ÄúThe sports regional sports stadium for football funding and the Casement Park funding has both been approved by this Executive,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWhy has this finance minister and the communities minister made sectarian decisions to proceed with Casement Park, but to stop and halt the sports stadiums for football.‚Äù"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland de .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ca-d--be-ad_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland de .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ca-d--be-ad_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland de .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ca-d--be-ad_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news northern-ireland de .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_ca-d--be-ad_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Sinn Fein Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey PA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueSinn Fein Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey In response, Mr Murphy claimed the DUP had not thought through the consequences of collapsing the Executive.‚ÄúIn scrambling to defend your own seats you haven‚Äôt thought through what the impact of that will be, and the impact is going to be very, very real across a range of communities and sports stadia are one,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThe sub regional stadia have not identied any specic projects and would require to come back to the Executive for further approval.‚ÄúThe fact that you have collapsed the Executive means that all those clubs who are waiting on money will continue to wait on money until such times as you grow up and start to play at serious politics.‚ÄùAt a later press conference, Mr Murphy added: ‚ÄúTo try and describe that as sectarian is an insult.‚ÄùMinister Hargey insisted the funding for the programme was secure.The minister said while she would examine ‚Äúother ways‚Äù to progress the initiative, she was signicantly limited by the absence of an executive.‚ÄúI am ready to bring proposals forward before the end of this mandate,‚Äù she told BBC Radio Ulster.‚ÄúThe budget is there and I do think that it‚Äôs incumbent upon those other parties, particularly the DUP that chose to walk away, to look at that because this is the impact of their decision.‚ÄùFoyle DUP MLA Gary Middleton dismissed Minister Hargey‚Äôs comments.‚ÄúDeirdre Hargey has been in office for two years but has failed to deliver on an NDNAagreement to advance funding for football stadiums across Northern Ireland,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThere is an Executive commitment on sub-regional stadia funding.‚ÄúThat could have been delivered upon at any time during the last two years, and it still should be delivered today.‚ÄúFor two years she has dithered, telling everyone that a result was just around the corner, but still today nothing has been delivered.‚ÄùMost ReadAll Covid-
