title: murphy blames dup as stormont budget targeting health issues is halted
story: Ruth Dudley Edwards: Doug Beattie‚Äôs engagement policy gets a boost from Alliance   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‚Äòmaximise unionist votes‚Äô in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsSinn Fein‚Äôs Conor Murphy blames DUP as he claims Stormont budget targeting health waiting lists cannot be introducedA draft three-year budget for Northern Ireland that prioritised action on the region‚Äôs spiralling health waiting lists cannot be introduced due to the powersharing crisis, the Finance Minister has announced.By The NewsroomTuesday, th February , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th February , : pm  "       "  Finance Minister Conor MurphyConor Murphy said more than ¬£ million in additional funds earmarked for the next financial year can also not be spent because of the lack of ing executive.Mr Murphy said a single-year budget for   could also not be set, with departments instead operating on emergency funding arrangements until the impasse is resolved.The minister had sought legal advice from the attorney general on whether he could bring the draft budget for  to  to the Assembly despite ministers having not signed off on it.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.The spending plan had been out for public consultation when the DUP withdrew first minister Paul Givan from the administration as part of its protest against Brexit‚Äôs Northern Ireland Protocol.The draft budget had proposed a % increase in health spending in Northern Ireland, with ¬£ billion earmarked for services over the next three years.The plan would have left other departments facing some tough choices as a result of the % cash increase for the health budget.While none of the other departments would have seen a reduction in their baseline allocation from the last budget, they would have been % down on what they would have expected to receiveextra funding were not being erted to health.‚ÄúSince the resignation of the first minister I have considered all possible avenues that might have allowed me to proceed with a budget, including bringing it directly to the Assembly,‚Äù Mr Murphy told MLAs on Tuesday.‚ÄúUnfortunately, the legal advice is clear that the budget must be agreed by the executive.‚ÄúThis means that on April  the health service will not be able to plan on a three-year basis, nor will it be equipped with additional resources to invest in waiting lists, cancer services and mental health.‚ÄúIn these circumstances, rather than improving, the health service will decline.‚ÄùMr Murphy said he had decided to pause the public consultation exercise on the draft budget.‚ÄúLast week the Health Ministerapologised to people on waiting lists because without a multi-year budget, the opportunity to rebuild the health service would be ‚Äòcruelly taken away‚Äô,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThat analysis is sadly correct, although it should be the DUP apologising for the damage it is inflicting on the health service, not Minister Swann.‚ÄùOn the ability of spending hundreds of millions of carried over funds next year, Mr Murphy said: ‚ÄúDepartments cannot plan to make use of this additional ¬£ million in funding.‚ÄúInstead the money will sit idle, until such times as an executive is re-established.‚ÄùMr Murphy said he would make a ¬£ million in-year reallocation of Stormont funds to ensure the administration did not breach the limit of underspent cash it can carry over into the next financial year.This money will go to the departments of communities, education and infrastructure.‚ÄúHaving considered this matter at some , and taken legal advice, I intend to proceed to make allocations to these departments,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúI have written to ministers to ask them for their views on this course of action and have made clear to them that the alternative is that funding that could be used to support local people and services might instead be lost to the Treasury.‚ÄùMr Murphy also highlighted the need to provide match funding for community groups supported through the European Social Fund .He urged DUP Economy Minister Gordon Lyons to prioritise the ESF match funding from within his own budget.The draft budget had proposed a continuation of the current freeze on both the domestic and non-domestic regional rates for the next three years.Mr Murphy said that freeze could now only be continued for one year.‚ÄúThis freeze was intended to help with the rising costs being faced by families and businesses alike,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúOn the basis of legal advice, I can proceed with this freeze for one year only.‚ÄúThat means that households and businesses will not have certainty on their rates for the subsequent two years.‚ÄùMr Murphy said he would proceed with a proposed ¬£ million rate relief package for businesses.The package would deliver a three-month rates holiday for sectors hit hardest by the pandemic, retail, tourism, hospitality, leisure, childcare, newspapers and airports.‚ÄúThe executive should be on the cusp of agreeing a multi-year budget which prioritises health,‚Äù Mr Murphy added.‚ÄúIt should be deciding how to invest an additional ¬£ million next year for housing, for skills, for the police, and for ESF match funding.‚ÄúDue to the reckless actions of the DUP, this is not possible.‚ÄúInstead, public services will operate on an emergency basis, without the benefits of long-term planning or additional resources, until such times as the executive is re-established.‚ÄùMr Murphy‚Äôs appearance before MLAs witnessed some sharp exchanges with DUP members.DUP MLA Keith Buchanan accused the minister of ‚Äúamnesia‚Äù, highlighting that Sinn Fein pulled down the administration in  and left the region without a budget.‚ÄúMinister, I see in your statement the Democratic Unionist Partyhas been mentioned four times but strangely no mention of your own party when they pulled this entire Assembly down in early  ‚Äì no budget, no health support, no nothing,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúSurely a case of amnesia from the members on the far side of the house, purely for political gain.‚ÄúCan you and other parties not see the damage the Northern Ireland Protocol is doing to this place, are you blind to seeing that ‚ÄùMr Murphy insisted that the renewable heat incentivecontroversy that prompted the collapse of powersharing in  would have brought down any coalition government.He told Mr Buchanan: ‚ÄúYour party‚Äôs decision in order to scramble to save your own seatsis having very real consequences, a lot of them apparently unforeseen or not thought through by your party, is having very real consequences for the communities that we represent and you should own that yourself.‚ÄùA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: sinn fein ministers accused of sectarian decisions over stadium funding
story: Jim Allister denounces ‚Äòcolonialism‚Äô from the EU as News Letter sets out timeline of anti-Protocol battle   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‚Äòmaximise unionist votes‚Äô in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsSinn Fein ministers accused of ‚Äòsectarian decisions‚Äô over stadium fundingA decision to halt a scheme to upgrade football stadia while continuing the redevelopment of Casement Park has been branded ‚Äúsectarian‚Äù by a DUP MLA.By David Young, PATuesday, th February , : pm  "       "  Mason McGrandles and Caoimhin McBride play football beside Solitude which is home to Cltonville FC in north Belfast. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEyeFormer economy minister Paul Frew accused Sinn Fein‚Äôs Communities Minister Deirdre Hargey and Finance Minister Conor Murphy of making ‚Äúsectarian decisions‚Äù as he claimed they were treating one project dferently to the other.Mr Murphy responded by describing Mr Frew‚Äôs comments as an ‚Äúinsult‚Äù.‚ÄúNeither the GAA or the soccer fraternity are sectarian,‚Äù he said.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.North Antrim MLA Mr Frew raised the issue in exchanges with Mr Murphy in the Assembly chamber.On Monday, Ms Hargey told MLAs she would be unable to progress the ¬£. million programme to redevelop local sub-regional football stadia due to the absence of a ing executive.She claims while the funding has been secured for the initiative, the approval of the wider Executive is required before it can progress to allocating funding for projects at specic grounds.Ms Hargey has blamed the DUP for the situation, claiming the party‚Äôs decision to pull Paul Givan out of the first minister‚Äôs role meant the stadia programme had to be placed on hold until a ing administration is back in place.The DUP has disputed this position and contrasted it with the minister‚Äôs insistence that the redevelopment of the GAA‚Äôs Casement Park in west Belfast can continue despite the Stormont crisis.Both Ms Hargey and Mr Murphy moved on Tuesday to explain that the two projects were at dferent stages of progression, with the Casement redevelopment a live project that had been approved by the Executive, while the sub regional stadia programme had not reached the stage of identying what works would be undertaken.In the Assembly, Mr Frew accused the Sinn Fein ministers of ‚Äúplaying silly games‚Äù with the issue.‚ÄúThe sports regional sports stadium for football funding and the Casement Park funding has both been approved by this Executive,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúWhy has this finance minister and the communities minister made sectarian decisions to proceed with Casement Park, but to stop and halt the sports stadiums for football.‚ÄùIn response, Mr Murphy claimed the DUP had not thought through the consequences of collapsing the Executive.‚ÄúIn scrambling to defend your own seats you haven‚Äôt thought through what the impact of that will be, and the impact is going to be very, very real across a range of communities and sports stadia are one,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThe sub regional stadia have not identied any specic projects and would require to come back to the Executive for further approval.‚ÄúThe fact that you have collapsed the Executive means that all those clubs who are waiting on money will continue to wait on money until such times as you grow up and start to play at serious politics.‚ÄùAt a later press conference, Mr Murphy added: ‚ÄúTo try and describe that as sectarian is an insult.‚ÄùMinister Hargey insisted the funding for the programme was secure.The minister said while she would examine ‚Äúother ways‚Äù to progress the initiative, she was signicantly limited by the absence of an executive.‚ÄúI am ready to bring proposals forward before the end of this mandate,‚Äù she told BBC Radio Ulster.‚ÄúThe budget is there and I do think that it‚Äôs incumbent upon those other parties, particularly the DUP that chose to walk away, to look at that because this is the impact of their decision.‚ÄùFoyle DUP MLA Gary Middleton dismissed Minister Hargey‚Äôs comments.‚ÄúDeirdre Hargey has been in office for two years but has failed to deliver on an NDNAagreement to advance funding for football stadiums across Northern Ireland,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúThere is an Executive commitment on sub-regional stadia funding.‚ÄúThat could have been delivered upon at any time during the last two years, and it still should be delivered today.‚ÄúFor two years she has dithered, telling everyone that a result was just around the corner, but still today nothing has been delivered.‚Äù‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‚ÄîA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: uup rejects dup tuv policy to maximise unionist vote in election
story: Ruth Dudley Edwards: Doug Beattie‚Äôs engagement policy gets a boost from Alliance   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‚Äòmaximise unionist votes‚Äô in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPoliticsUUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‚Äòmaximise unionist votes‚Äô in Assembly electionThe UUP has rejected appeals by the DUP and TUV to urge unionist voters to cooperate with other unionist parties in the Assembly election.By Philip BradfieldMonday, th February , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th February , : pm  "       "  Last week DUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson and TUV leader Jim Allister revealed that they had agreed to ‚Äòcooperate‚Äô in the election and called for UUP leader Doug Beattie to join them.Mr Donaldson made the point during an anti-NI Protocol rally on Thursday in Dromore Orange Hall, Co Down.He said that ‚Äúwe are agreed that we will jointly call for all the people who vote for our parties to transfer their votes to pro-Union anti-protocol parties‚Äù.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.UUP party leader Doug Beattie had not defined the party position on the issue up until this point. Photo: Jonathan Porter PressEyeHe added: ‚ÄúWe have an opportunity in this election to maximise the number of unionists who are ed to the Assembly.‚ÄùFormer UUP chairman asks when party ‚Äòmoved away‚Äô from DUP-TUV position on transfer votes But, he said that what he wants to avoid is what happened in the last Assembly election. ‚ÄúI stood at the last Assembly election in this constituency and I watched, for the final seat in Lagan Valley, unionist transfers going to the SDLP and defeating a unionist candidate.‚ÄùMr Allister he would not define the agreement with the DUP as a pact. ‚ÄúI have said and he [Jeffrey] has said unionists should transfer to other anti-protocol unionists,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI‚Äôd like to see Doug Beattie say the same. TUV has always been clear that unionists need to vote down the ballot for all pro-Union candidates in the order of their preference. With the protocol a live issue this is all the more important.‚ÄúTUV will be making it clear during the campaign and in our election literature that after voting TUV electors should continue to vote for pro-Union, anti-protocol candidates.‚Äù The UUP declined to comment on on Friday but told the News Letter today it would not be adopting the DUP-TUV policy.A UUP spokesperson said: ‚ÄúWe are offering fresh leadership to Northern Ireland so we are asking people to vote for their Ulster Unionist Party Candidates. The Ulster Unionist Party believes the Northern Ireland electorate are more than capable of deciding for themselves who they should give their transfers to. ‚ÄúThey need to be trusted more and dictated to less. It is up to each party to set out their vision for Northern Ireland to attract first preference votes and transfers.‚ÄùThe issue of maximising unionist votes has come to the fore even more than usual as unionists discuss how to respond to claims from some polls that Sinn Fein could emerge as the largest single party in this election.This has caused intense debate about whether Sinn Fein could take the First Minister position for the first time.Loyalist activist Jamie Bryson responded: ‚ÄúThe party of Carson and Craig flatly refuse to encourage transfers to other unionists. This comes only a few short years after the ‚Äòvote Mike get Column‚Äô debacle whereby the UUP urged voters to transfer to the SDLP.‚ÄúIt is clear the soul of the once proud UUP has been taken captive by a small cabal of liberals who believe that Twitter is the real world and that the praise being heaped on them by nationalists will translate into votes. It‚Äôs madness.‚ÄùMORE NEWS:Former UUP chairman asks when party ‚Äòmoved away‚Äô from DUP-TUV position on transfer votes ‚ÄòChilling warning that stopped me selling explosives to the IRA‚Äô - ex-gangster John Lawson tells how he escaped a le of brutality and crimeDUP leader Sir Jeffrey Donaldson and TUV leader Jim Allister strike a deal to ‚Äòcooperate‚Äô at Assembly election call for UUP leader Doug Beattie to join themStorms Dudley and Eunice: Met Office amber weather warning of ‚Äòvery strong winds‚Äô across Northern Ireland over three daysA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: two storms on way to batter the province
story: Ruth Dudley Edwards: Doug Beattie‚Äôs engagement policy gets a boost from Alliance   UUP rejects DUP-TUV election deal to ‚Äòmaximise unionist votes‚Äô in Assembly electionNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsWeatherAdvice to homeowners as two storms about to batter Northern IrelandNorthern Ireland is set to be hit by two storms in three days as forecasters warn of up to mph winds.By Graeme CousinsTuesday, th February , : pmUpdated Tuesday, th February , : pm  "       "  The effects of Storm Dudley are likely to be felt in the Province tomorrow afternoon.A yellow warning for wind is in place for all of NI from pm tomorrow afternoon, changing to a more severe amber warning from pm for coastal regions to the north.The amber warning ends at am on Thursday, but the yellow wind warning for Northern Ireland extends until pm on Thursday when the storm is expected to dissipate.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Strong winds and waves hit the coast at Newcastle, Co Down during Storm Barra in December. Picture by Jonathan Porter PressEyeHowever another storm is expected to arrive just six hours laterin the shape of Storm Eunice bringing with it a yellow wind warning, lasting until pm on Friday.The Met Office said that the amber warning, which is unique for Northern Ireland, meant that road, rail, air and ferry services may be affected, and some roads and bridges are likely to close, leading to longer journey times and cancellations.A Met Office spokesperson said: ‚ÄúThere will probably be some fallen trees and damage to buildings, such as tiles blown from roofs‚ÄúThere is a good chance that power cuts may occur, with the potential to affect other services, such as mobile phone coverage.‚ÄùA fallen tree near Cushendun during Storm Barra. Pic Steven McAuley McAuley MultimediaPeople on the north coast, which is likely to be the worst affected, were warned to stay away from the sea front: ‚ÄúInjuries and danger to le is likely from large waves and beach material being thrown onto coastal roads, sea fronts and properties.‚ÄùMet Office chief meteorologist Paul Gundersen said an active jet stream is driving low-pressure systems across the UK, both of which are likely to cause some disruption.He said gusts of  to mph are possible on exposed coasts, with the strongest winds forecasts for Scotland.The Met Office told people that unless their journey was absolutely necessary they should stay indoors during the storms.Before the storms hit they advised people to:‚Ä¢ Secure loose objects such as ladders, garden furniture or anything  that could be blown into windows and other glazing and break them‚Ä¢ Close and securely fasten doors and windows, particularly those on the windward side of the house, and especially large doors such as those on garages‚Ä¢ Park vehicles in a garage,available otherwise keep them clear of buildings, trees, walls and fences‚Ä¢ Close and secure loft trapdoors with bolts, particularlyroof pitch is less than ¬∞‚Ä¢ If the house is fitted with storm shutters over the windows then ensure that these are closed and fastened‚Ä¢ If chimney stacks are tall and in poor condition, move beds away from areas directly below them‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‚ÄîA message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. It comes in behind Pembrokeshire at first place with  beaches, Devon with , Cornwall with  and Anglesey with .The research comes as people are looking to continue to holiday at home as Wales and the UK begins to re-open and international travel is still looking unsure. It was carried out by Uswitch and can be viewed here: https:www.uswitch car-insurance guides uk-dog-friendly-beaches-mapped In their list of  beaches from across the UK, Ogmore Beach comes in third place behind Cayton Bay in North Yorkshire and Oxwich Beach near Swansea.MORE NEWS:Coronavirus: One in three adults in Wales now fully vaccinatedDream seaside home has seven bedrooms and an amazing al-fresco entertaining areaLaurence Llewellyn-Bowen joins campaign to transform oldest Vale homeThe Uswitch guide says that Ogmore Beach is best for fishing, walking and dog-friendly pubs and the car park costs ¬£ a day, with dogs allowed on the beach all-year round and there are no restrictions. They say that the beach is a sand and shingle beach and has a reputation for being one of the cleanest in the region. There is a coastal walk, chance to go fishing, surfing and views of Tusker Rock.For those owners who may not yet have ventured to the beach with their pups or are concerned about behaviour while at the beach, Wood Green‚Äôs dog behaviour and training specialist, Wendy Kruger, has provided some tips to prepare your dog for the beach.‚Ä¢ Ensure your dog‚Äôs microchip and collar tag details are up to date ‚Äì just in case.‚Ä¢ Get used to checking ground surface temperatures before you take your dog out, as dry sand can be too hot for dogs‚Äô paws on sunny days. To check the ground temperature, place the back of your hand on the ground. If its too hot to hold comfortably for five seconds, it‚Äôs too hot for dogs‚Äô paws..remove‚Ä¢ Practise basic, reward-based training when out and about to help your dog to maintain focus and engagement on walks.‚Ä¢ Recall is also an area that needs particular attention. Evenyour dog has a great recall at home, its not something that can be guaranteed in unfamiliar environments with exciting new distractions. title: vale author details history welsh pubs new book
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityGraham Loveluck-Edwards has announced the release of his new book Historic Pubs of Wales where he relishes in some of the more colourful myths, legends and stories from Wales ancient past and oldest pubs.¬†Included in the book is The Captains We, in Sully,¬†a house originally owned by a captain.¬†"I have always loved old pubs, and we are blessed to have so many belters here in Wales," added Mr Loveluck-Edwards.¬†Graham Loveluck-Edwards out snapping some pubs for his book"For example, the pub which claims to have an elephant buried under its beer garden, or the pub where funeral parties take a short cut to the cemetery through the bar to keep an ancient right of access alive, or the pub that claims to have invented pancake day and so many more.¬†"In all, Ive compiled over  incredible stories based around  amazing old pubs - is there any truth to them "Some for sure, but this book captures them and puts them in the context of history so you can be the judge."MORE NEWS:The book also contains a travel guide so readers can go on a tour around Wales and visit all the pubs in the book.You can find out more at www.talesfromhistoricpubsofwales.¬†¬†The book is available to buy now"As you can imagine for such a book the research was relentless and thorough, and a lot of fun," he added."Pubs have had such a tough time in the last year with us going in and out of lockdowns and with the introduction of social distancing measures.¬†"Sixteenth century¬†inns are usually a warren of tiny rooms so being two metres apart has made opening and trading near impossible for many.¬†"So, a book which celebrates all that is great about our old pubs, which tells people their history, where to find them and what to expect when you get there has been welcomed by all landlords." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - title: county ecologist nature emergency talk q penarth
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe event will focus on the nature emergency which affects Penarth and the rest ltspan classtruncategtltspan classtruncate-previewgtof the world lt spangtlt spangtlt spangt" Penarth group to host first event in nearly two years - what you need to knowThe event will be at St Augustines Hall in Penarth " Skip to next photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentPENARTH Civic Society is able to promote events in the town again ‚Äì after nearly two years of being unable to.Penarth Civic Society is an independent, non-political, voluntary organisation which campaigns for the protection and enhancement of Penarth ‚Äì including the heritage and culture of the town.Due to the Covid pandemic events have been put on hold for nearly two years ‚Äì but now the society is able to promote their first event of .The event, led by Colin Cheeseman, will be focused on ‚ÄòResponding to a Nature Emergency ‚Äì what is happening ‚ÄôIt will be hosted at St Augustine‚Äôs Hall, on Albert Road in Penarth, from pm on Thursday, February .Mr Cheeseman is the county ecologist for the Vale of Glamorgan Council and will give a presentation on his work, projects he is involved with and the aspirations of the council to combat the nature and climate emergencies.He will also talk about the effect of recent legislation on how councils are now required to be more proactive on all things ecological. Following this informative talk there will be a question-and-answer session.Although Covid restrictions have eased there will be measures in place to protect those attending the event.People are asked to book in advance and wear a face covering during the meeting ‚Äì unless exempt. Anyone who has symptoms of Covid, has tested positive for Covid, or has been identied as a close contact of someone with the virus should not attend.To ensure there is a degree of social distancing at the event in St Augustine‚Äôs Hall the maximum number of people allowed to attend is .Booking is preferred via e-mail, but people who do not have e-mail access can leave a message on the answerphone ‚Äì contact details for both are listed below.Entry to ‚ÄòResponding to a Nature Emergency ‚Äì what is happening ‚Äô at St Augustine‚Äôs Hall from pm on February  is free for members of Penarth Civic Society or ¬£ for non-members.E-mail: enquiries@penarthsociety.org.ukAnswerphone:  . article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: smacking ban wales need know
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe law changes on Monday, March , removing the legal defence of reasonable punishment and opening the possibility for anyone who smacks a child to be prosecuted for assault.The Welsh Government passed the law change two years ago, seeing off opposition in the Senedd to win a vote - on what was described as a ‚Äúlandmark day for children in Wales‚ÄùThe government said the law change would help ‚Äúprotect children and their rights, and give them the best start in le‚Äù. By banning smacking, ministers argue children in Wales are now given the same protections from assault as adults.Physical punishmentis "not a necessary part of disciplining children" and "doesn‚Äôt help children learn about self-control or appropriate behaviour", the Welsh Government advises, adding that such punishments can hurt children and¬†give them the message violence is an "appropriate response to strong feelings".The new law will apply to everyone in Wales, including visitors, and ¬£. million is being invested in parenting support services.Advice and support for parents and s is available on the Welsh Government‚Äôs Give It Time website https:gov.wales parenting-give-it-time.Children‚Äôs charities like Barnardo‚Äôs Cymru and the NSPCC have supported the law change, but the ban has not been welcomed universally.As well as some opposition in the Senedd, mainly from the Welsh Conservatives, a campaign group called Be Reasonable argued the move would ‚Äúinevitably catch ordinary, loving parents and turn them into criminals‚Äù, and their petition against the government‚Äôs proposals collected nearly , signatures in Wales.And the Welsh Government‚Äôs own studies suggest members of the public are equally ided over the issue.Researchers carried out three surveys between  and  to gauge public opinion on banning the physical punishment of children..removeWhile support for a smacking ban grew in , research shows that level fell slightly a year later. If anything, people‚Äôs opinions have become less rigid, with more people in  than in previous years saying they would need more information before deciding whether they agreed with the law change.Among those members of the public who said they supported a smacking ban in the last survey, more than one-thirdsaid they did not agree generally with the physical punishment of children.Other common reasons for supporting the ban included the belief there were other good forms of ensuring good behaviour and discipline , and the belief smacking was abuse, or could lead to abuse .Meanwhile, one in four peoplewho said they opposed the smacking ban in the most recent survey did so because they believed physical punishment was needed to control behaviour, the discipline a child, to teach respect or to show boundaries.Other common reasons for opposing the law change included the belief smacking doesn‚Äôt do any harm‚Äì including cases when people said it hadn‚Äôt done themselves or their own children any harm ‚Äì and that smacking was OKit was a reasonable punishment and doesn‚Äôt go too far.Not everyone who smacks a child from March  will be automatically prosecuted. Wales four police forces have been encouraged to consider a "rehabilitative alternative to prosecution"this is more appropriate."In cases where the police decide it is appropriate to offer an out of court disposal, there will be an option of tailored parenting support to encourage positive parenting techniques and help avoid re-offending," the government has advised.Those parenting support schemes will be offered by councils. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: plea rethink decision merging penarth nursery primary school
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityBute Cottage Nursery is set to merge with Evenlode Primary under Vale of Glamorgan council plans opposed by hundreds.The council‚Äôs cabinet was urged to rethink the merger, with some councillors claiming not enough attention was given to a public consultation where most people opposed the plan.Cllr George Carroll, leader of the Conservative group on the Vale council, called in the merger decision to be looked at by the learning and culture scrutiny committee.He said: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a clear and signicant majority of consultees who were opposed to this proposal. Insufficient consideration was made regarding those consultations responses.‚ÄùThe scrutiny committee, which met on Thursday, February , also heard from parents, governors and trade union representatives about their concerns over the merger.Richard Disley, chair of governors at Bute Cottage, said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs been dficult to get our voices heard during this process. Our concerns have always been about the wellbeing of our staff. If the amalgamation happens, the current positions of the majority of nursery staff are only guaranteed for  months.‚ÄúLong-serving permanent staff members who are in our current budget have job stability, will now only have guaranteed work for  months. Staff haven‚Äôt been offered any support from the local authority during this very stressful time.‚ÄúBute Cottage should be held up as an example of how things should be done, not merged into a primary school with the sole purpose of fitting into a ‚Äì year model, for which there is no proof of improved outcomes for children. We have asked for evidence on a number of occasions but none has been forthcoming.‚ÄùKate Rees, a parent whose children went to Bute Cottage, said: ‚ÄúIt was disappointing that there wasn‚Äôt more consideration for the issues we raised. Bute Cottage has its own headteacher, budget, governing body, and specialist staff. Those are the magic ingredients that come together to create the exceptional setting for education..remove‚ÄúI have three children. All three of them were lucky enough to go to Bute Cottage, and they all attend Evenlode now, and Bute Cottage was just a really wonderful experience for them. I got to know that nursery really well. Because of that I‚Äôm absolutely passionate about the provision there.‚ÄùConcerns over the merger include the possible relocation of the nursery to the Evenlode Primary School site, although this would be several years away and only a potential move and a change in the teaching style. The Vale council has said the merger would help provide continuity and stability for pupils to attend the same school from three to eleven years.Cllr Rhiannon Birch said the concerns were overblown and ‚Äúdisappointing‚Äù, and added high teaching standards would be kept after the merger.She said: ‚ÄúThey will have the same staff, there will be the same guiding ethos, there will be the same standards of professionalism. To hear some of these speakers, you would think these children are going to be put in a field to poke each other with sticks, rather than having an education.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs very disappointing their lack of trust in teaching professionals who will continue to maintain high standards, to provide pastoral care, education and all the dferent aspects of nursery education. It seems to me incredible to believe that all of this should be going out of the window simply because we‚Äôre talking about the governing body.‚ÄùCllr Lis Burnett, cabinet member for education, said no changes to staff will be made as part of the merger, which would be restricted to how the school and nursery are governed.She said: ‚ÄúA consultation is not a referendum. It‚Äôs where we listen to views to see whether there‚Äôs any reason why the agreed policy ‚Ä¶ should not be applied. The nurseries would only be merged at a governance and leadership level, and there would be no change to where they‚Äôre operating. Those nurseries are not moving.‚ÄúThere will be no change to staffing or surroundings. There‚Äôs no reason to think that anything in terms of teaching and standards of learning in these schools will be altered in any way at all.‚ÄùAsked about a potential future feasibility study into relocating the nursery next to Evenlode, she said: ‚ÄúBecause you would want to see whether you have the best model, and whether it would be betterit were on one site. I‚Äôm on record as saying I don‚Äôt think it would be feasible.‚ÄúBut there were comments of people who don‚Äôt have cars, who live in the Evenlode catchment area, and actually walk from lower Penarth up to the nursery every day and back.‚ÄúSo you have to do a feasibility [study], to see whether or not that would work. But there is such a workload on the st Century Schools team, that unless it was prioritised, it would be a number of years before we could even look at it with the amount of other work.‚ÄùIf approved, the merger of the nursery and the primary school would take effect in September this year. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: bike repair stations penarth vale glamorgan
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityVale of Glamorgan Council, with Public Health Wales funding, has set-up the stations to encourage people to use active travel.The equipment is hard-wearing to ensure that they are vandal-proof, with cyclists able to use the free facilities to repair bikes with air pumpsand tools.Within Penarth the bike repair stations are at Penarth leisure centre and Cosmeston Country Park.Elsewhere in the Vale of Glamorgan, the bike repair stations are at:Alexandra GardensBarry Island car parkBarry leisure centreColcot sports centreCowbridge leisure centreLlantwit Major leisure centreLlantwit Major beach car parkMurchfield community centre.The council is also working to install a station at Colwinston community centre in Cowbridge and Porthkerry Country Park in Barry.This scheme links closely to the Council‚Äôs Project Zero initiative, which aims to reduce their carbon emissions to net zero by .It also aligns with the Vale of Glamorgan‚Äôs Move More Eat Well plan objectives to encourage healthier lestyles.Cabinet member for neighbourhood services and transport, Cllr Peter King, said:¬†‚ÄúIt is great to see the Vale‚Äôs new bicycle repair stations open for the public to use.‚ÄúWith more and more residents using their bikes, it is important to us that we implement schemes and facilities to make their journeys as smooth and enjoyable as possible.‚ÄúEncouraging active travel is a key part of our Project Zero Strategy, the Council‚Äôs commitment to tackle climate change.‚ÄùPeople who would like to see a bicycle repair station in their area of the Vale of Glamorgan, can e-mail activetravel@valeofglamorgan.gov.uk article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url title: per cent wales support four day working week
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityA study revealed that the sht to shorter hours could boost mental health, help more people provide care to elderly relatives and create almost , new public sector jobs.Research led by Wales‚Äô Future Generations Commissioner Sophie Howe found  per cent¬†of the public would like a shorter working weekthere was no decrease in salary.Ms Howe‚Äôs role is to protect the interests of future generations, and was created after Wales passed the Wellbeing of Future Generations Act in April .She is now calling on the Government to pilot a four-day working week in parts of the public sector.It found  per cent¬†of the Welsh public would support the sharing out of work to ensure everyone can have a better work-le balance.A further  per cent¬†would support Wales‚Äô Government piloting a scheme to assess the feasibility of a four-day working week.The research, conducted in partnership with economic think-tank Autonomy, found that as well as public support, a move to shorter hours could create , public sector jobs in Wales.It would cost an estimated ¬£ billion, the equivalent of . per cent¬†of Wales‚Äô current public sector spending.The study also cited evidence that a cut in the volume of people commuting can help slash carbon emissions.It pointed to research that found Cardf and Port Talbot have poorer air quality than Birmingham or Manchester due to the number of people that travel by car.The commissioner also wants private sector firms to be supported in transitioning to shorter hours.Ms Howe said: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs clear that following the pandemic, people across Wales are re-evaluating their priorities in le and looking for a healthier work-le balance.‚ÄúThe escalating demands of caring for loved-ones due to an ageing population and an increase in mental health issues exacerbated by working long hours are just some of the factors which make a shorter working week more appealing.‚Äù.removeMs Howe added: ‚ÄúA shorter working week can result in increased productivity which will be of huge benefit to employers for a happier, healthier workforce.‚ÄúThe working week has not changed for more than  years, and now seems the perfect opportunity for the Welsh Government to commit to a pioneering trial and build evidence for greater change across Wales.‚ÄùWill Stronge, co-director of Autonomy, said: ‚ÄúAll the evidence suggests that a shorter working week with no loss of pay would be a win-win for both workers and employers in Wales.‚ÄúCountries across the world including Scotland and Ireland have already launched four-day week trials and a radical Welsh Government should be leading the way on this too.‚ÄúMoving to a four-day week would boost productivity and workers‚Äô wellbeing, and create tens of thousands of new jobs in the Welsh public sector. The potential benefits are too large to ignore.‚ÄùThe research is published in the report A Future Fit for Wales: The roadmap to a shorter working weekGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: cost living households wales getting  payment
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityWales‚Äô minister for finance and local government, Rebecca Evans, said the government is ‚Äúmore than doubling the equivalent support provided by the UK Government‚Äù for those most in need, as it aims to ensure ‚Äúno-one is left behind‚Äù.The Welsh Government has announced what it described as a package of expanded measures to help people amid rising prices, including a ¬£ cost-of-living payment to be paid as soon as possible and an extra ¬£ for low-income households through the winter fuel payment next winter.The ¬£ payment will be available to all households who live in properties in council tax bands A-D, as well as those in receipt of the Council Tax Reduction Scheme in all bands.The devolved government said it will be working with local authorities to provide more detail about how the scheme will operate and will start making payments as soon as possible.It said a further ¬£ million will be made available as a discretionary fund, allowing councils to use their local knowledge to help households who might be struggling.The government added that in - more than ¬£ million will be provided to strengthen other schemes that help people meet the rising costs of living.More funds will be allocated through the discretionary assistance fund ‚Äì which helps people pay for essential costs such as food, electricity, clothing and emergency travel ‚Äì and the winter fuel support scheme, which will deliver an additional ¬£ later this year to hundreds of thousands of low-income households, the government said.Ms Evans, of Welsh Labour, said: ‚ÄúPeople are facing a very real cost-of-living crisis and urgent, meaningful action is required.‚ÄúThe Chancellor‚Äôs offer at the start of the month fell short of what people needed. We have been able to go above and beyond to provide Welsh households with more help in paying bills, heating homes and putting food on the table..remove‚ÄúIn total we are more than doubling the equivalent support provided by the UK Government for those who need it the most, reflecting our priority of creating a fairer Wales in which no-one is left behind.‚ÄùEarlier this month, Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced ¬£ of support for households across England to deal with rising energy bills over the year from April .Some ¬£ of the support will take the form of a council tax rebate for all ratepayers in council tax bands A to D.The Treasury also announced that devolved governments in Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland would be given a total of ¬£ million extra funding to carry out the same measure.Last week Wales‚Äô first minister Mark Drakeford said there was ‚Äúno extra money for Wales‚Äù from the Treasury to provide the rebate.His claim came after the UK Government‚Äôs Welsh secretary accused the devolved Welsh Government of leaving its taxpayers ‚Äúunclear‚Äù about whether they would be getting a ¬£ council tax rebate to help with energy bills.Jane Hutt, minister for social justice in Wales, said: ‚ÄúThe funding we are announcing today will ensure more people get more support, in what are challenging circumstances for so many families in Wales.‚ÄúAs bills rise, prices go up and wages are stretched we know people will need help, that‚Äôs why I‚Äôve convened a Wales-wide Cost of Living Summit on Thursday  February, with over  participants from a wide range of social partners and third sector organisations across Wales to discuss the crisis and the proactive actions we can take to support people across Wales.‚ÄúAddressing the cost-of-living crisis remains a crucial priority for this Government and we will continue to consider all the options available to us.‚Äù article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net title: royal mint launches  years fa cup commemorative coin
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe collectable ¬£ coin features the iconic FA Cup trophy at the heart of the design and will take centre stage for the coin toss at the Emirates FA Cup Final at Wembley on May .Designed by artists Matt Dent and Christian Davies, the trophy appears in miniature on the ¬£ coin.It is etched with celebratory ribbon alongside the words ‚Äòcelebrating  years of The FA Cup‚Äô. On the highly secure milled edge of ¬£ coin is the inscription ‚Äòfootball‚Äôs greatest cup competition‚Äô, a further nod to the landmark celebration of football‚Äôs longest-running knockout competition." alt"Penarth Times: " class"editor-image" The coin can be purchased in a range of base and precious metal finishers and is sure to be a hit with both sports lovers and coin collectors.A silver version, with a certicate of authenticity baring the number , will be minted to the highest Proof standard for the coin toss in May.¬†The Royal Mint‚Äôs Director of Commemorative Coin Clare Maclennan said: ‚ÄúThe Emirates FA Cup is an iconic footballing competition that has enabled clubs across the country to dream of lting the coveted trophy for  years. In what is an extra special season for everyone involved in the game, we are thrilled to be working with The FA and celebrating the th anniversary of the much-loved competition with a commemorative ¬£ coin. Designed with the trophy at its heart, it is fitting that the coin will be used for the coin toss during Final at Wembley in May.‚Äù¬†The FA‚Äôs Head of Player Status and Competitions, David Newton, said: ‚ÄúThe parallels between The Royal Mint‚Äôs traditional craftsmanship and innovations, and the Emirates FA Cup‚Äôs rich history and evolution over the years mean that this special coin is an incredibly fitting celebration of the competition‚Äôs th anniversary season. We are delighted that it will be used for the Final‚Äôs coin toss and fans across the country now have the chance to take home their very own piece of silverware to savour for years to come.‚Äù.removeYou can find more information about the collection at The Royal website here.¬† ¬†Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. photo Show caption  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl" href" my account emailthispage " s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentA PENARTH business has been rated as one of the top  most-loved local businesses in the UK.Queen B Boutique, a womens clothing shop, made the annual Love Local Day list from Shopappy this year.The list takes nominations from more than  locations in the UK and publishes their top  every Valentines Day.The entry on the Shopappy website says: "One of the many nominations read ‚Ä¶for me it‚Äôs the friendliness of the staff and their knowledge of what would suit you and what would not, they are honest, kind and just amazing, they work so hard and kept everyone going and updated through the pandemic and went above and beyond, well done."The owner of the shop, Jodie Tanner, said: "It was a surreal moment."When you get told that youve been nominated as one of the top  in the UK it feels a bit grand really."Its amazing,¬†Im absolutely thrilled to bits.":Queen B Boutique has been in business for  years and specialises in occasion wear, although they do sell casual clothing as well.Started as a hobby, Ms Tanner said that the business has now "taken over [her] le".Ms Tanner said: "I think¬†the crux of it is that we love our customers."As a business owner¬†that gets encouraged from the top,¬†the team are so super friendly."Were very honest, so we we build great relationships with our clients, its not just pop in and buy something and we never see them again.¬†"I think¬†our loyalty to them and what we deliver to them is¬†delivered back in turn."Throughout the pandemic, the shop made great effort to keep in touch with their customers and to do their bit for charity.Amongst other things, every week they hosted bonkers bingo online for customers with all proceeds going to ious charities..removeThey also hosted live fashion shows on Thursdays which were filmed in a closed unit of the shop and put online so customers could feel like they were having a night out.Ms Tanner said: "Were just coming out of that time now and customers havent forgotten that."I feel almost its like their recognition or their reward to¬†me for perhaps what weve delivered to them in lockdown in a very dficult time for everybody."Queen B Boutique can be¬† found on Stanwell Road in Penarth and a second shop can be found on the High Street in Barry.There is also an online store and their main website can be found¬†hereGet involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--ByThis website and associated newspapers title: john mcguinness hints retirement isle man tt
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe -year-old, who collected an MBE for services to motorcycle racing at Windsor Castle on Tuesday, said the race in May ‚Äì which he has won  times ‚Äì could be his last.Speaking after the ceremony, the motorsport champion told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúLast time I raced there I didn‚Äôt have a great TT and I didn‚Äôt want to finish my racing career on a breakdown so this, never said it before, could possibly be my last TT but I wanted to just go there with everything, you know, all the i‚Äôs dotted and t‚Äôs crossed and go and enjoy it and see where we end up.‚ÄùMcGuinness, from Morecambe, Lancashire, added that riders were ‚Äúa little bit nervous‚Äù about the race following a break during the pandemic.He said: ‚ÄúGetting back to racing, we‚Äôre all a little bit nervous, all us riders especially.‚ÄúWe did some racing through Covid but not the road racing like in the Isle of Man so we‚Äôve all been away for two years.‚ÄúThe bikes are getting faster, none of us have been there so we‚Äôre all nervous, there‚Äôs a lot of anticipation but, you watch, once we get there it will be flat out, it will be mph, we‚Äôll be doing what we do but, you know, it‚Äôs leading up to my  starts ‚Äì my century of starts ‚Äì I‚Äôll be  years old, which is probably one of the oldest on the grid, it‚Äôs  years of anniversary of the Honda Fireblade, which I ride, so there‚Äôs loads of little boxes being ticked.‚ÄùThe racer attended the ceremony with his we Becky and said collecting the MBE from the Princess Royal was ‚Äúthe icing on the cake‚Äù of his career.He said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really pleased, proud of it really, family‚Äôs proud, kids are proud, can‚Äôt wait to get home and show it them title: statistical look womens test cricket england host south africa june
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityIt will be another welcome outing in a rare format for female players and here, the PA news agency takes a statistical look at women‚Äôs Test cricket.Slow decade vw,vw,px, px"Opportunities for Test action have been limited in the women‚Äôs game There have been only  women‚Äôs Test matches in the last  years, with the format grinding to a virtual halt.All  of those have involved either England , Australiaor India , with South Africa the only other nation to feature when they took on India in November .Since a relative peak between  and , with  games in those four years including five separate two-Test series,  and  are the only years to see more than one Test played.This year will join that list but there were none at all in , , ,  or, more understandably given the Covid- pandemic, .There have been only  women‚Äôs Tests ever ‚Äì including two abandoned without a ball bowled ‚Äì since the first one in  between England and Australia.England Womens summer  fixtures have landed!Details and ticket information ‚¨áÔ∏è‚Äî England CricketFebruary , Those two nations lead the way in terms of involvement with England playing in almost two-thirds of all women‚Äôs Tests, , and Australia in .New Zealand and India have played  and  respectively, while South Africa‚Äôs outing in Taunton this summer will be their th and take them one ahead of the West Indies.No other nation has played more than Pakistan‚Äôs three, with Sri Lanka alongside Ireland and Holland in playing a solitary Test. Among Test-playing nations in men‚Äôs cricket, Bangladesh, Zimbabwe and Afghanistan have never played a women‚Äôs Test.The case for five daysThere has been an increasing push in recent months, intensying since the thrilling drawn Test in the Women‚Äôs Ashes, for Tests to be played over five days as in men‚Äôs cricket, rather than four..removeWhen that match ended after four days with all four results possible until the closing overs, it concluded a fth successive drawn women‚Äôs Test ‚Äì a figure which accounts for all fixtures since Australia‚Äôs win over England in August .That is not a new problem, as  per cent of all women‚Äôs Tests excluding the two abandonments have been drawn ‚Äì , compared to only  producing a positive result.An incredible Test match ends in a draw.#Ashes | #AUSvENG pic hTzVkHPaa‚Äî England CricketJanuary , New Zealand and India lead the way with draw percentages in the s, with the White Ferns drawing  out of  Tests and India  out of .Australia‚Äôs win ratio of  per cent is the highest in the format, at least among those to play more than once, while they are alongside England on a record  wins with no other nation managing more than five.One encouraging sign for June‚Äôs match is that six of South Africa‚Äôs previous  Tests have ended in a result, albeit with a solitary win and five defeats.The International Cricket Council‚Äôs laws state that the duration of women‚Äôs Test matches is four days. They do allow for the possibility of a reserve dayan entire day‚Äôs play is lost but play cannot take place on more than four days..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: A statistical look at women us Test cricket as England host South Africa in June article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: golda film producer admits stirring jewish casting controversy
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe -year-old, who honoured for services to the film industry, said the controversy over his latest picture, Golda, a biopic about Israeli first female PM Golda Meir,¬†was good for publicity.The lead, the character of Meir, who was Jewish, is played by Dame Helen Mirren." data-title"Golda Meir " data--holder"PA Archive" data--notice"PA Archive PA Images" data-credit"PA" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production bfdcaedbeYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjQMDMOTk ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Golda Meir Mr Kuhn said he made the confession to the Princess Royal as he collected his CBE at an investiture ceremony at Windsor Castle on Tuesday.The -year-old told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúI just mentioned about the film I‚Äôm finishing now with Helen Mirren and she obviously knew about all the controversy there had been with ‚Äòcan a non-Jew play a Jew‚Äô and I told her I was stirring it as much as I could for publicity and she seemed quite amused by that.‚ÄùActor Dame Maureen Lipman criticised the casting, the Jewish Chronicle reported." data-title"Helen Mirren as Golda Meir" data--holder"PA Media" data--notice"PA Media" data-credit"Jasper Wolf Assemble publicity" data-usage-terms"PICTURE DESK USE ONLY. title: starmer pm needs get house order dirty russian cash
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityThe Labour leader also called for the Government to ‚Äúgo now and go hard‚Äù with sanctions against Russia, as he said the Prime Minister shouldall ‚ÄúRussian-linked‚Äù donations to the Conservative party over the last  years.Sir Keir made the comments after the Prime Minister announced a new Economic Crime Bill would ‚Äúhit companies‚Äù laundering Kremlin-linked Russian money through Britain.It comes after Foreign Secretary Liz Truss said UK sanctionsMoscow invades Ukraine would be severe in targeting ‚Äúoligarchs‚Äù and ‚Äúcompanies across Russia‚Äù.Sir Keir said Labour ‚Äústands united‚Äù with the Government against Russian aggression, but also said: ‚ÄúFor a decade, the Tories have not just failed to challenge Russian influence ‚Äì they have enabled it.‚ÄùHe added: ‚ÄúIf Boris Johnson is now serious about tackling Russian dirty money and influence, he should immediately get his own house in order.‚ÄúThat means ing the millions of pounds of Russian-linked cash that has been donated to the Tories and their MPs since he became Prime Minister, and reversing his plans to allow unlimited donations from abroad.‚ÄùSir Keir also called for the Government to take other steps to limit the spread of corrupt cash, including reforming Companies House, creating a register of overseas entities and a register of foreign agents, and bringing forward new counter-espionage laws.In an interview with Channel  News, Sir Keir added: ‚ÄúWe should go now and hard with the sanctions.‚ÄúIt is important, I should say that we stand united with our allies in the face of Russian aggression. It‚Äôs very important we stand united in the United Kingdom in the face of Russian aggression. ‚ÄùConservative MPs were also critical of what they have perceived to be a lack of action on honing in on Russian money being invested in the UK..removeBob Seely, a member of the Commons Foreign Affairs Committee , said Britain was ‚Äúa decade behind the times‚Äù on the threat posed by Russian financial influence.We need a long-term and coherent plan and a strategy to deal with a dangerous world. Our states need to understand how neo-authoritarian states use the full spectrum of state power military, economic, energy, espionage, political, etc. We are not there yet.  ‚Äî Bob Seely MPFebruary , The Isle of Wight MP told the PA news agency: ‚ÄúOn Russia, we have known about this problem for years.‚ÄúThe problem is that the front line with Ukraine is the border, the front line with Germany is the gas pipeline ‚Äì and the front line with the UK is the City of London.‚ÄúWe need to be wiser about how the Putin regime acts and the potential threat to our institutions and values, and how we can protect them against a potential tsunami of questionable money.‚ÄùMr Seely also said any legislation should be widely targeted enough to incorporate the growing threat posed by China.FAC chairman Tom Tugendhat said it was time to clean out money from British politics that had originated in Russia.‚ÄúFrankly, get it out and get it out now,‚Äù he told Times Radio.There was cross-party agreement that the changes being proposed in the Government‚Äôs economic crime legislation had been needed well before the crisis with Ukraine developed.Senior Labour MP Chris Bryant, who is also an FAC member, told PA: ‚ÄúThis should have been in place before this whole saga, not after.‚ÄúTalk about the horse having bolted.‚ÄùMr Bryant said warnings about Russian money had come from the Foreign Affairs Committee in  with its Moscow‚Äôs Gold report, as well as ‚Äôs Intelligence and Security Committee report on Russian influence in Britain‚Äôs democracy.He added: ‚ÄúIt is like the Prime Minister has finally woken up to contraception the day after conception.‚ÄùBut the Prime Minister, speaking after a Cobra meeting about Ukraine and Russia border tensions, defended the UK‚Äôs record on tackling Russian monetary influence at home.He told broadcasters: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think that it‚Äôs fair to say the UK hasn‚Äôt done a huge amount on dirty money, whether it‚Äôs from Russia or anywhere .‚ÄùMr Johnson added: ‚ÄúWhat we want to do is strengthen now the package that we have, strengthen the measures we have against potential ill-gotten Russian money, whether here or anywhere for‚Ä¶ which we have responsibility, with new measures that will hit the companies and concerns that I‚Äôve talked about.‚ÄúBut also open up the Matryoshka doll,you like ‚Äì you know what I‚Äôm talking about ‚Äì so that we see ‚Ä¶ who really owns the companies that we‚Äôre talking about, who really owns the properties that we‚Äôre talking about, and those measures, yes, we will be bringing forward from the Economic Crime Bill.‚ÄùHe signalled that the Bill would be brought forward in the next Queen‚Äôs Speech..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Starmer: PM needs to  uget his title: rail services end early scotland prepares storm dudley
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityScotRail announced on Tuesday its services would end early on Wednesday due to Storm Dudley, the forecast for which has led to the Met Office issuing an amber weather warning for the north of England and the central belt and south of Scotland.Gusts could rise as high as  miles per hour in coastal areas, with the amber warning due to come into force at pm tomorrow and expire at midnight, when it will be downgraded to a yellow warning until am on Thursday.Storm Dudley will be immediately followed by Storm Eunice later this week.‚ö†Ô∏èTHREAD: Scotland is bracing itself for #StormDudley tomorrow. The welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most @ScotRail train services will shut down from  on Wednesday .   pic QGGxZWpFA‚Äî ScotRailFebruary , Deputy First Minister John Swinney said the weather could cause disruption to travel and power supplies as well as danger from falling trees.‚ÄúWe expect another period of disruption this week, with Storms Dudley and Eunice set to bring strong winds to Scotland,‚Äù he said.‚ÄúHigh winds may cause issues on roads and bridges, disruption to power supplies and danger from falling trees. We would urge everyone to plan their journeys in advance, exercise caution on the roads, and follow the latest travel advice.‚ÄùFollowing a meeting of the Scottish Government‚Äôs Resilience Room, the Deputy First Minister said they would continue to monitor the situation as the storms approach.Services running in the far north, Kyle of Lochalsh, and Aberdeen-Inverness lines will continue to run as usual because the areas are outside the boundaries of the weather warning.‚ÄúScotland is bracing itself for Storm Dudley tomorrow,‚Äù the rail operator said on Twitter.‚ÄúThe welfare of our customers and staff is most important, so for safety reasons most ScotRail train services will shut down from  on Wednesday.‚Äù.removeThe RNLI warned adverse weather conditions could make seas ‚Äútreacherous‚Äù, urging people to take extra care in coastal areas.‚ÄúThe expected storms could make our seas treacherous, increasing the risk for those visiting the coast around the UK and Ireland,‚Äù RNLI national water safety partner, Samantha Hughes, said.‚ÄúIn a normal year, around  people lose their lives at the coast and we know that more than half of those never intended to be in the water.‚ÄúSo, whether you are walking, running or cycling at the coast, please be extra responsible and avoid taking unnecessary risk or entering the water.‚ÄúIn particular, we ask people to stay well back from stormy, wintery seas and clf edges, check tide times before you go, take a phone with you, and call  or  and ask for the Coastguardyou or someone  is in trouble.‚ÄùMeanwhile, the Woodland Trust Scotland urged people to stay away from wooded areas during the high winds.‚ÄúPlease do not enter woodland when winds are high and be cautious when entering woodland after a storm,‚Äù said spokesman, George Anderson.He added: ‚ÄúEven fully toppled trees are best avoided when newly felled as they are often not completely settled and still have the potential to move or tip.‚ÄúWe know a felled tree can be fascinating, especially to children, but it is not safe to clamber about on or under them.‚ÄúWoodland Trust Scotland manages  sites across the country and, in the aftermath of any storm, public safety is our first concern.‚ÄúWhere paths are blocked, we will have them cleared as quickly as possible but, in the meantime, we call on the public to heed all path ersions and safety notices on sites.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Rail services to end early as Scotland prepares for Storm Dudley article_url   content_id   site_id title: covid vaccine offered five  year olds wales minister says
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityWales‚Äô health minister Eluned Morgan said she had read the ‚Äúyet to be published‚Äù report by the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationand would be further rolling out the jab.There are reports the JCVI announcement of its decision on whether to expand the immunisation programme to younger children has been delayed due to a disagreement with the UK Government.Responding to questions during a Plenary session at the Senedd on Tuesday, Baroness Morgan called the hold-up a ‚Äúshame‚Äù and ‚Äúperplexing‚Äù.She said: ‚ÄúIn relation to vaccination of children, the JCVI has yet to publish its report, although there are lots of clues inand other places where there seems to have been lots of leaks come out.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame and it‚Äôs perplexing to understand why that has not been published yet.‚ÄúBut I have seen a copy of that advice and we will be commencing the rollout of vaccinations for five to -year-olds.‚ÄùThe minister has not set out a timetable for when youngsters will be able to get the jab, and told Senedd members: ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre not going to do that as a matter of urgency, as we did over the Christmas period. That‚Äôs partly because the risk isn‚Äôt as great to that cohort.‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre also waiting to hear from the JCVI to see whether they‚Äôll need a booster on top of the booster for older age groups in the spring.‚ÄùShe added: ‚ÄúOf course, it‚Äôs likely to have been a very dficult decision for the JCVI, because generally, children have a milder illness and fewer hospitalisations. But, of course, they have to balance that against the prospect of missing school.‚ÄúWe have to consider very dferent issues when it comes to the vaccination of children as young as five years old, of course, so we‚Äôll be in a position where we will expect those children to be accompanied by an adult. There will be a need for informed consent, but there will be an opportunity for siblings, for example, to be brought at the same time.‚Äù.removeBaroness Morgan said children would receive the vaccine in health centres.The UK medical regulator, the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency , approved the Pfizer Covid- vaccine for use in children aged five to  last year.The dose approved for children is lower than that used for adults and older children.After the announcement, the JCVI said that the vaccine should be offered to at-risk children in this age group. It is yet to announce its decision about wider use among children aged five to .Over . million dosages of the vaccine have already been administered to five to -year-olds in the US alone.A Government spokesperson in Westminster said: ‚ÄúWe are reviewing the JCVI‚Äôs advice as part of wider decision-making ahead of the publication of our long-term strategy for living with COVID-. More detail will be set out shortly.‚ÄùThe Government in England is expected to make an announcement next week.A spokeswoman for the Scottish Government urged Westminster to quickly publish the advice, saying they ‚Äústand ready‚Äù to implement any JCVI recommendation.‚ÄúWhen the UK Government publishes the final advice on vaccination for  to -year-olds we stand ready to take it forward,‚Äù she said.‚ÄúFollowing the update from the Welsh Government on this matter in the Senedd, we hope that the UK Government will publish the JCVI advice as quickly as is practicable.‚Äù.push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Covid vaccine to be offered to all five to -year-olds in Wales, minister says article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: bp mean six nation scoreboard
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience ‚Äì the local communityHowever, novices might not be up on all the quirks of the game which could lead to confusion.One such puzzler leaving many fans scratching their heads is the initials BP seemingly randomly appearing just above the scoreboard graphic in the corner of the screen.To save face among all your new rugby pals ‚Äì here‚Äôs why it happens.BP simply stands for ‚ÄúBonus Point‚Äù which are awarded for a iety of reasons during the competition.During the game, the bonus point they are referring to is when a team scores four tries or more. Achieve this and they will receive an extra point.But is not just during the game a team can be awarded bonus points. Read on to discover what points a team could pick up during and of the Six Nations games.The winning team will be awarded four points. Any winning team scoring four tries or more in any game, an additional bonus point will be awarded.The losing side gets no points but can achieve bonus match points. If a team scores four tries or more or loses by a margin of seven points or fewer they will be awarded one point. If the losing side scores four tries or more and loses by a margin of seven points or fewer, they will be awarded two points.Unions that draw a Match shall each be awarded two Match Points and any of them that scores four tries or more in the process shall be awarded a further one Match Point.For a draw, two match points will be awarded to each side, howevereither team scores four tries or more during the game, they will achieve a further one bonus point. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentsComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues.
